post780.caption: "Elon Musk's House of Gigacards"The founder of Tesla, SolarCity, and SpaceX is deservedly admired for his technological insight. But is his latest business plan reckless? To find out, click the link in our bio. Illustration by @sundayfriedman

post781.caption: "Sweatbands for Health Monitoring"Wei Gao, 31, made a sweatband that combines sensors with electronic processors and a Bluetooth transmitter on a flexible circuit board. Why? "Our body is generating data all the time," Gao says. "It came into my mind: what about sweat?" Gao is working with exercise physiologists on clinical studies to look at which chemical changes can help signal signs of trouble before it's too late. To read more, follow the link in our bio. Photograph by @damienmaloney

post782.caption: "Birth Control for Mosquitoes"How the search giant Alphabet found itself breeding mosquitoes to try to stop the spread of Zika. Read on at the link in our bio. Illustration by @danielzender

post783.caption: "The One and Only Texas Wind Boom"Wind power has transformed the heart of fossil-fuel country. Can the rest of the United States follow suit? To find out, follow the link in our bio. Photograph by @sandy_carson

post784.caption: "Outsize Gene Therapy Hype"Most experts in the medical field will tell you that gene therapy has finally come of age, but the numbers tell a different story. There are hundreds of early clinical trials but only a handily of late-stage ones have actually reached completion. To read more, click the link in our bio. Illustration by @matthewhollister

post785.caption: "The Internet Is No Place for Elections"It's not safe to connect our voting infrastructure to the Internet, but some election boards are doing it anyway. To read about why voting online isn't safe, follow the link in our bio. Animation by @patrick.kyle

post786.caption: "Google Assistant"This week Google began a project to rethink the conventional search engine that got the company where it is today. The alternative is a virtual assistant that we would be just as dependent on as the search box. "We are evolving search," said Google CRO Sundar Pichai. Click our bio link to read more. Illustration by @vinnieneu

post787.caption: "Computer Gameplay is Serious Business"Oriol Vinyals, 33, is working at Google DeepMind in London to create computers that can teach themselves how to play and win complex gamesnot by hard-coding the rules but by enabling them to learn from experience. To read more about Vinyals, follow the link in our bio. Photograph by @jess.kohl

post788.caption: "Drone Security Guards"An unarmed, unmanned aircraft that shines bright lights and broadcasts warning messages is intended to combine the best of human security guards, cameras, and alarms. To read more about the startup that's building them, Aptonomy, click the link in our bio. Animation by @kclogg

post789.caption: "Personal Stakes in the Game"A devastating diagnosis led Sonia Vallabh, 32, to switch career paths, become a scientist, and stay hot on the trail of a cure for the deadly brain disease she inherited from her mother. To read more of Sonia's incredible story, follow the link in our bio. Photograph by @leonard_greco

post790.caption: "OK Computer, Write Me a Song"Google says its AI software could make creative suggestions to help musicians, architects, and visual artists. To find out how that would work, clink on our bio link. Illustration by @helloachron

post791.caption: "An Augmented-Reality Dreamer Tries to Trounce HoloLens"Meron Gribetz, 30, unveiled his companys latest headset, the Meta 2, which sells for less than a third of what the HoloLens headset is going for. It lets you do things like grab and prod 3-D imagery with your hands, or conduct a video call with another Meta user, who can hand you a virtual object that you can then inspect from any angle. To read more, follow the link in our bio. Photograph by @damienmaloney

post792.caption: "Behind Google's Secretive Ad-Blocking Policy"The decision to stop carrying certain types of online ads prompts questions. Read more by clicking our bio link. Illustration by @sarahmazzetti

post793.caption: "Bots Are Getting Better at Detecting Your Agitation"A virtual assistant that can tell you're frustrated can slow down and help you out instead of further frustrating you. To read about how this works, click the link in our bio. Illustration by @oscarrboltongreen

post794.caption: @mandland made sure to have a cup of tea at the ready while she read her copy of the Business Issue. Tag us in your public photos with and show us how and where you like to read the magazine!

post795.caption: Dive into this month's print issue, on newsstands and online now. The issue features four different covers this month in honor of our 16th annual Innovators Under 35 list. So crack the spine and meet 35 people whose ideas will shape the futuretheyre inquisitive and persistent, inspired and inspiring. Follow the link in our bio and subscribe to read the full issue online. Cover photos by @jacksonkrule, @leonard_greco, @damon_c, and @timothysean

post796.caption: "Microsoft's Top Lawyer Becomes a Civil Rights Crusader"Brad Smith, the number 2 executive at Microsoft, is fighting the U.S. government in a series of cases that will shape online privacy and the cloud business. Smiths cases affect anyone who stores data in the cloud, from large corporations to the millions of individuals using Skype and Web mail. To read more, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @mikemcquade

post797.caption: "The Do-Not-Call List Doesn't Work Anymore"Illegal robocalls that try to scam you out of money are flourishing. Can the phone companies figure out how to stop them? Follow the link in our bio to find out. Animation by Nicholas Little

post798.caption: "Artificial Intelligence Wants to Be Your Bro, Not Your Foe"Artificial intelligence will transform just about everything, but technologists should stop fretting that it's going to destroy the world like Skynet. To read more, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @johnfmalta

post799.caption: "New Gene-Editing Techniques"Kevin Esvelt, 34, is already developing new gene-editing techniques that could eradicate diseases like malaria and Lyme disease. But he also warns of their potential to disrupt how ecosystems evolve. To read more about gene drives, follow the link in our bio. Photograph by @leonard_greco

post800.caption: "Why We Still Don't Have Better Batteries"A number of startups are close to producing devices that are economical, safe, compact, and energy-dense enough to store energy at a cost of less than $100 per kilowatt-hour. But those batteries are not being commercialized at anywhere near the pace needed to hasten the shift from fossil fuels to renewables. To read more about the holy grail of batteries, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @federicojordan

post801.caption: "Gene Editing Ban"A Congressionally imposed ban on genetically modified babies has an important downside: the testing of new therapies to prevent a debilitating mitochondrial disease in babies has now hit a dead end. To read more about this ban, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @roman_m

post802.caption: It's here! This year's list of 35 Innovators Under 35 is full of dreamers and disrupters who are shaking up their fieldsfrom augmented reality to women's health. These people are inventors, entrepreneurs, visionaries, humanitarians, and pioneers. Click the link in our bio to meet these 35 inspiring young innovators. Illustrations by @morgzilla28

post803.caption: "How to Give Fake Hands Real Feeling"In Zhenan Bao's lab at Stanford, researchers are inventing materials for touch-sensitive prosthetics. The electronic skin can sense pressure, heal when cut, and process sensory data. To read more about these bionic hands, follow the link in our bio. Photograph by @rcrivera

post804.caption: "The Next Must-Have Smartphone Feature"Googles new location-sensing system, Tango, will make augmented reality far more useful. To read more about how Tango could transform your smartphone, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @beefstrong

post805.caption: "Life as an Entrepreneur in a Violent Mexico"The Mexican market offers great opportunity for mobile technologies, but it comes with a risk. Click on our bio link to read the story of Alejandro Avila, the 30-year-old Mexican cofounder of Espiral, a mobile wallet service. Illustration by @vinnieneu

post806.caption: "Will Embryonic Stem Cells Ever Cure Anything?"Doug Melton, founder of Semma Therapeutics, has been on a quest to cure his kids' type 1 diabetes for 15 years, to no avail. To read more about Melton's quest for a cure, click on the link in our bio. Illustration by @marinamuun

post807.caption: "AI's Language Problem"Machines that truly understand language would be incredible. But we don't know how to build them. Today we're featuring art that represents how understanding language can be open to interpretation, depending on the context and even the appearance of the words or letters. To read more about this big AI challenge, follow the link in our bio. John Baldessari, "Pure Beauty," 1966 - 1968

post808.caption: "AI's Language Problem"Machines that truly understand language would be incredible. But we don't know how to build them. Today we're featuring art that represents how understanding language can be open to interpretation, depending on the context and even the appearance of the words or letters. To read more about this big AI challenge, follow the link in our bio. Raina Auerbach, "The Answer/Wasn't Here II," 2008

post809.caption: "AI's Language Problem"Machines that truly understand language would be incredible. But we don't know how to build them. Today we're featuring art that represents how understanding language can be open to interpretation, depending on the context and even the appearance of the words or letters. To read more about this big AI challenge, follow the link in our bio. Mel Bochner, "Babble," 2011

post810.caption: "Can We Help the Losers in Climate Change?"The demise of the coal industry should start a discussion of how we will respond to the economic upheaval caused by global warming. To read more about this response, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @danielzender

post811.caption: "Precision Medicine"The hope is that precision medicinewhich creates a medical portrait of individuals, and designs more effective, targeted treatments for themwill eventually be used to treat major illnesses. But that will be challenging. Those conditions are complex and may not have a clear genomic component. To read more about what's holding up precision medicine from reaching you, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @patrick.kyle

post812.caption: "The HR Person at Your Next Job May Actually Be a Bot"The next time you're hired, you might find yourself getting information about payroll, vacations, and expenses by talking to a chatbot instead of consulting a handbook for new employees or talking to someone at HR. To read more about the imminent rise of chatbots, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @aishathesheriff

post813.caption: "Fail-Safe Nuclear Power"Cheaper and cleaner nuclear plants could finally become realitybut not in the United States, where the technology was invented more than 50 years ago. To read more about why, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by Edwin Fotheringham

post814.caption: "Google and Microsoft Want Every Company to Scrutinize You With AI"The tech giants are eager to rent out their AI breakthroughs to other companies. To read more about the spread of AI techniques, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @oscarrboltongreen

post815.caption: "Genomic Data"Indians with colon cancer have different genetic mutations from the ones that appear in Western countries. A startup called Global Gene Corp plans to study Indian patients' genomes to find out why colon cancer expresses itself differently in the two groups, which may yield clues to better treatment. To read more about Global Gene Corp, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by JooHee Yoon

post816.caption: "Genomics Maverick"J. Craig Venter's goal is to sequence at least one million genomesalong with information about some of the DNA donors' health historiesto find better ways to treat and prevent a range of disorders common among aging people, from cancer to heart disease. Oh, and his dog's name is Darwin. To read more about Venter's venture, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @rebeccaclarke

post817.caption: "Prosper and Live Longer"A new study highlights how poverty affects life expectancy. To read about the results, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @rrebekkaa

post818.caption: In honor of the 47th anniversary of the moon landing today, we're doing a day early. A few months before Apollo 11 successfully landed on the moon, our May 1969 cover featured Apollo 9 pilot Russell Schweickart exiting the Lunar Module to complete tests that would later be crucial to Apollo 11's success. The red text on the cover reads: Red Rover: Do you want me to start, Jim? Spider: Yeah, Rusty. Red Rover: Okay, here I go. Spider: Rusty, I want you to evaluate those handles and when you get through with that, I want a conclusion from you on whether it's a practical way of doing it, like we said it was. Red Rover: Okay. Spider: Stay away from the radar antenna. Red Rover: Rog. Oh, yeah, this is very good. Spider: Yes. Hey, let me get that camera out. Red Rover: Okay. Spider: Anything left of that one? Red Rover: Oh, running very good. This is no problem at all. Spider: Good. Be right there. Smile. Cover design by Ralph Coburn

post819.caption: "Earth-like Exoplanets"Scientists have discovered potentially habitable planets just 40 light-years from Earth. To read more about these planets, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @edward_monaghan

post820.caption: "Better Than Opioids?"Soon your doctor might be prescribing virtual reality instead of a painkiller. In one study, VR did about as well as narcotics in reducing pain. To read more about this futuristic approach to pain reduction, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @nivbavarsky

post821.caption: "The Glowing Plant Is Total B.S."Do-it-yourself biologists who hit the crowdfunding jackpot with their proposed glowing plant have learned that genetic engineering isn't so easy after all. There is still no glowing plant. To read more about this biohacking flop, follow the link in our bio. Animation by @mattjpanuska

post822.caption: "Tougher Turing Test Exposes Chatbots' Stupidity"We have a long way to go if we want virtual assistants to understand us. To read more about the new stakes in the Turing Test, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @maxembargo

post823.caption: "Before PCs Vanish, Microsoft Fights for Relevance in the Cloud"Under Satya Nadella, the software giant hopes to survive by overturning the way it has always done business. Follow the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Tibor Krpti

post824.caption: "Toyota Makes a U-Turn on Autonomous Cars"The world's largest automaker is finally getting serious about self-driving technologies. Follow the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @michael__kirkham

post825.caption: "How to Help Self-Driving Cars Make Ethical Decisions"Engineers and ethicists are increasingly coming together to guide computerized decision-making. A pre-programmed ethics module for your self-driving car wont be available tomorrow, but it might be better to make one sooner rather than later. To read more, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by Victor Kerlow

post826.caption: "Are Face Recognition Systems Accurate? Depends on Your RaceEverything we know about the face recognition systems the FBI and police use suggests the software has a built-in racial bias. That isnt on purposeits an artifact of how the systems are designed, and the data they are trained on. But it is problematic. Follow the link in our bio for the full story. Illustration by @hellophia

post827.caption: This sketch was made by Francis Crick in 1953, showing his first impression of the DNA molecule. It appeared on our website in 2014 for an article about CRISPR, a new biotechnology on the scene two years ago. Drawing courtesy of @wellcomecollection Library, London

post828.caption: "23andMe Sells Data for Drug Search"The consumer genetic-testing startup has amassed one of the world's largest databases of DNA. Now it is sifting through it for clues to new drugs. Follow the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @davidboring90

post829.caption: "Funding of Space Ventures Gets a Lift""Space is finally being taken seriously by the investment community," says Jane Poynter, CEO of World View. "We've been talking about a vibrant ecosystem of entrepreneurs and investors for decades, and finally it's actually emerging." To read more about what's "fueling" space investments, follow our bio link. Illustration by @oscarrboltongreen

post830.caption: "Making It Easy to Make Apps"App Inventor is a tool that lets people with virtually no coding experience make Android apps. It enabled a group of girls in India, who range in age from 8 to 16, to develop an app that uses geotagging and SMS to communicate with fire sensors to alert neighbors via text message if there's a fire nearby. To read the full story, please follow the link in our bio. Illustration by Luc Melanson

post831.caption: "Intel Outside as Other Companies Prosper from AI Chips"The world's leading chip maker missed a huge opportunity in mobile devices. Now the rise of artificial intelligence gives the company another chance to prove itself. Follow the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by Gary Taxali

post832.caption: "24M's Batteries Could Better Harness Wind and Solar Power"the startup's cheaper way to make lithium-ion batteries could make it cost-effective to store energy from renewable sources. Follow the link in our bio to read more. Photograph by Adam DeTour

post833.caption: "As It Searches for Suspects, the FBI May Be Looking at You"The FBI has access to nearly 412 million facial photos in its facial recognition system, but according to a new governing watchdog report, the bureau doesn't know how error-prone the system is, or whether it enhances or hinders investigations. To read the full story, follow our bio link. Animation by @danielzender

post834.caption: "Dear Silicon Valley: Forget Flying Cars, Give Us Economic Growth"Despite impressive advances in artificial intelligence and automation, the economy remains in a troubling slowdown. Follow the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @emilianoponzi

post835.caption: The July/August 2016 issue is live on our website today and will be on newsstands July 5. Follow our bio link to read the cover story, "Guaranteed Income: The New American Dream?" as well as our annual ranking of the 50 smartest companies this year, and more. Cover illustration by @obrienillustration

post836.caption: Before our list of the 50 Smartest Companies of 2016 comes out tomorrow, take a look back at one of our other big lists of the year. This past February, we rounded up the 10 Breakthrough Technologies of 2016. To read about those 10 technologies, follow our bio link. Illustration by @jessica_svendsen

post837.caption: "Why Scientists Are So Worried about Brexit"On June 23, the UK will vote on whether or not to leave the EU, and scientists are worried. Funding for British research and innovation is only one reason. To read more about this, follow our bio link. Illustration by @simonlandrein

post838.caption: "The Road to Solar Fuels Hits a Speed Bump"We can now efficiently split water to make hydrogen, but a practical way to make fuels via artificial photosynthesis remains an elusive goal. To read more, please follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @jonwrhan

post839.caption: "Why Startups Are Struggling"Even amid the venture capital boom of the past few years, entrepreneurs are finding it harder to build big, enduring companies. What does this mean for the future of innovation? Visit our bio link to dig into this long read. Illustration by @yannkebbi

post840.caption: "Immune Engineering"Genetically engineered immune cells are slowly but surely saving the lives of cancer patients. And that may be just the start. To read more about this breakthrough technology, follow our bio link. Illustration by @jonwrhan

post841.caption: The cover of our special issue, "Energy 2016." The issue looks at how the modern world is rethinking its energy sources, as the developing world tries to get up to speed. To read the articles inside this issue, please follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @merijnhos

post842.caption: "Basic Income: A Sellout of the American Dream"Schemes for giving everyone a guaranteed income are gaining momentum in Silicon Valley and throughout Western Europe. It's a great idea, until you look closely. To learn why a universal basic income isn't in our best interest, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @javier_jaen

post843.caption: "Gene Therapy Is Curing Hemophilia"Sure, gene therapy has been tried before. What's different this time is Spark Therapeutics' therapy looks as if it might work every timea consistency that's eluded prior efforts. In short, it looks like a product, not an experiment. To read more about this therapy, click the link in our bio. Illustration by @sarahmazzetti

post844.caption: "Oculus Rift Is Too Cool to Ignore"Now that virtual reality has arrived (again), it's here to stayeven if it's not clear exactly how we will end up using it. To read a first person review of Oculus Rift, follow the link in our bio. Photograph by @damienmaloney

post845.caption: "The All-American iPhone"Political candidates opposed to free trade say Apple should make phones in the United States. To see how much that would cost, follow the link in our bio for the full article. We broke it down soup to nuts. Illustration by Owen Smith

post846.caption: "China's Internet Contradictions"Mobile innovation in China is flourishing and bringing new convenience to daily life. Is that happening despite or because of the country's strict controls on online expression? To read the rest of today's website cover story, follow our bio link. Illustration by @noma_bear

post847.caption: Apples Encryption ProblemRedesigning iCloud so that only customers can unlock their data would increase security, but would also increase the risk of people irrevocably losing access to precious photos and messages when they lose their passwords. To read the rest of todays cover story on the site, follow our bio link. Illustration by @helloachron

post848.caption: Sucking AirA pilot plant north of Vancouver is testing a process to suck carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere to help lower carbon emissions. See the full photo essay by following the link in our bio. Photograph by @kamilbialous

post849.caption: "SolarCity's Gigafactory"A $750 million solar facility in Buffalo will produce a gigawatt of high-efficiency solar panels per year and make the technology far more attractive to homeowners. To read more about the facility, follow our bio link. Photo by @dirtywhitebucks

post850.caption: Today's cover story is "Q&A: Rachel Haot"The former chief digital officer of New York, Rachel Haot, explains why government and entrepreneurs need to work together. And why the best thing an entrepreneur can do is fight inertia. To read her full conversation with our editor in chief Jason Pontin, please follow our bio link. Photograph by @samanthacasolari

post851.caption: "A Boost for Solar"Silicon probably won't be replaced as the dominant solar material anytime soon, but it might not be too long before it gets a partner from a promising class of materials called perovskites that could make solar cells far more efficient. To read more about perovskites, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @moniiqwa

post852.caption: "Slack"How a service built for the era of mobile phones and short text messages is changing the workplace. See our bio link for more on this, and other 10 Breakthrough Technologies of 2016. Illustrations by @miguelporlan

post853.caption: "Cyber Survival"Cyberattacks are getting worse, so we published a collection of stories examining key vulnerabilities around the world, and the innovative technological responses that are making a difference. To read this collection of stories on cybersecurity, please follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @sachinteng

post854.caption: "Monsanto Cultivates a Rose That Doesn't Wilt"New advances in biotechnology could keep your flowers in bloom longer. To read the full story, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @morgzilla28

post855.caption: #fbf "Enlightened Spaces"In 2014 we reviewed the work of James Turrell, then 71, who makes innovative art out of the most fundamental elements: light, space, and time. Here, an aperture in the wall is covered by a surface of frosted glass with a digitally controlled LED display behind it. For more on Turrell's work, click the link in our bio. James Turrell, "Raethro, Pink," 1968 Installation view at Louise Blouin Foundation, London, 2006

post856.caption: "A Renaissance Woman for the Nano Age"Sangeeta Bhatia is an engineer, doctor, entrepreneur, and mother, who invented a device that tests whether potential drugs are toxic. Now she's working on fighting malaria and curing cancer. You can read more about this talented woman by clicking the link in our bio. Illustration by Thomas Ehretsmann

post857.caption: "Snow in Vietnam and Other New Climate Patterns Threaten Farmers"Doan Van Thuy, vice chairman for agriculture in the Yan Ten district of Yen Bai province, reports that at least 60 cows and buffalo died in his ward, and 300 hectares of rice seedlings were destroyed because of snow this year. Thuy, who is in his 50s, had never even seen snow before. Please click the link in our bio to read more. Illustration by @dadushin

post858.caption: "Companies Adapt to Climate Change"Most industries seem to be in a similar spot: aware that climate change is likely to affect their future but not yet planning for it with any consistency or depth. But a few are. To read more about those companies, please follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @sergiomembrillas

post859.caption: "Smart Bandages"Researchers have developed a new kind of wound dressing that could serve as an early-detection system for infections by turning fluorescent green. Illustration by @johnfmalta

post860.caption: "Musical Neurons"For the first time, neuroscientists have identified a neural population in the human auditory cortex that responds specifically to music, but not to speech or other environmental sounds. To read the story, please follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @joooheeeyooon

post861.caption: "Fusion's Future"A startup in California has raised $500 million to chase the elusive dream of fusion power. Is this crazy, or is the company on to something? Here, two men are above the central confinement vesselby 2017, the next version will be able to heat plasma up to 40 million degrees Celsius. To see the full photo essay, please follow the link in our bio. Photo by @julianxberman

post862.caption: Today's cover story is "Imaginative ComputingAn enigmatic company called Vicarious hopes that reinventing the neural network will give computers an imagination, and help them make the leap from processing words and symbols to comprehending the real world. To read the rest of the story, please follow our bio link. Illustration by @hullophia

post863.caption: Our three views in the May/June issue cover smartphone encryption, gene drives, and the increasing work of robots in China's manufacturing industry. To read the views, follow the link in our bio. Illustrations by @sundayfriedman

post864.caption: "Moore's Law Is Dead. Now What?"Shrinking transistors have powered 50 years of advances in computingbut now other ways must be found to make computers more capable. To read this story, please follow the link in our bio. Animation by @yukai_du

post865.caption: "Sky-High Air Cooling"An unconventional approach to cooling sends heat to the cold sky. To read the full story, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @phantasmosis

post866.caption: "The Nauseating Disappointment of Oculus Rift"Oculus's VR headset can be thrilling, but will you buy it if some experiences make you sick and it's hard to use for more than 20 minutes? Our senior editor of mobile spent a week playing around with the headset, you can read her whole review by following the link in our bio. Illustration by @roman_m

post867.caption: "The World's Most Expensive Medicine Is a Bust"The first gene therapy approved in the Western world costs $1 million and has been used just once. The doctor who tried it says the price is "absolutely too high." You can read the full article by following our bio link. Illustration by @ericpetersenart

post868.caption: "Daredevil Drones"Startup Skydio has developed a more sophisticated autopilot for stones. Beyond obstacle avoidance, it lets an aircraft orient itself and navigate through busy areas. Follow our bio link to the read the rest of the story. Illustration by @timlahan

post869.caption: The May/June issue lives! And with a provocative cover story to boot: "What If Apple Is Wrong?" You can find it on newsstands tomorrow, or online right nowjust follow the link in our bio. Photo by @jonnotherattman

post870.caption: "Twitter's AI Knows What's Happening in Live Video"Twitter has been developing technology that automatically recognizes what's happening in live video, a step toward sophisticated recommendations. Illustration by @gwendallebec

post871.caption: Yep, those are mosquitoes. But not just any mosquitoes. In one of our May/June issue's big feature pieces, "The Extinction Invention," we look at a new technology called gene drives that could wipe out malaria-carrying mosquitoes. But is it too risky to do? You can read the full article by following the link in our bio. Photo by Michele Borzoni

post872.caption: "We Still Haven't Found a Fountain of Youth in Our DNA"Some 90-year-olds still have jet black hair, among other signs of youth and health, but the genetic underpinnings of these exceptional people continue to elude us. To read more, follow the link in our bio. Illustration by @evahscat

post873.caption: "Who Approved the Generically Engineered Foods Coming to Your Plate? No one"USDA regulations can't keep up with the changing technology used to genetically engineer crops. Follow the link in our bio to check out the full story. Illustration by @johnfmalta

post874.caption: "New 3-D Printing Technique Makes Ceramic Parts"A new way of making these tough materials, involving a polymer that becomes a ceramic in the kiln, could be a key step in producing better airplane engines and long-lasting machine parts. You can read more by following the link in our bio. Photo by @julianxberman

post875.caption: "How to Prevent a Plague of Dumb Chatbots"The best (and least annoying) chatbots will be those that recognize their limitations, and occasionally turn to humans for help. Illustration by @espenfriberg

post876.caption: As you wait for the New York primary results to roll in, check out the link in our bio to read one of our cover stories last week, "Personality Mining"The latest data-driven campaign pitches target you based on your personality, not just your demographics. Illustration by @hullophia

post877.caption: Today's cover story on the website is, "Drugs on Demand"The method behind drug manufacturing is dangerously out of date. This automatic drug-making machine could represent the future of pharmaceuticals. Read the full story by clicking the link in our bio. Illustration by @davidboring90

post878.caption: "Genetic Superheroes"Clues to novel treatments could be gleaned from people who have all the DNA mutations for some serious diseases, but are miraculously disease-free. So far, more than a dozen of these people have been discovered. Read the full news article by following the link in our bio. Illustration by @tomium

post879.caption: Today's cover story is the "Gene-Editing Mailroom"Each weekday at 8 a.m. at the offices of AddGene in Cambridge, Massachusetts, interns start loading UPS packages containing the raw DNA material needed for gene-editing, sending it as far away as Zimbabwe and Croatia. Follow our bio link to read the full story. Animation by @simonlandrein

post880.caption: Today's cover story over on the site is, "What If Apple Is Wrong?"Since Apple stopped being able to get into its devices, the office of Manhattan district attorney Cyrus Vance Jr. has been unable to carry out more 215 search warrants for iPhones and iPads in cases that include homicide and sexual abuse of children. Follow our bio link to read the full feature. Photo by @jonnotherattman

post881.caption: "Tech Slowdown"Despite the allure of apps and social media, today's digital technologies are doing little to generate the kind of prosperity that previous generations enjoyed, a prominent economist argues. But that doesn't mean we should give up on innovation. To read the full story, check out our bio link. Illustration by @paulrogersstudio

post882.caption: "Tech Slowdown"Despite the allure of apps and social media, today's digital technologies are doing little to generate the kind of prosperity that previous generations enjoyed, a prominent economist argues. But that doesn't mean we should give up on innovation. To read the full story, check out our bio link. Illustration by @paulrogersstudio

post883.caption: "Man and Machine"To fine-tune its machine learning and provide better search results faster, Pinterest turned to an unexpected source: human intelligence. Illustration by @aishathesheriff

post884.caption: "How Google Plans to Solve Artificial Intelligence"Mastering Go is just the beginning for Google DeepMind, which hopes to create human-like artificial intelligence. Illustration by @jonwrhan

post885.caption: "App Spots Objects for the Visually Impaired"A new iPhone app uses machine learning to identify objects for people with poor eyesight, and it doesn't need an Internet connection. Illustration by @matthewhollister

post886.caption: "Harbingers of Failure"If these customers like your new product, its probably doomed. These hapless consumers have a higher preference for risk than other buyers. Illustration by @benkalt

post887.caption: "Google's Quantum Dream Machine"Physicist John Martinis could deliver one of the holy grails of computing to Google: A machine that dramatically speeds up today's applications and makes new ones possible. Illustration by @dadushin

post888.caption: "The Feds Are Wrong to Warrant-Proof Phones"For most of history, communications were warrant-proofa conversation, a phone call, a typed or handwritten letter, they all disappeared once the communication was over. For law enforcement purposes, encrypted phones are equally inaccessible, so the debate over not being able to access their information is curious. Illustration by Victor Kerlow.

post889.caption: Today's cover story on the website: "Health-Tracking Startup Fails to Deliver on Its Ambitions"Quanttus spent several years trying to track blood pressure at the wrist, but doing so appears to be even more difficult than the company thought. Illustration by @patrick.kyle

post890.caption: It's amazing what a strategically placed pair of sunglasses can do to a coverin this case the May/June issue from last summer. The March/April issue is out now; show us how you're enjoying it by tagging your pictures with

post891.caption: Today's top story on the website is, "A Robotic Home That Knows You're Hungover"A startup called Brain of Things is developing apartment buildings in California with sensors, automated appliances, and the ability to learn and adapt to an owner's habits. Illustration by @johnfmalta

post892.caption: "The AI Doctor Will Hear You Now"U.K.-based startup Babylon will launch an app later this year that will listen to your symptoms and provide medical advice. You can read the full article over on the homepage today. Illustration by @mukaigrimace

post893.caption: Our cover story over on the site today: "WeChat in Schools"New homework assignments at 7 p.m., corrections due by midnight: how teachers, parents, and students in some schools in China are using WeChat to perpetuate round-the-clock pressure. Illustration by @marinamuun

post894.caption: "When Biology Meets Ideology"At the heart of a new book, Lysenko's Ghost, are the ways that politics, religion, cultural norms, and ideologies of all kinds distort science. Illustration by @cristianacouceiro

post895.caption: "Precise Gene Editing in Plants"We need to increase agricultural productivity to feed the world's growing population, which is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050. CRISPR offers an easy, exact way to alter genes to create traits such as disease resistance and drought tolerance. Photo by @grantcornett

post896.caption: "In Apple vs. the FBI, There Is No Technical Middle Ground"Either you let law enforcement get into encrypted devices and run the risk of letting others find a similar way in, or you don't. Illustration by Rebekkah Dunlap

post897.caption: "Conversational Interfaces"China is an ideal place for voice interfaces to take off, because Chinese characters were hardly designed with tiny touch screens in mind. But people everywhere should benefit as Baidu advances speech technology and makes voice interfaces more practical and useful. That could make it easier for anyone to communicate with the machines around us. Illustration by @tomium

post898.caption: "Power from the Air"Even the smallest Internet-connected devices typically need a battery or power cord. Not for much longer. Technology that lets gadgets work and communicate using only energy harvested from nearby TV, radio, cell-phone, or Wi-Fi signals is headed toward commercialization. Illustration by @brendantheblob; photo by @bermanphotos

post899.caption: "Apple's 'Code = Speech' Mistake""If we were to accept the fantasy that Code = Speech, we would be putting our ability to regulate our fast-changing digital society in peril," argues Neil Richards, a law professor from Washington University in St. Louis. Check out the full story on today's homepage. Illustration by @sarahmazzetti

post0.caption: Ok UFO hunters, here we go The Pentagon has released new information about a series of fascinating encounters between US Navy pilots and unidentified flying objects. The hazard reports include details about the size and shape of the unidentified aerial phenomena. It's an interesting twist after decades of denial from the US government. To be clear, the Pentagon confirming authentic UFO videos doesn't necessarily mean we've found aliens, but it does mean that we don't really have an explanation for these flying objects in the footage, hence UFO. While unusual aircraft can't be ruled out, it's entirely possible the objects seen in Navy videos might be drones, although no nearby drone operators could be located. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what the Pentagon had to say about these UFOs. #UFO

post1.caption: According to a new report by The Wall Street Journal, Chinese and Iranian hackers are targeting US efforts to develop a coronavirus vaccine. China has long engaged in the theft of biomedical research, and COVID-19 research is the fields Holy Grail right now, assistant attorney general for national security John Demers told the WSJ. While its commercial value is of importance, the geopolitical significance of being the first to develop a treatment or vaccine means the Chinese will try to use every tool both cyber intrusions and insiders to get it. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #COVID19

post2.caption: Two new provisions tacked on to the Patriot Act would, if signed into law, grant the federal government far greater powers to probe citizens private lives online. Introduced by Senate GOP Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, the provisions would allow the FBI to collect any Americans web browsing and search history without a warrant. If the American government is determined to see just how much time I'm spending on Instagram, well that's their call, but the new provisions have many digital privacy advocates and even some other US Senators deeply concerned. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the new provisions. #cybersecurity

post3.caption: A team of research physicists at Princeton University may have found a new way to control fusion reactions an incremental step towards making fusion energy, the holy grail of energy production, a reality. Fusion power is a proposed form of generating electricity that works by using heat from nuclear fusion reactions. During the process two lighter atomic nuclei fuse together to make one heavier one, releasing energy as well. Most fusion reactors today use light elements in the form of plasma to generate power, but these can be incredibly hot, unpredictable, and difficult to control. That's why it's a pretty big deal that these Princeton researchers think they may have found a way to make fusion reactors more stable. Tap the link in our bio to read more about their process. #energy

post4.caption: Would you work with a bot for a boss? That's the premise of our next digital conversation! Automation of our workplaces has been a topic of discussion for years, but how are algorithms and automation innovating our working lives today? Come learn more and join the discussion in the latest, free digital salon in our next:Work digital event series. Tap the link in our bio to save a spot. Futurism bless.

post5.caption: What does the future of work look like? Thinking about the future of the working world raises important questions. How will businesses shift as we move forward from a global pandemic? How will people find new ways to support their families, and how can technology help us to do that? If you're curious about the future, join us on Tuesdays and Thursdays for a free weekly digital salon series, next:Work! We've brought together experts from all backgrounds to talk about the future of work. Tap the link in our bio to see the full agenda or to reserve a spot. #work

post6.caption: Get this, doctors are cloning COVID patients' antibodies to create a new treatment. When a person recovers from an infectious disease their immune system develops antibodies to help prevent them from getting sick again. A team of doctors and medical researchers from Mount Sinai Health System and the pharmaceutical company Sorrento Therapeutics are hoping to leverage those antibodies by taking them from recovered COVID patients and cloning them en mass. The antibodies would be turned into a "pharmaceutical cocktail" which could help keep someone healthy for up to two months. A vaccine takes time to generate immunity and not everyone will respond to a vaccine, especially the elderly and immune-compromised patients, Sorrento CEO Henry Ji told Futurism. A neutralizing antibody cocktail bypassed the need for a patient to respond to a vaccine and gives instant immunity upon injection. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the team's work. #health

post7.caption: Scientists built a prototype jet engine that propels itself without fossil fuels. Air travel represents a small but not insignificant portion factor of climate change. With a prototype jet engine like this though planes might one day be propelled by nothing but electricity and the air around them. The device works by compressing air and ionizing it with microwaves, generating plasma that thrusts it forward, according to research published in the journal AIP Advances. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the work being done on this prototype.

post8.caption: Tim Burton takes on outer space. Astronomers recently announced the discovery of a distant brown dwarf, a celestial body that resembles a star, thats covered in dark brown stripes. Sort of like a cross between Jupiter and something Tim Burton might draw, the discovery is rare but not entirely unheard of. What's even more notable, perhaps, is the technique used by the Caltech astronomers, known as polarimetry, which works similarly to the way sunglasses do and could prove a useful tool to astronomers exploring the cosmos. Tap the link in our bio to read more about polarimetry and this peculiar planet.

post9.caption: Ultimate tactical CyberTruck With the help of designer Jan Peisert, the YouTube channel Electric Future has come up with a terrifying new take on Teslas already well-armored Cybertruck. Right now the concept is little more than a series of flashy renders. But these renders feature a host of heavily military-focused add-ons that show how a CyberTruck could become quite a unit in any armed force. Tap the link in our bio to check out more of Peisert's renders, and Electric Future's video. #CyberTruck

post10.caption: That's right Futurists, the app is back! We've given our mobile app a tune-up and it's looking sharper than ever. It's the easiest way to stay up-to-date on all the science and technology stories from Futurism. You can browse by category and even save and share your favorites! Download it today in the App Store or Google Play Store, depending on your device. Just search for Futurism!

post11.caption: Here lies the corpse of a planet, charred by its burnt-out star. The corpse of a planet may seem like a strange place to look for signs of life, but that's exactly what researchers propose doing. It takes a special kind of Earth-like exoplanet. One orbiting a white dwarf. This particular brand of exoplanet would have survived the death of its host star: white dwarves are the remnant cores of stars that exhausted all of their fuel and collapsed. Needless to say, any life that was on such a planet when its star collapsed would most likely long be dead, but the theory is that new life could still have emerged afterward. The next step for researchers is to create a catalog of such star systems so that every astronomer can know what to look for. #astronomy

post12.caption: BOOM! - For the first time, scientists built a rocket engine powered by spiraling explosions. The wild concept, called a rotating detonation rocket engine, would completely change the way we launch rockets. It propels itself through a continuous series of powerful explosions. Based on what the researchers found, they say it could make rockets both lighter and more environmentally-friendly. Rotating detonation rocket engines were first theorized back in the 1960s. But it wasn't until recently that researchers figured out exactly how they could make one work.

post13.caption: NASA awarded three massive contracts this week for future lunar missions. It's all part of NASA's goal to put Americans on the Moon again. Among the big winners, SpaceX walked away with a massive $135 million contract to further develop the Super Heavy rocket-powered Starship. Starship, currently in development, is SpaceX's huge rocket which could one-day ferry passengers to destinations like the Moon or perhaps even further beyond. Tap the link in our bio to read more about SpaceX's plans, as well as two more lunar projects NASA is considering.

post14.caption: Microsoft wants to put your brainwaves to work. An unusual new patent application from Microsoft details a system that would read users brainwaves in exchange for cryptocurrency like Bitcoin. But there's a catch! The system would monitor your brains waves to detect specific signals, such as if you were watching an advertisement. Then the system would use those signals to mine cryptocurrencies. Nothing comes free, right? Tap the link in our bio to read more about Microsoft's patent.

post15.caption: Money, money, money (money!) Pandemic? Arguably not so great. Unless you happen to be one of several billionaires who, even now, are making more money. In fact, billionaires in the U.S. have increased their wealth by a combined $282 billion, Fast Company reports. Thats a ten percent increase over where the billionaire class stood at the beginning of March. Tap the link in our bio to read more about who's getting richer, and why.

post16.caption: We all know what happens when matter and antimatter meet... Since the two forms of matter destroy each other, it's long been a mystery how there's any matter left in the universe to form the stars and planets. Now, a team of scientists says they're getting closer to figuring out why, but it's just a first step. We dont call it a discovery yet, Stony Brook University researcher and T2K team member Chang Kee Jung told SciAm. Still, if more evidence can be found to support their theory, called leptogenesis, it could provide some answers as to why our universe is the way it is. Tap the link in our bio to read more about leptogenesis.

post17.caption: When artificial intelligence development company OpenAI created the text-writing algorithm GPT-2, it initially said it was too dangerous to release into the world. Maybe so. But since GPT-2 was released it hasn't caused the flood of misinformation its creators feared it would. Instead, it's been repurposed as an AI dungeon master and, now, used to write college papers! We caught up with Tiago, a student pursuing a Master's degree in business who says he's using GPT-2 to automate his term paper writing. He was willing to share his story and copies of his AI-generated essays on the condition that Futurism didnt share identifying information beyond his first name. Tap the link in our bio to read our exclusive interview with Tiago.

post18.caption: Every day we learn a little more. An international team of researchers say that the coronavirus doesnt just attack lungs it also assaults blood vessels throughout the body. This virus does not only attack the lungs, it attacks the vessels everywhere, University Hospital Zurich researcher Frank Ruschitzka, who worked on the research, told the South China Morning Post. It enters the endothelium, which is the defense line of the blood vessels. So it brings your own defense down and causes problems in microcirculation. The finding, published in the prestigious medical journal The Lancet, could explain why patients with conditions that affect their blood vessels like high blood pressure, hypertension, and heart disease are in more danger from the COVID than the rest of the population. As researchers learn we're sharing their work in our reporting at Futurism. Tap the link in the bio to read the latest in our ongoing coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic.

post19.caption: 2I/Borisov isn't like *other* comets... Actually, it's dramatically different than most comets we've seen before. In 2019, astronomers made an incredible discovery: a comet from a different star system making a close approach to the Sun at an extremely unusual trajectory, which was later named 2I/Borisov after the amateur astronomer who discovered it. Now, a new study by an international team of researchers led by NASA has revealed something highly unusual: gas emanating from the comet contained unusually high amounts of carbon monoxide up to 26 times higher than that of the average comet. The fact that they found any carbon monoxide isnt in itself unusual. Its one of the most commonly found molecules in space. But the extremely high concentration puzzled the researchers. You can read more about 2I/Borisov and other cool "space stuff" on our website, Futurism.com. As always, link in the bio. #NASA

post20.caption: Talk about losing steam this giant exoplanet completely ran out of gas. A distant exoplanet named TOI-849b has completely lost its gassy outer layers. What this means is that, by studying its strange state, astronomers have a rare opportunity to better understand our solar system's gas giants like Jupiter and Saturn because this exoplanet appears to be the exposed core of a similar gas giant. The most obvious explanation for why only the core of TOI-849b remains? Its atmosphere may have been incinerated away from its close proximity to a star, or a collision with another exoplanet... or maybe it's just a late bloomer! Tap the link in our bio to read more. #space #

post21.caption: There's no way around it: Our ocean's ecosystem is on the brink of a total collapse. And the global ecosystem is in far greater danger than scientists previously thought, according to a new study and thats really saying something. The research predicts that without dire action to reverse global climate change, entire ocean ecosystems could suddenly collapse this decade. Its a dire warning: as various organisms face temperatures higher than anything they have before, the study predicts sudden, massive die-offs. The world is currently rightly focused on tackling the global health emergency, Mark Wright, science director of the U.K. branch of the World Wildlife Fund, told The Guardian. However, this new research reinforces that, after we are through this extremely difficult time, we will need renewed ambitious action to address the climate and nature crisis. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the devastating ripple effect this could have on our planet. #earth

post22.caption: In a letter to world leaders, Pope Francis himself argued in favor of a global universal basic income. The idea that has recently gained more traction through the likes of Andrew Yang, previously a US presidential candidate, who formed his platform around the idea. And Yang himself was impressed with the Popes call to action. Wow, he tweeted on Sunday. Game-changing. The idea of a universal basic income is to hand out sums of money, either fixed or dependent on a number of socioeconomic factors, on a regular basis, providing the populace with enough funds to meet basic needs to help people achieve financial stability. The Pope said that many workers, including street vendors, recyclers, carnies, small farmers, construction workers, dressmakers, the different kinds of caregivers were being excluded from the benefits of globalization, while the lockdowns are becoming unbearable. Tap the link in our bio to hear more from the Pope's letter. #PopeFrancis

post23.caption: We know you're getting pretty lonely in social isolation, but it may have to continue on a bit longer than expected even for the next few years according to scientists. In a new study, a group of Harvard researchers argue that prolonged or intermittent social distancing may be necessary into 2022 due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. After analyzing computer models of several scenarios, they concluded that lifting current restrictions too quickly or too early could end up delaying the epidemics peak and possibly make consequences even more dire down the line. But the researchers also noted that their models arent meant to be hard and fast rules and that a long-term isolation could have other damaging societal effects. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the research. #coronavirus

post24.caption: This new device from MIT is essentially like "Inception" but uses a power glove instead of a dream-inducing, serum-filled briefcase. Confusing enough for you? Don't worry, it's more simple than that. Essentially, a team of researchers at MITs Dream Lab are working on an open source wearable "glove-like" device that can track and interact with dreams in a number of ways including, hopefully, giving you the ability to control the content of your own dreams. No, seriously! The teams radical goal is to prove once and for all that dreams arent just meaningless gibberish but can be hacked, augmented, and swayed to our benefit. The glove-like device is called Dormio, and it's outfitted with a host of sensors that can detect which sleeping state the wearer is in. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how the glove works to control dreams. #MIT

post25.caption: NASA spotted the mother of all "dragons" in space and of course, they found it on Mars The lighter, reddish channel is the floor of Mars Melas Chasma, a massive canyon that cuts through what is thought to be the remains of an old lake bed. NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter has been sending back troves of information about the Red Planet's surface since it first reached Martian orbit back in 2006 including this image that "resembles a fabled Chinese dragon," as noticed in a tweet by the University of Arizonas HiRISE program, which took the photo from a camera attached to the orbiter. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what we've learned about the Mars from the orbiter's journey. #NASA

post26.caption: A surprisingly simple technique is saving the lives of patients with COVID-19: positioning them on their stomachs. So why does this work so well? "Prone positioning" as it's called, may seem counter-intuitive to easy breathing, but the position actually helps patients get more oxygen to their lungs and opens up the chest. Were saving lives with this, one hundred percent, said Mangala Narasimhan, the regional director for critical care at Northwell Health in New York City, to CNN. Its such a simple thing to do, and weve seen remarkable improvement. We can see it for every single patient. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how this simple, life-saving flip helps save lives in intensive care units. #coronavirus

post27.caption: Here's what happens when someone coughs near you in the grocery store. Even an aisle away, after about a minute, the particles of their cough have dispersed through the aisle and traveled over the shelves into your aisle. More than sixty seconds and you're surrounded by infectious particles. A new 3D-rendered simulation by Finnish researchers shows exactly how aerosol particles travel in an indoor environment, like a grocery store, and how easily coronavirus can spread terrifyingly far in close quarters. Someone infected by the coronavirus, can cough and walk away, but then leave behind extremely small aerosol particles carrying the coronavirus, explained Aalto University assistant professor Ville Vuorinen in the statement about the research. These particles could then end up in the respiratory tract of others in the vicinity. Tap the link in our bio to watch the short simulation yourself and see how important it is to wear a mask and protective clothing when you go into public spaces. #coronavirus

post28.caption: This might seem like nothing but if you're an astronomer, this blur is a really big deal. So here's what we're looking at: This is a screen capture from a video of a supermassive black hole spewing a brilliant jet of particles from a new research paper published in the journal Astronomy & Astrophysics this week. The video shows a distant quasar called 3C 279 in the Virgo constellation about five billion light-years away from Earth blasting out twin fire-hose-like jets of plasma." These jets leave the black hole at 99.5 percent of the speed of light, thanks to the immense forces involved in the black hole sucking up matter. Tap the link in our bio to watch the incredible video yourself. #space .

post29.caption: New research out of China shows that as many as one in five COVID-19 patients experienced cardiac damage, heart failure and, in some instances, death while suffering from the virus. We've known that the coronavirus severely impacts patients lungs, so the focus has largely been on respiratory problems and the need for ventilators to support COVID patients which is still very true today, as there continues to be a dire ventilator shortage in hospitals. But now, cardiologists are racing to figure out if existing treatment methods for COVID-19 have to be adjusted based on how the virus is affecting the heart. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what doctors are learning from researchers from China and Italy. #COVID19

post30.caption: NASA caught a new angle of Jupiter's swirling, tumultuous surface and the results are glorious. NASA just released a dramatic image that its Juno spacecraft took of Jupiters northern regions during a close flyby in February from a distance about twice the size of the diameter of Earth. The beautiful close-up of the gas giant showed the scientists hazy "thin bands" that are running across the planet. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what astronomers think these mysterious streaks could be from. #space

post31.caption: This patch the size of a Band-Aid is filled with 400 microneedles and it's the key to a promising new COVID-19 vaccine. Researchers at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine announced today that early animal trials of the potential vaccine have shown promise so far, with human trials still in the planning stages. The vaccine dubbed PittCoVacc (Pittsburgh Coronavirus Vaccine) works in the same basic way as a flu shot: by injecting lab-made pieces of viral protein into the body to help it build an immunity. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how the patch works, and how long it may take for FDA approval and testing on humans. #coronavirus

post32.caption: What's on your mind? Researchers have built a new system that could answer that question without you saying a word by translating your brain signals directly into text. You could say it's a bit of mind reading, but not the kind you're used to from sci fi movies. The translation of thought to text works by collecting information from electrode arrays implanted in the brains of subjects. First, the scientists asked them to read sentences aloud while picking up their neural information, and then used that dataset to train an algorithm to understand what they were saying even when the subjects weren't reading aloud. Tap the link in our bio read more about how this technology could help those who've lost the ability to speak find their voice again through a computer, otherwise known as "speech prosthesis." #brain

post33.caption: Don't try this one at home. An astrophysicist in Australia ended up in the hospital, not with the coronavirus, but because he had four small magnets stuck up in his nose. Um... so how did this happen? Daniel Reardon, the physicist in question, was actually working on building a contraption that would stop you from touching your face a big no-no when preventing COVID-19 but somehow during the build, things got... a bit turned around. Tap the link in our bio to read more about his device. #coronavirus

post34.caption: Listen up: Those DIY face masks you see people sewing and selling online are, unfortunately, ineffective at preventing the coronavirus. Knitting enthusiasts are hard at work filling a giant, gaping hole in the nations supply of face masks for healthcare workers. But despite the good intentions of the "sewing army" as the New York Times called them, the simple fact is that home-sown cloth masks are nearly useless in protecting against the virus and should only be a very last resort for practitioners in the field. So what are to do when medical professionals are in desperate need of protection? Donate money to your local hospital so they can afford to buy proper gear, leave the respirator masks at the store and dont hoard them for yourself to make sure that healthcare practitioners on the front lines have access to them instead. And above all, if you can: Stay. Inside. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what the CDC says about homemade masks. (And, obviously, don't try any of the terrible DIY masks you see in this photo.) #coronavirus

post35.caption: Watch out: Bosses are trying to spy on their employees more than ever now that people are working from home. Due to the coronavirus pandemic, many employees are working remotely but does that mean managers and business leaders let up with their bizarre, over-reaching workplace surveillance? Not a chance. Bloomberg reports that workplace-surveillance software is flying off shelves and being forced on people working in their own homes a massive breach of trust and privacy. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #surveillance

post36.caption: Bill Gates is angry that we didn't do more to stop the spread of the coronavirus and he has a lot to say on the matter. In an interview with Chris Anderson, the curator of the famed TED Talks series, Gates opined "we shouldve done more... everybody should have taken notice back in January. During their discussion, Gates seems to take aim at U.S. President Donald Trump, who has been suggesting that society ease off the shelter-in-place guidelines which are crucial to keeping new infections at bay, but are hurting the economy. Its hard to tell people during an epidemic that they should go about things knowing their activity is spreading this disease," Gates said. Tap the link in our bio to watch the full interview. #BillGates

post37.caption: Move over Mars scientists think there could be life on Mercury. In a new study published last week, researchers argue there's a minuscule chance that Mercury, our Suns closest neighbor, has all it needs to host life. It is possible that as long as there was water, the temperatures would be appropriate for the survival and possibly the origin of life, the study's co-author, Jeffrey Kargel from the Planetary Science Institute, told The New York Times. The idea of life on Mercury is still a long shot, but the researchers are hopeful. Tap the link in our bio to read more about why the planet may have what it takes. #space

post38.caption: Can't handle two weeks stuck inside your house? Try a year isolated in space. Self quarantine can get pretty lonely especially if youre used to spending a lot of time around other people on a daily basis. But theres one group who are real pros when it comes to isolation: astronauts. Orbiting the Earth with nothing but empty space around you can give you a lot of time to figure out how to be alone. So now, its time to listen to the experts. Tap the link in our bio to hear advice from 5 astronauts on how to get through social isolation. If they can survive months, if not years, aboard the International Space Station, you can survive a couple of weeks locked up in your apartment. Good luck! #coronavirus

post39.caption: Doctors think they may know one of the first telltale symptoms of the coronavirus and, as you may have guessed by now from this image, it has to do with your sense of smell. For many patients, the first symptom of the bug, before a telltale cough or fever, could be losing your sense of taste, smell, or both and a fascinating new story in The New York Times found evidence that those subtle symptoms could in many cases be harbingers of a coronavirus diagnosis. Almost everybody who is hospitalized has this same story, said Italian doctor Marco Metra, whose hospital is treating hundreds of COVID-19 patients. You ask about the patients wife or husband. And the patient says, My wife has just lost her smell and taste but otherwise she is well." A prominent group of American head and neck doctors has now asked for the loss of taste and smell to be added to the list of screening criteria for COVID-19. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this new update. #coronavirus

post40.caption: Listen, things are getting ruff out there, and socially isolating at home gives people a lot of time to get... creative. But we've still gotta do what we've gotta do! Including taking our dogs out for a quick . (I'm sorry, I know that rhyme was terrible, but we all need a laugh. Oh, you didn't laugh? Okay. ) But one man, Vakis Demetriou, found a way to follow the World Health Organization's instructions to stay home and still get his dog some outdoor time by coming up with the brilliant idea of walking his pup using a drone. Now, don't try this at home. It might have worked for a little pup like this one, but your fully-grown Doberman will definitely yank that drone to the ground and get loose. But keep being creative, everyone! Tap the link in our bio to watch a video of the doggie drone in action. #creativity

post41.caption: What if you could print anything you wanted? Yes, anything! Enter: the nanofabricator. By the middle of this century, maybe even as early as 2042, our world could be drastically redefined by this new device. So, here's how it works. Nanofabricators are like tiny factories, and at first, they'll be large like early computers were but soon enough youll be able to buy one that can fit on a desk. Youll pour in some raw materials perhaps water, air, dirt, and a few powders of rare elements if required and the nanofabricator will go to work, manipulating materials at the atomic level to create anything you'd like. It sounds like science fiction although, with the advent of 3D printers in recent years, less so than it used to. But we're close to making that fiction a reality. Tap the link in our bio to read more from our friends at @singularityhub. #technology scientists

post42.caption: Scientists really really (really!) want a nuclear fusion power plant in the United States and more than 300 researchers have signed on to a report asking to prioritize it. In an ambitious push to develop and implement nuclear fusion power, the report lays out exactly what the scientific community needs and what it should prioritize to get the ball rolling. The main goal is to develop a shared, functional nuclear fusion power plant in the U.S. by the end of the decade the most ambitious and concerted call-to-arms for nuclear physicists, arguably, that the field has seen in years. But theres a lot that needs to happen before that pilot fusion plant can be built. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #energy

post43.caption: Within a day of each other, South Korea and the United States confirmed their first cases of the coronavirus two months ago, and since then, the two countries have had very different responses to national outbreaks but only one worked. Why? Let's unpack it a bit. Ever since the coronavirus pandemic hit South Korea, the country went into a state of full mobilization. While the country quickly developed tests and sent them out to nearly 300,000 of citizens over the past seven weeks, officials in the U.S. have still only issued about 60,000 tests. Meanwhile, Trump repeatedly lied about the outbreak and downplayed the danger the new coronavirus posed. But South Koreas health agencies acted as soon as the virus emerged within the country. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what lessons can be learned about these two approaches to the coronavirus COVID-19. #coronavirus

post44.caption: Researchers took a closer look at the groundbreaking first-ever image of a black hole and what they found could make the next image way crisper. Last April, the international coalition of scientists who run the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT), a network of eight telescopes from around the world, revealed the first-ever image of a black hole. The EHT image was able to catch the black holes photon sphere or photon ring, a region around a black hole where gravity is so overpowering, it forces photons to travel in orbits. But as it turns out, theres even more to the original image: the black hole actually contains a nested series of rings. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about what this means. #space

post45.caption: In what could be a major inflection point in the global coronavirus outbreak, scientists are now testing a potential COVID-19 vaccine on volunteers in Seattle. This work is critical to national efforts to respond to the threat of this emerging virus, said Lisa Jackson, a senior investigator at a Kaiser Permanente research facility whos leading the trial. Jackson and her colleagues plan to enroll 45 adult volunteers to take doses of the potential vaccine over the course of six weeks, and evaluate whether or not the doses are safe and effective at inducing an immune response. But experts warn that any one potential vaccine may well end up being a dead end, and that bringing any new vaccine to market, especially when millions or billions of doses are needed, could take months or even years. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #coronavirus

post46.caption: United we stand, divided fall! Chinese billionaire Jack Ma has pledged to donate 500,000 COVID-19 testing kits and one million face masks to the United States. Ma, the founder of Alibaba, also gave materials to other afflicted areas in Japan, Korea, Italy, Iran, and Spain. In January, Ma also donated $14.5 million towards a coronavirus vaccine. At this moment, we cant beat this virus unless we eliminate boundaries to resources and share our know-how and hard-earned lessons, Ma wrote in the statement. United we stand, divided fall! Tap the link in our bio to read more. #coronavirus

post47.caption: Next time someone tries to tell you to stop playing so many video games, tell them it's educational! There's a new way to read the news, and it's by booting up Minecraft. (Yes, Minecraft!) As governments around the globe crack down on journalistic freedom and censor their national press, Reporters Without Borders is working to deliver uncensored news to the public through an unlikely channel: an enormous library housed inside the popular block-building video game Minecraft. The massive digital library made from more than 12.5 million Minecraft blocks contains articles from journalists who have been censored in their own countries, including Russia, Mexico, Egypt, Vietnam, and Saudi Arabia. But those repressive governments can't stop us from cracking open the pixelated books in a Minecraft server! Tap the link in our bio to read more and to download the beautiful map for yourself to play around in. #Minecraft

post48.caption: Even after recovering from the coronavirus, some patients are still dealing with long-term health effects. After analyzing 12 patients who recovered from the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus, doctors at the Hong Kong Hospital Authority found that several of them now have significantly reduced lung capacity. They gasp if they walk a bit more quickly, Owen Tsang, medical director of the HKHAs Infectious Disease Center, said in a press conference. Some patients might have around a drop of 20 to 30 percent in lung function. Tap the link in our bio to read more on what else the doctors learned about the coronavirus's impact on patients. EDIT: For more context, please read our note below in the comments. vvvvv #coronanvirus

post49.caption: This might be just the thing you need to get through a 14-day self quarantine: a $1,200 gaming bed. The cozy bed concept developed by Japanese company Bauhutte somehow has enough room for a dual monitor setup, oversized cupholders, a desk lamp, and even a retractable phone holder so you dont have to go through the pain of holding your phone with your hand. (Make sure you disinfect that phone first, too!) The coronavirus is no match for social distancing, and if this bed helps you avoid social contact for the next few weeks, all the better! Plug in, lay down, and tune out. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this futuristic furniture. #gaming

post50.caption: This might be just the thing you need to get through a 14-day self quarantine: a $1,200 gaming bed. The cozy bed concept developed by Japanese company Bauhutte somehow has enough room for a dual monitor setup, oversized cupholders, a desk lamp, and even a retractable phone holder so you dont have to go through the pain of holding your phone with your hand.
