post51.caption: Science has significantly progressed since history's worst pandemics and outbreaks but historians say that our global leaders are making the same mistakes they did in the past. When a mysterious new coronavirus started to spread out of Wuhan, China, last year, fear began to grow that it would turn into a new global pandemic. Now, months after reports of an outbreak began, the coronavirus has infected more than 120,000 and killed over 4,500 people around the world a rapid spread in which some historians see parallels to deadly historical diseases like the Spanish Flu. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what mistakes society made in the past, and what we can do now to slow the spread of COVID-19. #health

post52.caption: If we dont improve our pace of progress, Im definitely going to be dead before we go to Mars." Elon Musk is anxious to get humanity to Mars even if it's literally the last thing he ever does. So, how far off are we? Musk has been closely supervising his space companys progress in constructing the first-ever functional prototype of the Starship, a 400-foot stainless steel rocket that could one day ferry up to 100 passengers to distant locales including the Moon and Mars. And his timeline for the Starship is ambitious: If all goes according to plan, he wants to establish a one million people-strong city on the Red Planet as soon as 2050 using a fleet of Starships. But despite progress towards those lofty goals, Musk still sounds pretty worried. Unless we improve our rate of innovation dramatically, then there is no chance of a base on the moon or a city on Mars, Musk said. This is my biggest concern. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about his plans for SpaceX. #ElonMusk

post53.caption: Youre Likely to Get the Coronavirus. Back in February, James Hamblin preventive medicine M.D., published book author, and staff writer for The Atlantic published a story about the COVID-19 outbreak that made this claim right in the headline. And it may have seemed extreme then, but now we know that COVID-19 cases are spreading rapidly across the globe. As workplaces tell employees to stay home, and local governments scramble to figure out their response plan, we spoke with Hamblin to discuss: What should we expect in the next few weeks of a global coronavirus outbreak? Tap the link in our bio to read the full interview. #health

post54.caption: "Nothing Really Matters." That's the title of a newly published physics paper (or the potential title of a really sad breakup ballade) in which physicists argue that extradimensional holes known as bubbles of nothing could cause the universe to consume itself from the inside out. Well.. that's grim! But don't worry: For now, it's all theoretical. Physicists have long thought that most of our universe is made up of nothingness, or vacuum, but that it's relatively stable. But now, they're questioning this conclusion. Maybe it's just a false vacuum" prone to... self-induced destruction via "nothingness bubbles." It's a bizarre theory, but tap the link in our bio to learn more about what this theoretical cosmic destruction could teach us about our universe. #science

post55.caption: Elon Musk is pretty pissed and honestly, wouldn't you be, too, if your rocket exploded? Early last week, Musk tweeted a video showing a Starship prototype dubbed SN1 exploding in a massive cloud of gas at the companys Boca Chica facilities. (It pretty much crumpled like an empty can of soda. Can of pop? Whatever, just yell at us in the comments...) Its fine, Musk tweeted afterward. Well just buff it out. Sounds like he might have been able to shake it off, but... not so much. Musk later told Ars Technica that I told them that, in the future, you treat that rocket like its your baby, and you do not send it to the test site unless you think your babys going to be OK." Tap the link in our bio to read more about how SpaceX's rapid recent hiring could have contributed to the screwup. #SpaceX

post56.caption: Something is weirdly warping our entire galaxy and it involves a galactic collision. Astronomers have known for years that the edges of the Milky Way warp, ripple, and wobble like a bowl of Jello but nobody knew why. Until now! A new study using data from the European Space Agencys star-mapping satellite Gaia has given us some answers: The disc of our Milky Way, made up of hundreds of billions of stars, is being warped as it slowly collides with a smaller neighboring galaxy. (Neighbors are always the worst even on a galactic level!) Tap the link in our bio to read more about how this warp will change our galaxy. #astronomy

post57.caption: "EEEAAAAAAEEEEEAAAAAA!" Okay, that's as close to the sound of a bat screeching as we can get. And also, it's now the sound made by a drone developed by Purdue University engineers. So, why give a drone the ability to screech? The engineers are taking a page out of a bats playbook by attaching a rig to the drone that allows it to chart out its surroundings using echolocation. Using a speaker and an array of four microphones, the drone was able to accurately map out the rooms walls and avoid collisions. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how this technology could potentially help lead to better car backup cameras or help people with disabilities navigate. #drone

post58.caption: For the first time (ever!) doctors have attempted to cure blindness by gene-hacking a patient with CRISPR technology. A team from Oregon Health & Science Institute injected three droplets of fluid into a patient's eyeball and inside those drops was CRISPR-edited DNA fragments. And once those cells in the eyeball are edited, doctors say it's permanent, and that the new cell should persist "hopefully for the life of the patient." Tap the link in our bio to read more about this groundbreaking procedure, and the rare genetic condition this will hopefully help cure. #CRISPR

post59.caption: See that asteroid? It might be worth, wait for it... a staggering $10,000 quadrillion. (!!) NASA is planning a mission to the asteroid Psyche, and it needs SpaceX's help to get there. The metal-rich asteroid orbits the Sun between Mars and Jupiter (so not *too* far away from us) and NASA plans to send out a probe to it, launched onboard a Falcon Heavy in 2022. Despite the unbelievable value of the asteroid's resources, NASAs goal, though, isnt financial. Instead, its hoping that new data about Psyche will help explain the early history of the solar system. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #space

post60.caption: Can you solve this equation? 2* = Here, let us spell it out for you: A team of physicists is working on building a functional wormhole. And what will it take to get there? Oh, you know, just two quantum entangled black holes. Conventional wisdom tells us: Nothing ever escapes from a black holes immense gravitational pull. But, according to theoretical research, two fully-entangled black holes should be able to transmit quantum information between them rather than destroying it like they usually would after it passes ones event horizon. And that would essentially create quantum teleportation. (Meaning... functional worm holes!!!) Listen, we know it's complicated. So that's why we wrote a whole article about it. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #science

post61.caption: The Trump administration really wants to control coronavirus information so much so, its even censoring its *own* infectious disease expert. So why the tight lip? It took several days for the White House to figure out who was in charge (it's VP Mike Pence). And moving forward, any government official who wants to talk about the COVID-19 outbreak will need Pence's explicit approval. Regardless of your view on politics, it's a troubling move for a few reasons: It mirrors how the Chinese government initially responded to news of a viral outbreak which involved censoring and silencing experts rather than giving the public crucial information and now all of the information will be filtered through Pence, whose regressive policies led to an HIV outbreak during his tenure as governor of Indiana. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how this policy could effect the U.S. response to the coronavirus. #coronavirus

post62.caption: Astronomers just detected a big bang but not, you know, *the* Big Bang. Researchers at the International Centre for Radio Astronomy Research discovered an explosion emanating from a supermassive black hole at the center of the Ophiuchus galaxy, which is about 390 million light-years from Earth. And it was such a violent explosion that it literally cut a hole in the cluster plasma, which is the hot gas that surrounds black holes, as spotted through X-ray telescope observations. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what this unprecedented blast can teach us about our universe. #science

post63.caption: We promise this isn't what it looks like! This might seem like a bloody scene, but it's actually... algae. So here's what's up: That green building is a research station, situated on an island just off the coast of Antarcticas northernmost peninsula. And that "Blood Snow" you're seeing isn't blood at all: It's a bright red, microscopic algae called Chlamydomonas nivalis. So you might wonder: Where did all of this come from and why are we seeing so much of it? Well, the algae thrives in freezing cold water, and so, as Antarctica suffers a record-breaking warm summer and more of its ice melts, we may be seeing more scenes like this. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this bizarre, bloody algae bloom and how climate change is drastically effecting the continent of Antarctica. #science

post64.caption: Big news for possible Planet B: Astronomers found a massive exoplanet capable of holding liquid water in livable conditions. I know a lot of you might say, "Why are we looking for Planet B when we should be taking care of Planet A, our very own Earth? And you're not wrong! But this is a pretty exceptional find by NASA and it's right in our cosmic back yard, only 124 light-years away. So, let's take a closer look at its potential. Called "K2-18b," the exoplanet is 2.6 times the radius of Earth and orbits its star within the habitable zone the region in a star system where liquid water can exist as determined by a brilliant team of astronomers from the University of Cambridge. Tap the link in our bio to read more about their findings. #space

post65.caption: If a war begins in space, who do you want sitting in the briefing room? Looks like the U.S. Space Force definitely wants Elon Musk there. As the Space Force evolved from a vague Trumpian thought to a full-fledged branch of the U.S. military, questions surfaced about what exactly it would do and who would be involved in decision making with NASA and the Air Force. Lieutenant General David Thompson, the Space Forces second-in-command, said they've begun working closely with Elon Musk's SpaceX. The Space Force plans to scan for hostile missile launches and other surveillance missions, as well as maintaining communication, GPS, and military satellites. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about how SpaceX would could help keep the peace in the stars. #space

post66.caption: BILL! BILL! BILL! Bill Nye the Science Guy has a pretty strange theory: Humans may be descendants of ancient Martians. The TV personality and public science advocate made an unusual pitch for NASA funding this week: We should fund research at the space agency to study whether humankind's origins actually began on the Red Planet. This might sound totally out there. (As far out there as, say, Mars! Sorry, bad joke.) But, as head of the influential Planetary Society, Nye's main priority is garnering funding for NASA's upcoming Mars rover mission which will attempt the first-ever feat of sending Martian rock samples back to Earth. And those little rocks will teach us a lot of important information about Mars. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #science

post67.caption: Listen, we all have needs. Even astronauts. And being stuck in space for a year can leave some things to be... desired. Let's not be coy: Astronauts need to satisfy their sexual desires, just like the rest of us. An essay published last week in The Conversation argues: NASA needs to do more to prepare for crew members' human needs. Even the dirty ones. Astronauts may face undue psychological and mental strain due to space-enforced abstinence, which could potentially be solved by bringing high-tech sex toys on the space station (Claire Denis's "High Life" anyone?) or, even AI-enabled sex robots that could act out the role of a partner. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the future of space sex and the very real psychological toll space abstinence could have. #sex

post68.caption: If there's life on Mars () it's probably going to be underground. At a recent conference about astrobiology on Mars, almost all attendees agreed: Life on Mars isn't just going to be waiting for us on the harsh surface. We're going to have to look deep inside the Red Planet. This summer, NASA plans to launch the most sophisticated Mars rover in history a 2,260-pound behemoth which, if all goes well, will eventually send samples from the Red Planet back to Earth and get us one step closer to finding that Martian life force. Tap the link in our bio to read more about why the surface of Mars is such a bad place to look for life. #Mars

post69.caption: Have any of you out there *actually* beaten the computer in online chess? (It's really hard, okay!) And even reigning global Chess grandmaster Garry Kasparov agrees with that. Twenty-three years ago, IBMs Deep Blue AI beat Kasparov at chess sending shockwaves through the worlds of chess, computing, and conspiratorial technophobes. Obviously, Kasparov was pretty upset, but now he's finally come to terms with it. "We all make mistakes. We lose," he said. "Whats important is how we deal with our mistakes, with negative experience." Tap the link in our bio to read more about the battle between humans and AI that's playing out on chessboards. #chess

post70.caption: Grimes really wants to go to Mars but by the time it happens, she might just be a brain in a jar (or, more like a consciousness on a computer chip). In a recent interview, the singer and artist was asked: Would you rather for to Mars, or upload your consciousness to the cloud? And her answer is... a little bit of both. With a baby on the way and her new album released just today, she's got a lot on her plate but still claims that going to Mars is one of the "main things I'm trying to do." (Maybe love interest Elon Musk will help her get there.) Would you want to store your consciousness in order to live on after you die? What if it meant you could walk around on Mars? Let us know what you think in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more about Grimes' futuristic vision. #Grimes

post71.caption: Meet Greta Thunberg! (on left... Yes, we mean the snail!) While on an expedition in Bruneis Ulu Temburong National Park, a team of researchers and citizen scientists discovered a never-before-classified species of snail. After taking a vote, they decided to name it Craspedotropis gretathunbergae after teenage climate activist Greta Thunberg. The snail is incredibly sensitive to changes in weather and temperature, according to its discoverers. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about why they chose Greta as a namesake. #nature

post72.caption: Doctors just performed successful brain surgery on a woman while she played the violin which is, like, *exactly* the same plot as an episode of Grey's Anatomy. The brain is a delicate instrument, and any neurosurgery risks permanently altering a patients cognitive capabilities. So, when the doctors discovered the tumor was near the region of the brain responsible for controlling the violinists's left hand, they knew they'd have to be extremely careful not to damage her playing ability. This process, known as intraoperative brain mapping or simply awake brain surgery, is not a totally uncommon practice but that doesn't make it any less miraculous. Tap the link in our bio to see a video of the incredible (musical!) surgery. #brain

post73.caption: We cannot do it." Tesla's competitors are totally blown away by the auto giant's computer hardware and they just can't seem to catch up. Japanese business newspaper Nikkei Asian Review recently conducted a teardown of a Tesla Model 3, and the engineers were shocked at how advanced the electric car's onboard computer technology was. The current generation of Teslas Hardware 3 chips installed in the cars starting last year have enough computational power to enable Teslas to fully drive themselves, according to CEO Elon Musk himself. Tap the link in our bio to read more about why the others guys just can't seem to measure up to Tesla's hardware. #Tesla

post74.caption: Hold on It's not what you're thinking. Dr. Kevin Debiparshad is talking about leg extension surgery: a controversial elective procedure to permanently increase your height by a few inches. So how does it work? Here are the grisly details. (That was your content warning beware!) First, Debiparshad an orthopedic surgeon and founder of the LimbplastX Institute in Las Vegas cuts through patients femurs or tibias with a bone saw. Next, he forces the bones in your legs to separate with metal implants. After that, he sends you home to heal. Eventually, new bone cells will grow, reconnecting the pieces and effectively making each leg up to three inches longer. But don't sign yourself up just yet. Experts and bioethicists are arguing that cosmetic leg extension is indefensibly frivolous and shouldn't be performed unless patients have been psychologically evaluated and taught the risks and limitations of the procedure. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the concerns over the controversial surgery. #health

post75.caption: Want to protect yourself from germs, but still be able to unlock your phone with your face? This might be the product for you. No, but seriously. A startup is trying to cash in on the surge of people buying protective medical masks in attempts to defend against the COVID-19 coronavirus by developing a product that solves a very first world problem: phones that unlock with facial recognition. The bizarre-looking masks, printed with the smiling mug of the wearer underneath it, are the work of newly-launched design firm Resting Risk Face, which advertises its wares as trendy dystopian products. Oof! If you enjoy late stage capitalism, facial recognition respirator masks will retail for $40 per mask, reads the websites FAQ. They are still in development. But is this all just a brilliant commentary on modern society? Or a PR stunt for a new futuristic product? Tap the link in our bio to read more. #technology

post76.caption: There are 11 nasty space rocks that could level entire cities so how come NASA hadn't flagged them yet? A team of researchers at Leiden University in the Netherlands have developed a neural network called Hazardous Object Identifier that they say can predict if an asteroid is on a collision course with Earth. The AI found 11 asteroids that were not previously classified by NASA as hazardous, and which were larger than 100 meters in diameter big enough to explode with the force of hundreds of nuclear weapons if they impacted Earth. But luckily, none of the 11 are an imminent threat: not only are their chances of ever hitting Earth astronomically slim, but they are making their flyby between the years 2131 and 2923 hundreds of years from now. But with this technology, we'll be ready to discover them when they do. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #space

post77.caption: When we're all finally living on Mars, how will we communicate with those we've left behind on Earth? NASA has a pretty good idea: lasers. To lay the groundwork for the space agency's ambitious timeline to get to the Red Planet by the mid 2030s, NASA has begun building a huge dish in California which will be able to pick up on the Martian laser communications (Sidebar: Isn't it cool that we'll be able to call those future, off-world humans Martians?) Anyway, back to it. Using lasers to communicate will increased our "data rate from Mars by about 10 times what you get from radio, said Suzanne Dodd, the director of the CA program Tap the link in our bio to read more about how the dish will work. #Mars

post78.caption: A mysterious signal from deep space has been repeating every 16 days and this Harvard professor thinks it could have an alien origin. Earlier this month, Canadian researchers discovered a powerful radio signal emanating from a distant galaxy, but at a very specific pattern: arriving in bursts every 16 days. So, there are... many possible sources of these signals. But Avi Loeb, the chair of Harvard Universitys astronomy department, told Futurism this week that he thinks one possibility is that the signals are coming from an alien civilization. But Loeb also acknowledged that the signals (fast radio bursts, or FRBs) could be generated by young neutron stars called magnetars or by another, yet-undiscovered natural phenomenon. (like, maybe alien stuff!) Tap the link in our bio for more of Loeb's theories on the source of the strange signals. #space

post79.caption: 30 years ago today, Voyager 1 snapped this remarkable photo just before powering down its cameras forever. Whats so remarkable about it, you may ask? Zoom in on the bottom right. Spoiler: that little blip in the corner? That's Earth baby! As seen by Voyager 1 as it looked back on our solar system for the last time, the Earth appears so alone against the emptiness of space. This historic photo, popularly known as the Pale Blue Dot photo, really puts things into perspective, doesn't it? You can read more about the history behind this snapshot at the link in our bio. #futurism

post80.caption: Juuling: Not 4 Kidz! You may have been confused about that, considering the advertisements Juul allegedly marketed on gaming websites aimed at young children, and even more insidiously tot-friendly TV websites including Nickelodeon and Cartoon Network. In an aggressive new lawsuit, Massachusetts prosecutors are attempting to truly nail the company to the wall for what they say was a longstanding pattern of attempts by Juul to woo lucrative underage users. The suit claims Juul even schmoozed with teen-friendly celebs and influencers ranging from Miley Cyrus and Cara Delevingne, to Robert Pattinson and Kirsten Stewart (not RPatz & KStew!!!!) Tap the link in our bio to see the ads in question and decide for yourself. #juul

post81.caption: Think you have what it takes to be a NASA astronaut? Okay, prove it. NASA is officially accepting applications for astronauts to travel to the Moon as part of its Artemis mission maybe even as soon as 2024. Were celebrating our 20th year of continuous presence aboard the International Space Station in low-Earth orbit this year, and were on the verge of sending the first woman and next man to the Moon by 2024, NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine said in a statement. (That could be you he's talking about!) Tap the link in our bio to see what they're looking for in a perfect candidate. Get your rsums ready! You can send in your own application, if you think you have what it takes, between March 2 and 31. #space

post82.caption: Hey gamers: Researchers want your brain waves. You know, for... science-y reasons. A team of artificial intelligence researchers at the University at Buffalo want to study the brain waves and eye movements of around 25 people while they play a video game. And what will they do with that data? Use it to train advanced AI that could coordinate the actions of an entire fleet of autonomous military robots. Yea, seriously. We know that sounds like a big jump, from gaming to robo-soldiers, but tap the link in our bio for an explanation on the research which just received $316,000 from U.S. Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, better known as DARPA. #research

post83.caption: The situation for those quarantined in Wuhan has become even more worrisome: The Chinese government has instructed Wuhan authorities to round up the sick and put them in "mass quarantine camps," as the New York Times reports. Its an extreme, authoritarian move: rounding up and isolating thousands of residents in makeshift shelters and isolated hospitals that are being hastily assembled per the governments order. Sun Chunlan, who is leading the governments response to the 2019-nCoV epidemic, told officials to go door to door and test people. Set up a 24-hour duty system, Sun said, according to NYT. During these wartime conditions, there must be no deserters, or they will be nailed to the pillar of historical shame forever. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the implications this could have for the people quarantined in Wuhan. #Wuhan

post84.caption: If you could see your deceased loved one again, but it was only in a virtual world, would you do it? One woman in South Korea said yes, and got to "see" her seven-year-old daughter again, years after she had died from an incurable disease. In a special documentary called "I Met You," the mother, Jang Ji-sung, can be seen reaching out for her lost daughter's digitized self a heartbreaking moment illuminating the power of VR to deliver us experiences we could never have in real life. But what implications does this technology have for the future of mourning? Is this just another terrifying, Black-Mirror-esque tech or could this help support people through the grieving process? Tap the link in our bio to see the virtual reunion for yourself. #VR

post85.caption: Want to hitch a ride on a SpaceX rocket? Better start saving your coin now. SpaceX has officially launched an online booking tool that lets you reserve space on a Falcon 9 rocket for a cool $1 million dollars. But don't get too excited yet; that million won't get you a seat into space, but it will give companies the opportunity to send a few hundred pounds of payloads into space, like small satellites. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #SpaceX

post86.caption: She's back! But not before setting an incredible space record. NASAs Christine Koch spent a total of 328 days aboard the ISS making her the new record holder for longest-ever single spaceflight by a woman (her trip lasted 39 days longer than previous record holder Peggy Whitson). On Thursday, Koch parachuted safely back down to Earth with two other astronauts. As for what shell miss the most about her time in orbit, Koch said that would be her fellow astronauts and the fun of bouncing around in microgravity. But now that shes back on Earth? She's going to walk her dog on the beach, stick her toes in the sand, and take a long swim. Tap the link in our bio to watch the video of Koch being pulled out of the capsule and throwing a thumbs up to the waiting cameras. #space

post87.caption: Here's something that will really make your skin crawl: Researchers have grown "yarn" from human skin cells. (Yes, this is an image of someone "knitting" with skin. Lab made! But still...) Researchers at the French National Institute of Health and Medical Research in Bordeaux have grown yarn from human skin cells that they call a human textile and they say it could be used by surgeons to close wounds or assemble implantable skin grafts. Okay, you might have already scrolled away because this creeped you out, but this innovative new medical breakthrough could be a game changer for surgeons. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how they made the thread. #health

post88.caption: Do you want the good news or the bad news first? Here's both anyway: There's not a cure for coronavirus, but encouragingly, doctors have found other medicine to help treat patients with the virus. Doctors in Thailand have had some success treating coronavirus patients with a mixture of existing drugs more commonly used to treat HIV and influenza. The treatment rapidly improved multiple patients conditions. One 70-year-old woman tested positive for the coronavirus for ten days straight, but was cleared 48 hours after doctors tried the experimental treatment. If more medical teams confirm that the drugs help, health officials could have a valuable new weapon in their arsenal against the global 2019-nCoV outbreak. Again, it's not a cure, but it's something really positive which we could all use at the start of another week of coronavirus news. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #coronavirus

post89.caption: Today's the big day! It's Super Bowl Sunday and whether or not you have an opinion on who wins, this AI hive mind sure has an idea who will take the trophy at Super Bowl LIV. Unanimous A.I., a startup founded by Stanford computer scientist Louis Rosenberg, combines the opinions of a lot of humans with artificial intelligence to make remarkably accurate predictions and that included the likely winner of today's game. Tap the link in our bio to see which team the smart money is on. (We know one of you is just going to copy and paste the answer and put it in the comments which is totally fine. Go right ahead! We'll even like it.) Edit: Turns out the hive mind was right! #SuperBowl

post90.caption: Listen up: The World Health Organization has now formally declared that the global outbreak of the coronavirus is a public health emergency of international concern. Previously, WHO said the outbreak wasnt yet a global emergency but still considered it highly alarming. So far, the vast majority of confirmed cases and all confirmed fatalities occurred within mainland China. But since the virus has spread to so many countries around the world, WHO decided to reverse its previous decision. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what went into WHO's serious decision and how it might affect you. For an explainer on what we know about coronavirus so far, head to our IG profile and click on our "Coronavirus" highlight. #health

post91.caption: Wow, this blew up! Check out my SoundCloud! Elon Musk, probably. SpaceX and Tesla CEO Elon Musk just dropped his very own EDM song on SoundCloud. No, seriously. Were not making this up! Ok, but the laser edit on this image was added. (Sorry, we had to.) Musk dropped a link to the heavily auto-tuned track titled Dont Doubt ur Vibe on his Twitter late last night. And... you need to hear this. Tap the link in our bio to listen for yourself. But don't forget to come back after and comment your response to it. Is it a banger? Or a flop? #ElonMusk

post92.caption: Alright, take your best guess: What is this an image of? Maybe you think it looks like caramel popcorn, or a microscopic close up of some cell formations. But would you ever guess that this is what the surface of our very own Sun looks like? Yep, this caramely goodness is the most high resolution image of the Sun we've ever seen, thanks to the National Science Foundation's Inouye Solar Telescope in Hawaii (the largest telescope in the world!). Each of these individual cells is about the size of the state of Texas. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the scientific process that causes the patterns in the turbulent plasma. #science

post93.caption: Welcome to the space hotel! Rooms are spacious, and oxygen comes free of charge. (But intergalactic continental breakfast is not provided.) NASA announced Monday that its chosen private space station manufacturer Axiom Space to build the first commercial launch destination read: space hotel for the super wealthy and attach it to the International Space Station. The goal is to help grow an economy in low-Earth orbit, according to NASA. And what will a room with a really good view cost you? About $50 million dollars, according to Axiom CEO Mike Suffredini. Its a bargain! Suffredini added. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #space

post94.caption: Now this took some heart to do: Researchers in Japan have just successfully completed a first-of-its-kind heart transplant on a patient. Here's why it was so unique. Rather than replacing their patients entire heart with a new organ, researchers from Japans Osaka University placed degradable sheets containing heart muscle cells onto the hearts damaged areas and if the procedure has the desired effect, it could eventually eliminate the need for some entire heart transplants. I hope that [the transplant] will become a medical technology that will save as many people as possible, as Ive seen many lives that I couldnt save, researcher Yoshiki Sawa said at a news conference. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about how the process works. #health

post95.caption: Over the weekend, reports of the coronavirus extended to every inhabited continent of the Earth (that's excluding only Antarctica). Officials in Australia confirmed the continents first case of 2019-nCoV, the pneumonia-like virus that emerged from Wuhan, China last month and by Monday, Australia had confirmed five total cases. And more could soon be confirmed: There are also suspected but yet-unconfirmed coronavirus cases in both Brazil and the Republic of Cte dIvoire. If those are confirmed, that would mean the viral pandemic has now spread to 6 out of 7 continents, after making its way to the U.S. and France last week. But before you scroll on, some context: Though the number of confirmed cases has tripled to nearly 2,900, about 2,840 of these cases remain within the borders of mainland China. Every other country affected by 2019-nCoV has confirmed *fewer than ten cases* each. For more on the newest coronavirus reports, tap the link in our bio. #health

post96.caption: *sniff sniff* Um, something is smelling... really dank in this small town in Michigan. (Yeah, it's weed.) Bessemer, MI, is spending $3,400 on a bizarre-looking device called a Nasal Ranger in hopes that it will solve a growing problem: the stench of marijuana plants. The city of Bessemer stinks, city council member Linda Nelson said during a town meeting. You can smell marijuana everywhere. Weve got people who cant sit in their backyard because the smell from their neighbor is so bad. Tap the link in our bio to see how this bad boy works at sniffing out the strongest strains. #weed

post97.caption: Hey, I think I can see my future Martian house from here! Elon Musk says he'll put a million people on Mars by 2050. In a series of evening tweets, Musk revealed new details about his plans to colonize Mars: In theory, 1,000 Starships could eventually send maybe around 100k people per Earth-Mars orbital sync, Musk tweeted. Musk envisions these ships departing Earth orbit over a 30-day period, the window of time when Earth and Mars are best aligned to make the trip, every 26 months. And once humans arrive, there will be plenty to do. There will be a lot of jobs on Mars! Musk added. Tap the link in our bio to learn how many megatons of cargo will be needed to built a civilization like the one in this image. #ElonMusk

post98.caption: This Boeing satellite may be about to explode. Here's what's going on. DirecTV, the company that owns the Boeing-built satellite, has asked the FCC for permission to conduct emergency operations to move a satellite that may be about to blow up due to a battery malfunction. The company said that once sunlight is no longer available and the satellite can't use its solar charging, the satellite will have to resort to using its damaged batteries risking a catastrophic battery failure. An explosion in an already-busy orbit chock full of other satellites could spell disaster: a cascade of orbital shrapnel. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #Boeing

post99.caption: Scientists may have figured out where 2019-nCoV, the virus behind Chinas growing pandemic, came from and it may have started with snakes. The viral outbreak began at a seafood market in Wuhan, China that sold both butchered meat and live animals. A team of Peking University of China researchers suspects that the original culprit wasnt one of the fish arguing instead that an infected snake likely set the whole thing off. But despite the progress of new research, it's still too soon to know exactly where the virus originated. Each day at Futurism, we strive to report the newest updates on the mysterious virus, but the story is often updating, and news can change often. For our most up-to-date stories, tap the link in our bio to see an updating list of our newest reporting on the 2019-nCoV virus. #China

post100.caption: Scientists may have figured out where 2019-nCoV, the virus behind Chinas growing pandemic, came from and it may have started with snakes. The viral outbreak began at a seafood market in Wuhan, China that sold both butchered meat and live animals. A team of Peking University of China researchers suspects that the original culprit wasnt one of the fish arguing instead that an infected snake likely set the whole thing off. But despite the progress of new research, it's still too soon to know exactly where the virus originated. post101.caption: What if there aren't aliens piloting UFOs but actually time-traveling humans from the future? At least, that's what a new book from Michael Masters, a professor of biological anthropology at Montana Technological University, suggests. We know were here. We know humans exist. We know that weve had a long evolutionary history on this planet. And we know our technology is going to be more advanced in the future, he says. Masters isnt the first to float this idea. But in his new book, he attempts to support it by drawing on his expertise in anthropology. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #aliens

post102.caption: 20/20 vision is so yesterday. How about a contact lens with a computer in it? A startup called Mojo Vision unveiled a working prototype of what it claims to be the worlds first true smart contact lens" complete with a teensy tiny display screen that you can wear in your eye. The company says it could provide directions, sports scores, or even let you see in the dark. People cant tell you are wearing it, so we want the interaction to be subtle, done using just your eyes, said the startup's senior vice president of product and marketing Steve Sinclair. Tap the link in our bio to see more of the exciting eyeball innovation, like how many thousands of pixels they were able to pack into it. #tech

post103.caption: IT'S ALIVEEEEEEEE! No, but really, this concrete is like... sort of actually alive. Scientists at the University of Colorado, Boulder have created what The New York Times calls a living concrete, teeming with photosynthetic bacteria, that can grow itself and regenerate itself much like a living organism. The concrete is a mixture of gelatin, sand, and cyanobacteria that cools similarly to Jell-O (but don't eat it please!). The resulting biostructure can regenerate itself three times after being cut apart by researchers an incredible breakthrough in the young, but rapidly growing, field of self-assembling materials. Tap the link in our bio to read more. (Don't be scared! No Frankensteins inside.) #science futurism

post104.caption: Japanese billionaire Yusaku Maezawa wants to Starship and chill with a special someone on a trip around the Moon and he has about 20,000 applicants for the position. In September 2018, SpaceX announced that Maezawa would be a passenger on the companys commercial Starship rocket as it makes its way around the Moon and back some time in 2023, and it turns out he's looking for a special someone to keep him company on the voyage. Earlier this month, Japanese video streaming website AbemaTV announced its planning to follow Maezawa on his hunt to find a life partner, as part of a reality TV show called Full Moon Lovers, and over 20,000 women have applied. Tap the link in our bio to read more about his galactic search for love. #space

post105.caption: NASA wants to grow a Moon base out of mushrooms. Now that's some futuristic fungus. Scientists at NASA are exploring a peculiar strategy for building biological off-world structures that could be grown onsite out of living shroomies. If the research pans out, it would allow future astronauts to construct off-world settlements without needing to carry expensive, heavy building materials with them all the way from Earth a game-changer in the plan to colonize space. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how scientists might grown fungus in the foreign soils of space. #space

post106.caption: That selfie filter giving you dog ears isn't as innocuous as you might think. On Wednesday, the United States House Oversight and Reform Committee held a hearing on facial recognition technology. During it, Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez closed her remarks by comparing the tech to the dystopian sci-fi series "Black Mirror." AOC noted how mobile apps help bolster facial recognition systems by collecting data unbeknownst to users through seemingly innocuous filters. "I think its really important that everyone really understand whats happening," she said, "Because this is happening secretly, as well. Tap the link in our bio to watch the full video of her statement. #technology

post107.caption: Here's some explosive new research: The Earth's oceans are warming at the rate of five atomic bombs being dropped on the planet *per second*. Let's put that number into context. When the U.S. dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima, Japan, in 1945, that atom-bomb exploded with an energy of about 63,000,000,000,000 Joules. New research from an international team of scientists has found that the amount of heat we have put in the world's oceans in the past 25 years is equivalent to 3.6 billion (yes, billion) Hiroshima atom-bomb explosions. That's a staggering influx of heat 228 sextillion Joules worth. That number may seem unfathomable to you, but tap the link in our bio and we'll explain the study's math. #science

post108.caption: This is a photo of intense determination. Last weekend, a man named Adam Gorlitsky broke the world record time for completing a marathon while wearing an assistive robotic exoskeleton. Gorlitsky who is paralyzed from the waist down completed the Charleston Marathon after walking for 33 hours, 50 minutes, and 23 seconds straight (he didn't even stop to sleep). That put him just shy of a three-hour lead over the previous record-holder Simon Kindleysides Ive been attempting to break Simons record for about a year now, Gorlitsky said. And now that I have, the second I crossed that finish line, I have a whole new level of respect for him." Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #technology

post109.caption: It's raining laser beams! China wants to mount laser cannons onto its fighter jets. China is reportedly working on a laser attack platform that can be attached to its militarys aircraft, the South China Morning Post reports, and such an airborne laser weapon could be used to intercept missiles or even shoot down enemy aircraft at close range. China isnt alone in its efforts to mount lasers on planes; Both Russian and the United States have worked to develop similar tech as well. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #military

post110.caption: It's the other *other* white meat: Impossible Foods has finally revealed its plant-based take on pork. Impossible Pork can be steamed, baked in an oven, charbroiled, grilled on a flat-top or sauted, much like the real thing but without using animal products. But is it any good? Some who've tried it say that although the texture wasnt quite right, the taste was basically accurate, and it does look pretty similar to real ground pork. But how do you think the faux pork looks? Would you consider saying goodbye to real pork and trying it for yourself? Let us know in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more. #meat

post111.caption: Helen Sharman, the UK's first astronaut, gave an interview with The Observer detailing everything from her experience in space to her belief that extraterrestrial life definitely exists and it might already be here on Earth with us. Sharman doesnt claim to have seen any extraterrestrial life during her jaunts to space. Like many others, she believes that the universe is just too massive for Earth to reasonably be the only place where life exists. There are so many billions of stars out there in the universe that there must be all sorts of different forms of life, she says. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #aliens

post112.caption: Want to breathe clean air in the future? You're going to have to cough up some cash for it. A startup called Ao Air announced their $350 air purification mask designed to protect its wearer against air pollution, like city smog or smoke from wildfires. The expensive accessory circles the lower half of the face and provides fresh air for its wearer. Now, breathing clean oxygen can become the latest fashion trend! (That was sarcasm.) In other words, it could be seen as a blatant attempt to profit from the effects of climate change. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this worryingly futuristic gadget. #climatechange

post113.caption: What you're seeing here are the glorious remains of an exploded star. But this is just one perspective on it; Now, we've got a 3D image of the miraculous event. It took a village of brilliant people to bring us this visual: A team of astronomers from the Space Telescope Science Institute, Caltech and Harvard have combined data from three different NASA observatories the Chandra X-ray Observatory as well as the Hubble and Spitzer space telescopes to create the 3D visualization. Whew, that's a lot of smart people and strong telescopes. And what their work shows us is a 3D visualization of the Crab Nebula, the remains of a star that exploded in a supernova thousands of light years away. Tap the link in our bio to watch the stunning 3D video yourself. #NASA

post114.caption: Could an AI detect cancer even better than a human radiologist could? Google thinks so. A team of UK researchers at Google Health and Googles AI lab DeepMind has created a tool that can successfully identify breast cancer in X-ray mammograms. Its so successful, according to the paper published in the journal Nature this week, that it could one day rival or even outperform human radiologists. (Compared to human radiologists, the AI model flagged 9.4 percent fewer false negatives and 5.7 percent fewer false positives in the US dataset.) Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope about how this AI could reduce our dependence on human radiologists. #health : This image depicts a microscopic close up of breast cancer cells, colorized.

post115.caption: Sorry, no more mango Juul pods for the time being: The FDA has officially banned all flavored vape pods except tobacco and menthol. The FDA has been under pressure to tackle the epidemic of teens getting hooked on nicotine-containing products, and the department's answer is to get rid of fruit and mint flavored options. The news comes after the FDA officially raised the legal age to buy any tobacco products to 21 last week. But the department claims the move is unrelated to the recent outbreak of a mysterious vaping illness that over 50 people have died from as of late December. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #vaping

post116.caption: If a killer asteroid is headed straight to Earth, what can we do to survive? We could try to destroy it, sure or we could just get out of its way. An astrophysicist named Matthew Caplan has designed a "stellar engine" that could theoretically move Earths entire solar system from one part of the Milky Way to another. If it works, it could theoretically push the Sun from its current location to a new one at a speed of about 50 light years per one million years. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how this fascinating (and Earth-saving) invention would work. #astronomy : This image from NASA represents a solar flare on the Sun.

post117.caption: Astrophysicist Ron Mallett believes hes found a way to travel back in time theoretically, that is. The tenured University of Connecticut physics professor believes its possible to twist time into a loop that would allow for time travel into the past and hes even built a prototype showing how lasers might help achieve this goal. By studying the type of gravitational field that was produced by a ring laser, Mallett says, this could lead to a new way of looking at the possibility of a time machine based on a circulating beam of light. As optimistic as Mallet might be about his work, though, his peers are skeptical that hes on the path to a working time machine. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how his theory could work. #space

post118.caption: Gotta catch 'em all? Eh, maybe avoid the ones on military bases. CBC News has obtained hundreds of pages of documents detailing the Canadian militarys efforts to overcome an unexpected adversary: Pokmon Go. Within days of the games July 2016 launch, players reportedly began wandering onto military property in pursuit of its virtual creatures and landmarks and the unexpected intrusion left the military hilariously out of its depth. We should almost hire a 12-year-old to help us out with this, one security expert wrote in an email. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the invasion of the Pok-Snatchers. #Pokemon

post119.caption: Okay, what is going on with this mysterious swarm of drones flying over the U.S. at night? Officials are baffled: Fleets of up to 17 drones, each with an estimated wingspan of six feet, had been spotted flying over Colorados Phillips and Yuma counties at night for more than a week. Since then, the sightings have expanded to six counties in Colorado and Nebraska, with as many as 30 drones spotted in the sky at once and, ominously, no one seems to know who they belong to. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the mysterious swarm (and how Michael Crichton's book "Prey" is maybe, probably about to come true. Kidding... or are we?). #drones

post120.caption: China just quietly confirmed the birth of a third gene-edited baby but not without revealing that the researcher responsible for it has been sentenced to three years in prison. He Jiankui has been charged with illegally practicing medicine, which is not a particularly surprising update considering China condemned Hes controversial research almost immediately after he announced the births of the CRISPRed twin babies. Theyve crossed the bottom line of ethics in scientific research and medical ethics," read the court report. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #genetics

post121.caption: Hubble who? This giant folding space telescope could be the key to helping us find Earth 2.0. The Habitable Exoplanet Observatory HabEx for short would have a four-meter-wide mirror, compared to the Hubble Space Telescopes 2.4 meter one. The mirror will grant it greater ability to scan space for new exoplanets and distant Earthlike worlds and then better determine whether they can support life, or even future human settlements. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this amazing exoplanet hunter. #space

post122.caption: Russia just became the first nation on Earth to posses an operational hypersonic weapon a new class of nuclear weapon against which other militaries currently cannot defend themselves. The United States and Russia have been working on hypersonic weapons for years, and the news that either country has built one especially before figuring out how to defend against them is a particularly troubling sign for the future of warfare. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the speed and power of Russia's new weapon, the Avangard. #military

post123.caption: A scientist decided to do something drastic to change his life: he let surgeons drill holes in his skull and insert electrodes into his brain. The reason? To "cure" his severe alcoholism. World-renowned infectious disease specialist Frank Plummer once drank 20 ounces of whiskey every night before bed a habit that led to chronic liver failure and an organ transplant in 2014. But a new experimental addiction treatment gave him hope that he could give up the habit for good, but it would take a bunch of technology installed in his brain to do it. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about this experimental treatment on Neoscope. #brain

post124.caption: I'm looking through you all with the help of new ultrasound technology that can see into the human body from a distance. Scientists at MIT have developed a system of lasers that can probe inside the human body, much like an ultrasound but it can accurately take an image of whats going on inside a persons body from six centimeters away (that's a lot for a technology that usually needs direct contact). The system uses two lasers to work: one to generate sound waves that bounce around inside the patients body, and the second to detect them as they reflect back. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this fascinating new medical technology on Neoscope. #health

post125.caption: Did you know an eel can generate enough electricity to light your Christmas Tree? Well, now you do! The Tennessee Aquarium has found a shocking (lol) yet wholesome way to celebrate the holiday season: the aquariums electric eel, Miguel Wattson, can control the lights on his very own Christmas tree. The display isnt just jolly, either its also educational. (Yeah, you're going to learn something on Christmas, okay?) According to aquarist Kimberly Hurt, the duration of the trees illumination corresponds to Miguels current status. Little blips here and there? He's casually swimming around. More powerful flashes? He's excited or eating! (Disclaimer: Please don't go and try to find your own eel to save on electric.) And before you scroll on, Happy Holidays from all of us at Futurism. Tap the link in our bio to watch the video of this very jolly eel charging up a Christmas tree. #HappyHolidays

post126.caption: Put down the holiday treats, we have something even better: planets made like cotton candy. Scientists just revealed new information about a bizarre type of exoplanet so light that they have roughly the same density as cotton candy. (But no, it's not made of cotton candy. And yes, we know that the picture *does* show cotton candy floating through space... that's for dramatic effect!) Anyway, the ultra-light worlds have been nicknamed super-puffs by the scientists analyzing them, according to a European Space Agency press release, invoking their Kirby-esque fluffiness and new data from the Hubble Space Telescope suggests how they might have formed. Tap the link in our bio to learn more. #NASA

post127.caption: This eight-year-old earned $26 million in 2019 and he did it by unboxing and reviewing toys on YouTube. (You might want to set up the camera for your own holiday unwrapping!) Ryan Kaji, YouTube vlogger superstar, has been the top earner on the site for the second year in a row. But Kaji wasnt the only minor to make the cut this year, either. YouTubes third-highest earner is Anastasia Radzinskaya, a five-year-old Russian with cerebral palsy and seven YouTube channels. An additional five of YouTubes top earners arent kids, but they are gamers who often showcase content popular with youngsters, such as Minecraft and Fortnite. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the young YouTubers raking in cash for their videos. #YouTube

post128.caption: Russia desperately wants its own quantum computer. The Russian government just launched a new initiative to catch its quantum computing program up to those of other global powers, and over the next five years, Russia plans to pump about 50 billion roubles thats around $790 million into programs that, hopefully, will result in a functional quantum computer. While the investment shows that the government is serious about quantum tech, the program is also a bid to rebuild and revitalize Russias science programs. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #Russia

post129.caption: It's a bird... it's a plane.... it's......a dude in a crazy looking jetsuit! Jet wing pilot and daredevil Yves Rossy just shared a video of himself taking off and hovering over lake Geneva in Switzerland with his jet-powered wingsuit and it's a pretty incredible sight. Its a stunning display of the improved suits abilities it no longer needs its pilot to jump out of a plane or helicopter to get up to speed. With the aid of his especially engineered jetsuit, Rossy, who calls himself Jetman, can fly at speeds of more than 350 km/h (217 mph) at altitudes of up to 6,000 meters (almost 20,000 feet). Tap the link in our bio to see the video. #technology

post130.caption: You think weather is bad on Earth? Check out these crazy storms on Jupiter. Even putting its Great Red Spot aside for the moment, Jupiter is a bizarre place covered in gigantic, swirling storms. NASA recently discovered another storm this one the size of the United States on the planets south pole, joining an array of six others that were already swirling around in a beautiful hexagonal pattern. Tap the link in our bio to read more about NASA's new discovery. #space

post131.caption: Hey Santa, recalibrate your compass: Something really weird is happening with the North Pole. We know that Earths magnetic North Pole doesnt quite line up with the North Pole on a world map its wandered, at a glacial pace, about 1,400 miles since its first discovery in 1831. But what scientists didnt expect is that the magnetic North Pole has been wandering towards Siberia at an increasing pace it even crossed into a different time zone! Tap the link in our bio to read more about this strange phenomenon. #Earth

post132.caption: Here's some more not great news for you vapers out there (if you haven't heard enough warnings already): A first-of-its-kind health study has yielded bad news for e-cigarette users and even worse news for those who both vape and smoke conventional cigarettes. A team of researchers from the University of California, San Francisco tracked the tobacco use of more than 32,000 American adults from 2013 to 2016 noting any new lung disease diagnoses they received. And what they discovered? You're a third more likely to develop chronic lung disease if you vape. Worse so, they found that the vast majority of e-cigarette users don't fully give up smoking cigarettes and using both forms of tobacco more than triples a person's risk of developing lung disease. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the research. #vaping

post133.caption: We already know that our Milky Way is home to one black hole but now astrophysicists think good ol' reliable Sagittarius A* may actually have a companion black hole. Here's what we know: For nearly two decades, scientists have been monitoring the dense cluster of stars that orbit Sgr A* which can reveal a lot about the supermassive black hole itself. But now, UCLA astrophysicist Smadar Naoz and her colleagues believe there may be a second black hole nearby that is at least 100,000 times the mass of the Sun. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how they're going to test their theory. Edit: sorry if this gives you a headache to look at. . . #astrophysics

post134.caption: Russia is working on a plan to blow up any killer asteroids that are on a collision course with Earth. Russian space agency Roscosmos is creating a center devoted to monitoring meteors, comets, and asteroids to ensure they dont collide with Earth even it means having to blow them up in space. But before Russia can blast any dangerous asteroids out of the sky, itll need to do a lot of research. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the country's plan. #space

post135.caption: As it stands, world leaders are way off track to prevent the worst effects of global climate change. A new report published by the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) concludes that national governments and businesses need to take far more drastic action than they have been, especially when it comes to the conservation and preservation of natural environments. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how WWF says we can take action. #climate

post136.caption: It may be easy for you to tell which face in this picture is a real person and which is a duplicate, but for facial recognition software, that mask is as good as reality. Researchers at the AI firm Kneron were able to easily fool facial recognition systems at a variety of high security locations including banks, border crossing checkpoints, and airports using a high quality mask. This suggests that anybody with the capability to create such a mask could easily fool these systems as well a grave reality check for widespread facial recognition tech. Tap the link in our bio to read this story and more of our recent coverage on facial recognition. #technology

post137.caption: Well, we've had a good run! But now, this futurist says automation will lead to the end of the world as we know it for the average person. Here's the bad news: As jobs are automated out of existence, the division between the very wealthy and the very poor will grow and any notion of a comfortable middle class will vanish. This is all according to Roey Tzezana, a future studies researcher at Israels Tel Aviv University. But his prediction stands in contrast to the common argument that new jobs will emerge as others vanish, painting a grim picture for the workforce and global economy. As for the good news? Uh... there is none. But one prediction doesn't mean this terrible vision of society will come true. What do you all think about the future of the workforce? Will automation help workers become more efficient, or will it just replace us all together? Let us know in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more. #automation

post138.caption: Talk about getting high... SpaceX is rocketing some cannabis straight up into space. Agri-tech company Front Range Biosciences announced plans to send cannabis to the ISS but no, its not to get astronauts high. Instead, itll send plant cultures of hemp, the legal cannabis strain with low levels of compound THC. So, why are they sending some of that sticky icky into space? Tap the link in our bio to read more. #cannabis

post139.caption: After years of viewing horrific content for Facebook, former moderators are suing the social media giant for causing them psychological trauma. As moderators, their job was to watch child abuse, animal torture, and executions disturbing imagery that left their mental health in shambles, and lead many to be diagnosed with PTSD. There are 40,000 people doing this shit, said Chris Gray, one of 12 former content moderators listed as plaintiffs in the lawsuit. If I can get them better working conditions, better care, then that also improves the quality of the content moderation decisions and the impact on society. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the trauma experienced by social media moderators and how they're holding Facebook accountable. #socialmedia

post140.caption: Target: Autonomously acquired. Christoffer Heckman, a DARPA-funded computer scientist at the University of Colorado Boulder is calling for scientists to stop developing autonomous weapon technology. If we want to prevent the rise of autonomous weapons like killer robots that can pull the trigger without needing a humans approval then engineers will actually need to stop working towards them. Sounds easy, right? It may sound like an obvious solution, but sometimes it's hard for researchers to predict how their work might get used or abused in the future. In theory, a weapon that puts human soldiers out of harm's way could be a great idea. At its worst? We've built an autonomous death machine that could go haywire at any moment. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the future of military tech. #military

post141.caption: The key to discovering alien life could lie in the tiny hands of microbes that like to eat meteorites. A microbial descendant of some of Earths earliest life can survive, and seemingly thrive, on eating space rocks a finding that could help us detect signs of past life throughout the universe. Here's how that would work: Using an electron microscope, researchers are able to see which specific meteorite metals bacteria gobbled up the most, which could help trace biosignatures for the search of life elsewhere in the Universe. Tap the link in our bio to read more about these meteor-hungry microbes. #space

post142.caption: Is it possible to teach your brain how to focus? A new study from MIT may have found the answer. Researchers taught test subjects how to manipulate their own alpha brain waves, thereby improving attention at a given task. The key: give the participants live feedback of their brain activity. The team of scientists found that by suppressing alpha waves in one half of their parietal cortex the lobe responsible for touch, spatial sense, navigation, as well as attention subjects were better able to pay attention to objects on a screen. The only problem? None of the test subjects has any idea *how* they controlled their own brain waves. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #brain

post143.caption: What do you get when you cross a pig with a monkey? Well, you get a pig-monkey chimera and it could one day help scientists grow organs for transplants. This isn't just a hypothetical: The first ever piglets with cells from monkeys have been born in a Chinese lab after researchers grew a monkey cell culture, derived embryonic stem cells from it, and injected them into pig embryos four days after fertilization. The researchers final aim for the hybrid animal? To be able to grown human organs inside of them, which could revolutionize organ transplantation. But is it unethical? Let us know what you think in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #animals

post144.caption: This weekend, a bunch of super-strong mice are hitching a ride on SpaceX's Dragon spacecraft and getting sent out to space. You may be asking yourself, "What do muscular rodents need to go to space for in the first place?" You may also be asking yourself, "Do they look like the Hulk-ish rodent in this Instagram?" to which the answer is no. But! The mighty mice will help researchers study muscle loss in microgravity, which could eventually help ensure future astronauts stay healthy while in space. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the fascinating research plan. #animals

post145.caption: Bad news, stoners: Marijuana use seems to be linked to testicular cancer. A massive new study has linked frequent weed smoking to an increased risk of testicular cancer, but scientists say they'll need to conduct more specific research before they can definitively unravel the complicated health implications of marijuana. And to be fair, the kind of heavy use analyzed in the study is the equivalent of smoking a full joint every single day for a decade, so unless that sounds like you, odds are you dont need to panic. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #smoking

post146.caption: The medicine your doctor prescribes you shouldn't be decided based on a fancy dinner or free tickets to the game but that's just how Big Pharma drug salesmen swayed doctors to choose their products for patients. One doctor, Shahram Ahari, has decided to spill the beans on what he did as a pharmaceutical sales representative for a major drug manufacturer. He had one primary objective: to convince doctors they should write more prescriptions for the companys drugs at whatever cost, bribing them with expensive meals and gifts. Tap the link in our bio to read more about Big Pharma's role in the opioid epidemic. #health

post147.caption: Do you think AI could ever surpass the human ability to make art? Last week, indie pop singer-songwriter Grimes made an appearance on astrophysicist Sean Carrolls Mindscape podcast. During the segment, the pop singer, who studied neuroscience before pursuing her music career, opined that humanity is at the end of art, human art AI, in Grimes mind, will soon master the arts and sciences, surpassing humans in the ability to produce superior works. In a since-deleted tweet, critically acclaimed singer-songwriter Zola Jesus called Grimes comments the voice of silicon fascist privilege, likely alluding to Grimes relationship with Elon Musk. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #Grimes

post148.caption: If we only focus on moving to Planet B, like Mars, it's going to be the death of Planet A (the one we currently live on). There are many ambitious goals for the off-world future of humanity like Elon Musk's plan to build a city on Mars, and Jeff Bezos wanting orbital space colonies but these plans are misguided according to York University anthropologist Kathryn Denning. Denning said the idea of building a colony to which humanity could escape if the Earth becomes uninhabitable is not only an unrealistic idea, but a dangerous one as well. "How can we be enthusiastic about the human capacity to explore while maintaining our focus on what needs to happen here on this planet?" Denning said. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Futurism. #space : This image from NASA of the surface of Mars represents the ancient ocean that once covered the planet based on research from NASA's Goddard Space Flight center using isotopic measurements. The ocean once covered approximately 20 percent of the Red Planet, and represents a possible future for what Mars could look like if we're able to make the planet habitable for humans through terraforming.

post149.caption: When you sit down to eat Thanksgiving dinner today, there'll be another celebration about 408 kilometers, or 254 miles, above your head: a group of NASA astronauts aboard the space station are planning to have a Thanksgiving dinner of their own. The International Space Stations official Twitter account shared a video of the three NASA astronauts onboard talking about what Thanksgiving means to them and sharing their plans for the best meal of the year. When we think of Thanksgiving, we think of friends, family, and food, astronaut Andrew Morgan said in the video. Tap the link in our bio to watch the video and see what's on their menu. (Hint: it's a lot of food from pouches!) #thanksgiving

post150.caption: Welcome to the Mootrix. In a bid to get more and better milk out of their cows, Russian farmers have taken to strapping specially-modified virtual reality headsets on their cows heads and giving them relaxing, pleasant virtual experiences. Its not clear whether the milk improved as a result, but the cows seemed happier while looking at a VR field than they were while faced with the grim reality that they were trapped in a crowded farm. And if that doesnt work, maybe the farmers could try letting the cows roam around an actual field. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on The Byte. #farming

post151.caption: CENSORSHIP ALARMS ACTIVATED Instagram keeps deleting the accounts of sex workers and porn stars for seemingly no reason even when their content meets the site's guidelines and restrictions. The people reporting us dont understand that peoples incomes are affected, or they dont care, said Ginger Banks, an adult performer and sex workers rights activist. They think that we shouldnt be doing this job or it shouldnt exist. Tap the link in our bio to read more about why Instagram is discriminating against, and censoring, sex workers. #instagram

post152.caption: You can't just CTRL+Z life to undo your mistakes. Or can you? Ohio University deleted a press release that supposedly provided evidence of life on Mars. But then the news just... disappeared. Entomologist William Romoser from Ohio University claimed last week to have spotted evidence of insect-like creatures living on the surface of Mars, pointing to blurry photographs as evidence. There has been and still is life on Mars, Romoser said in a press release about his presentation. But after broad backlash, the press release has since been disappeared from Ohio Universitys site. OU... where'd it go? Tap the link in our bio to read more about the science community's response to the controversial research. #Mars

post153.caption: A new wave of shady startups are asking for your money and your DNA. The companies claim to deliver insights ranging from personalized diets and wine pairings, to personality traits and mental health diagnoses. But experts told our reporter that the results can't trusted. At least, not until science is able to catch up to what these scammy companies are claiming to offer. If you could learn anything about yourself from your DNA, what would you want to know? And how much would you be willing to pay to find out? Let us know in the comments, and tap the link in our bio to read more. #health

post154.caption: For some people, male contraceptives can be a hard pill to swallow but luckily, this one's just a shot. Women have a number of options for contraception, from pills to implants to injections. But aside from condoms, men have just one: sterilization, which isnt always ideal given that it involves surgery and can be difficult to reverse. That could soon change, though, as researchers in India have completed testing on a male birth control injection and the only thing now standing in its way is regulatory approval. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #health

post155.caption: Tesla CEO Elon Musk finally revealed the companys long-awaited Cybertruck" and its, uh, a conversation starter. The outrageous Blade Runner-style pickup truck, starting at a price of $39,900, is a pretty killer deal. But some are having a visceral reaction to its brutalist design. "Seriously it's like a Delorean mated with a Pontiac Aztek," said Twitter user Tom Giles. The absolute unit of a truck is meant to be armored and fully bulletproof, but during Musk's big reveal, something went... a bit wrong, and the "impenetrable" truck's window shattered. But Musk is undeterred! He tweeted Friday that a future iteration of the electric pickup may even have solar panels to keep you going before the next recharge. There's a lot to learn about the new Tesla release, and we're keeping up with the latest news on Futurism. Tap the link in our bio to read all of our cybertruck coverage. #Tesla

post156.caption: Do you know what's at the edge of our solar system? Take your guess, then click to learn the answer... It turns out, at the outermost edges of our solar system lies a barrier of super-hot plasma a giant wall of fire from the Sun that defines the edge of interstellar space. So just how hot is it? As Voyager 2 began its journey into interstellar space in late 2018, it recorded temperatures as high as 49,427 degrees Celsius (89,000 degrees Fahrenheit). While the space probe seemed to come out unscathed, this scorching plasma shield around our solar system could pose quite a problem for NASA as it plans more missions into interstellar space. Tap the link in our bio to read more, and scroll down to learn more about this image in the comment below. #NASA

post157.caption: It's like a horoscope reading for your health and just as untrustworthy. A wave of startups are claiming to find a wealth of data in your DNA tests ranging from ludicrously specific personality traits like "social communication problems" and "loneliness" to medical conditions like allergies. The problem? Experts say it's a complete scam. Make no mistake: DNA tests and genomic assessments can provide doctors with valuable information about patients health. But thousands of people turn over their genetic data to private companies every day, and they could make significant health decisions based on the results. In the case of some startups, DNA tests are blurring the line between entertainment and medicine with potentially dangerous consequences. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the scammy startups of DNA testing. #health

post158.caption: The Earth is singing an eerie song and it's all thanks to the Sun. (Don't worry... this is scientific.) During a solar storm, the Sun releases electrically charged particles, which bombard the Earth with energy temporarily distorting the shape of the Earths magnetic field. A team of scientists from the University of Helsinki used data collected by the European Space Agency to map out the strange song that the shockwaves from this event create and you can hear it for yourself. Tap the link in our bio to "listen" to the otherworldly music the Earth creates. #Earth

post159.caption: An engineer has found a creative way to filter unwanted cells from blood: magnets. The technology works similarly to dialysis: first, it removes a patients blood and then infuses it with magnetic nanoparticles designed to bind to a specific disease. The magnets are then able to draw the "bad blood" out before pumping the good blood back into the patient. In theory, you can go after almost anything, engineer George Frodsham said. Poisons, pathogens, viruses, bacteria, anything that we can specifically bind to we can remove." Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #health

post160.caption: Even winning the Nobel Prize doesn't guarantee that you have all the answers. (But it does give you some perspective.) Nobel-winning cosmologist James Peebles has a bone to pick with the scientific community: he wants the world to stop referring to the earliest moments of our universe as the Big Bang. His main qualm? We simply don't have a good way to test whether such a thing actually happened. But not everyone agrees with him. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #science

post161.caption: The U.S. military is really interested in bacteria. But not just any bacteria this is bomb-sniffing bacteria. Okay, it can't really... sniff... but it does help identify where a bomb may be hidden. Detecting underground explosives is difficult because, well, you cant see them buried underground. But by genetically engineering bacteria to "glow" when it detects a bomb, the military hopes it will help save the lives of the soldiers, dogs and even robots that were tasked with the dangerous job beforehand. And DARPA is funding the research. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how it works. #military

post162.caption: Fig. 1A: This is a brain on Neuralink. Elon Musk, CEO of the mysterious neurotech startup, made an appearance on a podcast where he claimed the companys brain-computer interface technology would be able to solve neurological diseases. In the past, Musk has promised the tech would be able to eliminate serious conditions like Alzheimers disease and schizophrenia, but now hes added a bizarre new example to the list: autism spectrum disorder. But there's a big problem with Musk's pronouncement: autism is considered a developmental disorder, not a brain disease that can, or necessarily should, be cured. Listing it as a disease to be solved as Musk did risks further stigmatizing a community pushing for better treatment and representation. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #ElonMusk . . : Pictured is a schematic of the sewing machine method for inserting electrodes into a rodents brain.

post163.caption: Five million years ago, a supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way yeeted away one poor, unfortunate star at millions of miles per hour. The star, recently spotted by Carnegie Mellon University astronomers, is on its way out of the galaxy at 3.7 million miles per hour a speed so high that it will never return. "It is a visitor from a strange land," one of the researchers said. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about why the star suffered such a disastrous fate.
