R.I.P. little buddy. #NASA : This image is an artist's concept from NASA depicting the shifting corona of a supermassive black hole, and includes a color filter. It is not a photograph of the black hole or star mentioned above.

post164.caption: It was love at first sight err, we mean, love at first AI-generated message. Redditor u/levonbinsh wrote a post explaining their adoration for OpenAI's GPT-2 text generator, claiming the AI makes them feel like someone whom is cared about. Weve seen examples of people falling in love with AIs before, in both fiction like the movie "Her" and reality. In a world where human connection is increasingly occurring over the internet, it's understandable that speaking with a human-like neural network could help stem the tides of loneliness. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how love can be found in the most hopeless, or humanless, of places. #AI

post165.caption: Finally. The U.S. government is pretty sure its learned what's behind the mysterious "vape lung epidemic" that's spread across the country. A compound called vitamin E acetate has been found in all 29 lung fluid samples taken by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (They first identified it as a possible cause back in September.) While this is a big step in helping us understand what may be causing these injuries, these findings do not rule out the potential for other compounds or ingredients as contributing factors, said public health expert Scott Becker. There may be more than one cause of the outbreak. So, why is vitamin E acetate so dangerous in vapes? Tap the link in our bio to read more. #vaping

post166.caption: Elon Musk really wants to build a sustainable city on Mars but he's going to need 20 years and 1,000 Starships to do it. In true Musk fashion, the CEO has set himself an aggressive timeline to start making trips to the Red Planet, with the goal of sending astronauts by 2024. Musk said he would load up Starships with 100s of tons of supplies, and ship them back and forth to the Red Planet year after year like an assembly line ferrying 10 million tons of payload to orbit per year. But is Musk's exciting and ambitious plan even plausible? Will he get astronauts to Mars by 2024? Tap the link in our bio to read more. #ElonMusk

post167.caption: Want to live on Mars? Let's mess with your DNA, first. The radiation in space is way too dangerous for humans to handle, so scientists think they've found a creative way to help us protect our measly human bodies from the dangerous cosmic rays. Weill Cornell University geneticist Chris Mason wants to gene-hack humans with the DNA from tardigrades that enables the weird little creatures to survive harsh radiation. Tap the link in our bio to read how it would work. #Mars

post168.caption: More than 11,000 scientists from 153 nations just declared a global climate emergency and we should probably listen to them. The authors' claims are supported by decades worth of hard data and scientific analysis, and they propose swift and concrete actions for humanity to take to preserve our planet. The climate crisis has arrived and is accelerating faster than most scientists expected, the authors wrote. It is more severe than anticipated, threatening natural ecosystems and the fate of humanity. Tap the link in our bio to read more from their statement. #climatecrisis

post169.caption: Have you ever heard of astronomy's "three-body problem"? Let's give you a quick lesson. When three celestial bodies for instance the Earth, Moon, and Sun orbit each other, their gravitational pulls produce a peculiar, and seemingly unpredictable, system. And figuring out how to predict where each celestial body will be in space and time at any given point is a problem that's been stumping astronomers for like... 300 years. (We have Sir Isaac Newton to thank for formulating the theory in the first place.) But now that we have a beautiful invention called a neural network, researchers claim they can solve the three-body problem faster than ever before. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #science

post170.caption: Have you ever wondered what would happen if our planet collided with a black hole? If you listen to the movies, you might think everything sucked into a black hole will turn into an impossibly flat pancake, or maybe it would release a massive, blinding explosion. But one physicist have been working on calculating what would *actually* happen, in reality. (You know, just so we can be prepared.) A new online tool called the Black Hole Collision Calculator, developed by particle physicist lvaro Dez, will quantify just how destructive the cosmic collision of Earth v. Black Hole would be. Tap the link in our bio to play around with inventing your own apocalypse. #space

post171.caption: When life gives you s, make pink lemonade. Deutsche Telekom, T-Mobile's parent company, is suing a New York-based insurance provider called Lemonade. The offense? @lemonade_inc dared to use the pinkish color magenta in its ads in Germany, and Deutsche Telekom says it owns the legal rights to the shade. Lemonade tried to capitalize on the bizarre lawsuit with a social media movement but so far results seem mixed. The suit is becoming a fantastic spectacle, but also illustrates the extent to which megacorporations can use the legal system to snuff out perceived threats, regardless how frivolous and has striking similarities to the legal conflicts between vantablack, licensed to artist Anish Kapor and the pinkest pink developed by artist Stuart Semple. #futurism

post172.caption: The univ The univ The univ Oops, sorry the universe is skipping hold on a second. There, that's better. The universe may actually be a loop like walking off the edge of an old video game just to pop back up again on the other side, or like the audio tape in a cassette player. That question of whether the universe is open, continuing on infinitely, or closed like a loop is causing a possible crisis for cosmology, according to a new paper published in the journal Nature Astronomy. Tap the link in our bio to read more about one of the oldest debates in the history of astrophysics. #space

post173.caption: *wink wink* This realistic robot is actually a clone of a real human (or, at least it looks like one). A Russian startup called Promobot is selling autonomous androids made to look like any person on Earth. Like, literally anyone you want: "Imagine a replica of Michael Jordan selling basketball uniforms and William Shakespeare reading his own texts in a museum," the startup's press release reads. It's a futuristic immortality, or very uncanny taxidermy. Would you want to "live forever" as an android clone of yourself? Let us know in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more. #robot

post174.caption: MORE BLACK HOLE NEWS INCOMING! A team of astronomers from Ohio State University claims to have discovered an entirely new and previously missing class of black holes and they're super tiny. At least... relatively tiny. One they found was only about 3.3 times the mass of the Sun, but usually they're at least five times the Suns mass (or much, much larger). If this discovery is confirmed, current theories would have to take into account an entirely new class of black hole forcing us to rethink how we understand the way stars and other kinds of celestial objects are born and die. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Futurism. #blackholes

post175.caption: NASA is planning a two week staycation on the Moon for four lucky astronauts. But before we get to that: NASA just shared fascinating new details about the agencys upcoming planned Moon mission. Two astronauts will post up on the Moons surface for 6.5 days twice as long as any NASA astronauts before them and take water samples and observe the lunar surface. But, not to be outdone.... by itself.... NASA is already looking beyond that to a future crewed mission to the Moon, with plans to send a team of four astronauts to the lunar surface for 14-day-long missions before 2030. Tap the link in our bio to read this story and more of our recent NASA coverage. #NASA

post176.caption: Double check the expiration dates on your mint JUUL pods. According to a lawsuit filed by former a JUUL executive, the vape manufacturer knowingly shipped more than a million contaminated pods and then he was fired for questioning the decision. Siddharth Breja, JUULs former senior vice president of global finance, alleges that 250,000 contaminated mint-flavored refill kits went out to retailers. And he says that wasn't the first time JUUL looked the other way on corrupted products. Breja also voiced his concerns over selling pods that were over a year old a valid worry, which Burns brusquely shoos away in this quote from the court documents. Tap the link in our bio to read more, and click the link in the first sentence to view the lawsuit in full. #JUUL

post177.caption: Space can be spooky sometimes just check out this ghoulish galaxy spotted by the Hubble Space Telescope. The two glowing ghastly "eyes" you see are actually the cores of two colliding galaxies. "The universe is a bubbling cauldron of matter and energy that have mixed together over billions of years to create a witches' brew of birth and destruction," said NASA's surprisingly poetic press release. Galaxy collisions are relatively common, but usually, they aren't a "head-on smashup," as NASA called it, like this one is. (Note: we added that orange tint, but the original image is just as spooky.) Tap the link in our bio to see more, and let us know in the comments what you'll be dressing up as for Halloween! #HappyHalloween

post178.caption: By the year 2069, what advancements do you imagine we'll make in the realm of artificial intelligence? In honor of the 50-year-anniversary of the first computer-to-computer message the precursor, arguably, to todays internet Pew Research Center and Elon University asked hundreds of tech experts to imagine how the internet might evolve over the next 50 years. And one of those experts envisions a future in which software has gained personhood. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the future of software with a "personality." Let us know in the comments what your predictions are for 2069. #artificialintelligence

post179.caption: *shudder* It seems that cherry picking your very own super-smart designer baby won't work, according to a new study from the American Society of Human Genetics. Determining a baby's smarts before they're born is seemingly still impossible. Today, having fertilized embryos undergo genetic testing prior to implantation is a fairly common option for people using in-vitro fertilization, and allows them to ensure a viable pregnancy without complications. But in November, a company called Genomic Prediction claimed to have developed a method for "scanning" embryos for their intelligence through genetic testing and assigning them a "polygenic score." If it was accurate, it would allow parents to pick and chose only the embryos with super smart "scores" but it turns out the accuracy of the tech may have been debunked. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #genetics

post180.caption: They finally did it; after weeks of speculation, Google is claiming to have achieved quantum supremacy. It's an incredible accomplishment, but some of you may be wondering: Why should I care? And what is quantum supremacy in the first place? Lets take a couple steps back. In a recent paper, a team of Google AI scientists claimed their quantum computer called Sycamore was capable of completing a task involving the verification of the randomness of large numbers in just three minutes and twenty seconds. The most powerful supercomputer in the world, they said, would need 10,000 years to accomplish the same task. Tap the link in our bio to continue reading about why quantum supremacy matters on Futurism. #Google

post181.caption: This is Hygiea, an object in the asteroid belt that just got a major promotion. Turns out, scientists think the asteroid deserves reclassification as a dwarf planet making it the smallest one yet identified in the entire solar system. To be classified as a dwarf planet, an object must meet four requirements: it must be spherical, it must orbit the Sun, it cant be a moon and it must not have cleared the neighborhood around itself, which would make it a proper planet. So how does Hygiea measure up? Tap the link in our bio to read more on The Byte. #space

post182.caption: What's the strangest type of meat you've ever tried? Maybe you're a foodie with an exotic palate, or maybe you're a vegetarian who skips meat altogether. Either way, you can look forward to a future where a smorgasbord of fake meat offerings will allow you to try a bite of chicken, beef, even elephant or giraffe all grown ethically from stem cells in a lab. No killing of animals required. What strange meat would you want to try first? Let us know in the comments, and tap the link in our bio to read more about the startups working on exotic fake meat substitutes. #fakemeat

post183.caption: Two star-crossed lovers, 300 light-years away from Earth, violently collided and totally obliterated each other. Two exoplanets recently crashed into each other, leaving a trail of dust and debris in their wake. The universe is a violent place, and space stuff collides with other space stuff pretty frequently. These shattered exoplanets give astronomers a rare glimpse into what happens when already-formed worlds collide. But something about the shrapnel they left behind surprised scientists. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on The Byte. #astronomy

post184.caption: Scientists may have finally come up with a way to detect traversable wormholes that is, assuming they exist. Theres never been conclusive evidence that traversable wormholes portals between two distant parts of the universe, or two universes within a theoretical multiverse are real. But if they are, a team of scientists think they know what that evidence might look like, breathing new life into a far-out theory that could finally achieve faster-than-light travel. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on The Byte. #science

post185.caption: For sale: human organs, lightly worn. People in dire need of cash have found an unusual way to make ends meet: putting their own kidneys up for sale on Facebook and law enforcement agencies are struggling to keep up with it. Often, it seems, people are selling their kidneys to try and scrape together enough money for hospital bills or for other unexpected expenses. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this murky online marketplace. #health

post186.caption: What does this beautiful blob look like to you? Maybe you think it resembles cotton candy, or the colorful swirls of an exploding bath bomb... or maybe you're really smart and you immediately knew this is the cosmic explosion named Tychos Supernova. This supernova has long been a source of disagreement among astronomers trying to explain its bizarre clumps and fluffy appearance, but with new x-ray data and simulations, NASA may have finally settled the debate. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #space

post187.caption: Life is tough but life as a sentient bodyless brain might be tougher. Some neuroscientists working with lab-grown human mini brains worry the brains could be experiencing an endless horror: a conscious existence with no body. Mini brains give scientists the opportunity to study neurological development and conditions in something more human-like than an animal model but is it crossing an ethical line if the brain could be suffering? Let us know what you think in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more on The Byte. #brain

post188.caption: This star has been annoying the s#&t out of astrophysicists for decades. Here's why. According to multiple observations and studies, the star HD 140283 appears to be older than the universe itself. Which is, like, completely impossible. But still, scientists date the star to be about 14.27 billion years old (best estimates say the universe itself has only been around for about 13.8 billion years, but that number is still up for debate as well). So what's the explanation? Tap the link in our bio to learn more about this frustrating mystery. #astronomy

post189.caption: Russian biologist Denis Rebrikov is one step closer to creating CRISPR babies. The journal Nature reported that Rebrikov claimed in an email that he had already used the gene-editing tech to tinker with the genetic code of donated humans eggs a critical piece of his plan to edit human embryos to prevent children from inheriting their parents deafness. But some would argue that the controversial technology shouldn't be used to "delete" deafness, as millions of people who are deaf can live happy, healthy lives without the risk of gene editing. Tap the link in our bio to read more about CRISPR. #CRISPR

post190.caption: Sometimes, you just need to get a new perspective. On Tuesday, a six-year-old boy named Ethan disappeared in Minnesota, prompting more than 600 people to form a search party. Numerous law enforcement agencies and even a state patrol helicopter contributed to the search but it was a heat-seeking drone operated by a local photographer that led to the boys rescue, 10 hours after he went missing. Tap the link in our bio to read where they found him. #drones

post191.caption: Get your reusable tote bags ready to shop at a Martian farmer's market because it might not be too far in our future. It turns out Martian and Moon soil is surprisingly fertile, and new research suggests it may someday be possible to harvest crops grown at off-world colonies. Wageningen University scientists tried to grow ten different crops in soils developed by NASA to mimic that found on Mars and the Moon, nine of them grew edible parts and viable seeds. Tap the link in our bio to find out what a Martian diet might look like. #Mars

post192.caption: Scientists want to grow babies inside of giant, liquid-filled balloons and it could totally revolutionize prenatal healthcare. Premature birth is a leading cause of death among newborns, but a device that dramatically improves premies chances of surviving may be just five years away. Designers Lisa Mandemaker and Hendrik-Jan Grievink teamed up with medical researcher Guid Oei to design a device that closely mimics the conditions found in the biological womb and it could lead to safer pregnancies and childbirths for mothers and babies alike. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #health

post193.caption: Posting a photo to social media could have cost this woman her life. It sounds like a horror story your parents might tell you to warn you about the dangers of posting your photo on the internet: Last month, Japanese pop star Ena Matsuoka was attacked outside her home by an obsessed stalker who found her by analyzing the reflection in her eye in a selfie. He studied the bus stop and trees outside her windows, even noting the angle at which sunlight hit her eye, and compared it to Google Maps. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on the Byte. #cybersecurity

post194.caption: Are we finally close to inventing a compact nuclear fusion reactor? Salvatore Cezar Pais, U.S. navy researcher and engineer, was granted a patent for a compact nuclear fusion reactor capable of generating anywhere from 1 billion to 1 trillion watts and it's so small it could allegedly fit inside a vehicle. Thats far more powerful than any of Americas operational nuclear power plants, but there's a catch: its not clear how much, if any, of the patent represents feasible tech. Here's another catch: Pais has a quasi-facetious reputation for working on UFO-like technology. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #nuclearpower

post195.caption: Welcome to a world where every single day, the Earth is under fire from a constant barrage of catastrophic asteroid hellfire. At least, according to this tabloid it is. We've found the absolute worst science journalism on the planet (and no, internet trolls in our comments, it's not Futurism.) The British tabloid The Daily Express publishes an average of three stories a day warning, or heavily implying, that a deadly space rock is about to annihilate civilization. But don't take them at their word none of the space rocks came anywhere close to actually hitting us. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the hundreds of potential "apocalypses" we've just barely avoided! #science

post196.caption: A 17-year-old teenager in the U.S. has died from the mysterious vaping illness the youngest to die from vaping nationwide. Despite the growing number of severe pulmonary illnesses related to vaping, scientists, doctors, parents, and government officials are still scrambling to pinpoint what about vaping is causing such severe damage to the human body. Here's what we know so far: - The damage vaping causes to the lungs resembles a toxic poison or a chemical burn, according to doctors from the Mayo Clinic. Some vapes were even found to contain cyanide. - Black market cartridges can be very dangerous to vapers, but it's not just unregulated THC that's causing "vape lung." A study published Monday found that vaping nicotine caused lung cancer in mice a worrying look at the future health impact nicotine vapers will face, and an argument for more research on humans. There are still gaps in our understanding of how a life of vaping will impact on the human body. At Futurism, our coverage is ongoing as we continue to report on the newest updates on vaping illnesses. To stay up to date, tap the link in our bio to read our recent coverage on vaping. #vaping

post197.caption: Weve spent decades and billions of dollars to answer one simple question: is there life on Mars? But according to former NASA scientist Gilbert Levin, we may already have found evidence of Martian life in 1976 during NASA's Viking mission. The smoking gun, according to Levin: the mission detected positive results during the Labeled Release life detection experiment, which he spearheaded. Tap the link in our bio to read more about how they came to this conclusion by testing the Martian soil. #Mars

post198.caption: It seems every day there's a new deepfake of a celeb pasted into a movie they never starred in but it turns out, these fun face swaps make up a small percentage of all deepfakes. The most popular targets for new deepfakes? Porn stars. According to the report, 96 percent of manipulated videos out there are placing celebrities, actresses, and musicians into porn. But this isn't just a harmless hack. The incredibly realistic videos violate the privacy of their faux subjects and unsurprisingly, the pornographic deepfakes analyzed in the study targeted only women. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #deepfakes

post199.caption: Should we gene-hack animals to make them smarter? This is a question scientists are asking themselves as technology like CRISPR continues to push the boundaries of biological ethics including the potential to hack new traits into animals that could enhance their intelligence. In March, scientists altered monkey brains to be more humanlike, seeing an immediate boost in the animals memory and cognitive skills. While doing so is still impossible, the developments raise the question of whether humanity could someday, far in the future, make animals as smart as humans. Let us know what you think in the comments, and tap the link in our bio to read more. #animals

post200.caption: Lift up foot, insert into mouth. Elon Musk regretted calling Vernon Unsworth a child rapist in an email to BuzzFeed, a court document filed by the British diver reveals, when Musk thought he was "off the record." (Pro tip: you can only say something is "off the record" if you've already agreed on those terms with the other party beforehand.) And in case you need a refresher: Musk suggested sending a mini-sub to rescue a group of boys from a flooded cave in Thailand in 2018. Unsworth said it was likely a PR stunt. Musk shot back and called him a pedo guy and a child rapist. This prompted Unsworth to sue Musk for defamation. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the case on The Byte. #ElonMusk

post201.caption: That's one hungry black hole and it's ready to feast on some stars. Scientists running the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) just announced plans to capture real-time video footage of Sagittarius A*, the supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way, gobbling up stars and planets. The EHT first captured that groundbreaking image of a black hole back in April. But now the team is getting more ambitious, and plans to capture actual video of a black hole. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on The Byte. #EHT

post202.caption: Put down the Juul while you read this one: the mysterious vaping illness is causing injuries similar to those caused by mustard gas and other poisons. A team of researchers from the Mayo Clinic analyzed samples of lung tissue taken from 17 vape lung sufferers and all 17 cases showed a pattern of injury in the lung that looked like a toxic chemical exposure or a chemical burn injury. Officials still arent sure whats causing vape lung, but theories range from the oils in vaping cartridges to fumes from the vaping devices themselves THC and tobacco vapes alike. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #vaping

post203.caption: If you give a bunch of people free money, what do you think they'll spend it on? Maybe you assume they'd blow it all on frivolous shopping purchases and luxurious steak and lobster dinners. At least, that's what critics of a universal basic income (UBI) argue. But it turns out, if you give people a monthly stipend, they'll use it on groceries, utility bills, and the "necessities" according to data from a test program of UBI in California. For 18 months, 125 people in Stockton, CA, received $500 a month to spend on anything they wanted and most used it to cover the expenses of their home and families. No lobster dinners to be found. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Futurism. #universalbasicincome

post204.caption: Let's all be upfront with ourselves: there's a lot humans still don't understand about the universe we live in. And one of the biggest, ahem, gaps in our knowledge revolves around black holes. New research from a pair of University of Hawaii scientists argues that some of the black holes floating around our universe might actually be blobs of dark energy that mysterious theoretical force thought to be pushing the universes outward expansion. If their work holds up, it could completely rewrite our understanding of the cosmos. Tap the link in our bio to read more on The Byte. #astronomy

post205.caption: Ashes to ashes, and from dust to... Facebook Live? This doctor had an oddball idea: start broadcasting human autopsies on livestream for grieving families and medical students alike to watch. Dr. Ben Margolis offers clients usually family members of the deceased who want answers or closure the distinctly 21-century option to have their loved ones autopsies recorded or broadcast live on Autopsy.Online, Margolis' streaming website. And many are taking him up on the offer. Would you opt for a live autopsy for a family member or even yourself? Tap the link in our bio to read more. #medicine

post206.caption: It's a bird! It's a plane! It's... an alien spy probe? A physicist whos on the hunt for extraterrestrial life says theres a chance that an ancient alien civilization has been spying on Earth for millions of years. James Benford, a physicist and independent SETI researcher, isn't suggesting they walk among us, but that an advanced civilization could have traveled close enough to launch an expedition into our solar system. We know there are a lot if "what ifs" and "maybes" to what he's proposing. But Benford's research suggests that while a surprise visit from some extraterrestrials is extremely unlikely it's possible that some alien tech was left behind on another rock co-orbiting our Sun, waiting to be uncovered by some humans from Earth. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on The Byte. #space

post207.caption: So, there's a lot going on with black holes lately. First, NASA released a stunning simulation of how a black hole distorts its appearance by skewing the matter around it. Next, astronomers discovered that a black hole or even a number of them could be orbiting our Sun right now, way beyond Neptune. And now, a team of NASA scientists discovered three supermassive black holes that are about to collide together. We're learning more about black holes than ever, but the mysterious voids keep teaching us new and surprising things about our universe. Tap the link in our bio to read some of our recent articles about black holes. #space

post208.caption: What do you get when you cross a labrador with a poodle? Apparently, the answer is Frankensteins monster. At least, that's according to dog breeder Wally Conron, the inventor of the labradoodle breed. Conron said that creating the labradoodle may be his life's greatest regret citing strange behavior, health concerns and unscrupulous breeders imitating his work with little regard for the dogs welfare. He claims the pups are either "crazy" or have major hereditary problems. Do you have a labradoodle? Let us know in the comments if you've got a happy pup or a freaky Fido, and tap the link in our bio to read more. #dogs

post209.caption: "I just want to live." These are the words of 43-year-old IT consultant Malakkar Vohryzek. He has a genetic condition with no name and no cure but he wants to use CRISPR gene-hacking technology to find a solution. What Vohryzek wants is to insert an entirely new gene into his DNA which is likely beyond the scope of current gene-hacking technology. The radical tech still has many unknowns, and requires more research before medical professionals will sign off on it so Vohryzek is volunteering to become a CRISPR guinea pig. "If I die because of an experimental treatment, it will at least help science," he said. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on Neoscope. #CRISPR

post210.caption: Kaboom. Six galaxies just suddenly ignited into voracious quasars a process that *should* have taken thousands of years. Researchers have spotted six previously quiet galaxies suddenly transforming into quasars a transition that could force astronomers to revisit what they thought they knew about one of the brightest, most energetic types of objects in the universe. Theory suggests that a quasar should take thousands of years to turn on, researcher Suvi Gezari of the University of Maryland said in a press release, but these observations suggest that it can happen very quickly. It tells us that the theory is all wrong. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on The Byte. #space

post211.caption: Way at the bottom of the deep blue sea, there's... still a ton of toxic oil and it's mutating the sea creatures. About 6,000 feet below sea level at the site of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, the seafloor remains all-but-lifeless an eerie, oil-coated wasteland populated largely by tumor-laden nightmare crustaceans. Video footage from a 2017 expedition resurfaced, showing a the hellish glimpse of the seafloor. It confirmed scientists worst suspicions: The Gulf of Mexico is still far from recovering from the catastrophic 2010 oil spill and the area may even have suffered permanent devastation. Tap the link in our bio to read more about these mutated mollusks on The Byte. #science

post212.caption: This laser could tear through the very fabric of space and time" if only it weren't just hypothetical. The prestigious academic physics journal Physical Review Letters published a paper last week about cutting-edge laser tech and it could have some wild ramifications. The paper itself is dry and technical, but the tech described in it is fascinating: it could theoretically pulse a laser through the fabric of the Universe. But the problem with super-powerful lasers? They tend to shred anything you would use to focus the beam. So how could we control it? Tap the link in our bio to read more on The Byte. #technology

post213.caption: Take a look at this absolute unit of a neutron star. A team of astronomers from West Virginia University claim theyve discovered the most massive neutron star to date packing in more than double the mass of the Sun into a sphere thats only 15 miles across. With the catchy name J0740+6620, the star is the corpse of a massive celestial body that was once between 10 and 29 times the mass of the Sun but collapsed in on itself in a supernova explosion. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on Futurism. #stars

post214.caption: The Navy is taking UFO sightings seriously. Very seriously. And now there's video footage showing unidentified aerial phenomena," captured on film by the military, which was never meant to be shown to the public. First published on a blog dedicated to exposing government secrets, three videos showing UFOs have been confirmed by the U.S. Navy to be authentic. But keep in mind: unidentified aerial phenomena are simply just that unidentified and unexplained and are not necessarily floating alien ships piloted by little green men. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on Futurism. #UFO

post215.caption: You know the common refrain, "rolling over in their grave?" Well, there may be truth behind it after all. Gruesome new research has revealed that corpses actually thrash around for about a year after we die. You might be imagining a graveyard full of dancing zombies but the movement is really more subtle. As bodies decompose, they tend to slowly-but-surely writhe around as the body mummifies and the ligaments dry out. To catch a glimpse of the corpse wiggling, a team of Australian scientists photographed a mans corpse every half hour for 17 months, according to the research published last month in a new journal called Forensic Science International: Synergy. The bodys arms started down along its sides, but ended up outstretched a troubling find that could also have far-reaching implications for forensic investigators. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #death

post216.caption: Here's what happens when you hit the eject button on your journey into space: In the event of an emergency, SpaceX's Crew Dragon module can engage its own thrusters to quickly escape the danger. The spacecraft is outfitted with eight SuperDraco engines, allowing it to cover half a mile in just 7.5 seconds during an emergency, reaching a top speed of 436 mph. Once the ejected module has safely escaped danger, parachutes are deployed to carry the craft gently back down to Earth. At least, that's the idea. SpaceX has been testing the Crew Dragon's abort system to ensure everything works in the event of an emergency but the tests don't always go as planned. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #SpaceX

post217.caption: Is storming Area 51 in search of aliens worth six months in prison or even your life? This may or may not surprise you, but some people have been taking the "Storm Area 51" Facebook event which jokingly urges attendees to swarm the military base to see them aliens" very seriously, and it's already landed two people in jail. If "stormers" are lucky, they might find themselves joining them in the jailhouse. If theyre not so lucky, they could experience a run-in with Air Force personnel who are authorized to use deadly force against Area 51 trespassers. Tap the link in our bio to read more... and be careful out there. #aliens

post218.caption: So... can you see it? (Turn your brightness up) Step aside, Vantablack, because MIT just "accidentally" invented the blackest material in existence. A team of MIT engineers created a material that absorbs 99.995 percent of light that reaches it making it even blacker than Surrey NanoSystems mind-bending Vantablack, which absorbs 99.965 percent of light. The MIT team has since offered up the material to any interested artists. But the substance could have many other applications, such as helping astronomers remove unwanted glare from telescopes. Tap the link in our bio to read more (if you can see it!). #MIT

post219.caption: As the vape lung crisis looms over the U.S., the White House wants to ban all flavored vape juice. The Trump administration is calling for a ban on flavored vape juice like the popular mango Juul pods arguing that companies like Juul where several former Trump staffers now work have made their nicotine more appealing to kids and teens. The Trump Administration is making it clear that we intend to clear the market of flavored e-cigarettes to reverse the deeply concerning epidemic of youth e-cigarette use that is impacting children, families, schools and communities, Alex Azar, the Health and Human Services Secretary, said in a statement. We will not stand idly by as these products become an on-ramp to combustible cigarettes or nicotine addiction for a generation of youth. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #JUUL

post220.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Pre-order our book "Cartoons from Tomorrow" for more! Link in bio.

post221.caption: So this is a first and it's a big deal. A team of researchers from the Institute for Research on Exoplanets at the Universit de Montral have detected water vapor and maybe even rain in the atmosphere of an exoplanet that's located in its star's habitable zone. Detecting liquid water on exoplanets suggests that they could harbor life and the more water worlds we spot, the closer we get to confirming that were not alone in the universe. The planet, named K2-18b and discovered by NASAs Keplers space telescope in 2015, is as far away from its star as Earth is from the Sun meaning it receives a similar amount of energy. Scientists dont know if life would be able to survive on K2-18b, but theyre hailing the discovery as a breakthrough. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on The Byte. #space

post222.caption: Are you seeing what I'm seeing? We might soon be able to communicate telepathically, thanks to brain-computer interfaces. At least, thats the gist of a new report about neural implant technology by the Royal Society, a UK scientific organization. Not only thoughts, but sensory experiences, could be communicated from brain to brain, the report reads. Someone on holiday could beam a neural postcard of what they are seeing, hearing or tasting into the mind of a friend back home. Which means, if you ever wanted to share your sensory experiences with your mates, you may soon have your chance. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on Futurism.com #technology

post223.caption: Five deaths. So far, there have been five deaths from the mysterious vaping-related respiratory illness that's sweeping the United States. Listen up: health officials are urging vapers to give up their e-cigarettes and vape pens at least temporarily. Researchers in Utah claim theyve identified a new connection between sufferers of vape lung and it could help health officials finally get to the bottom of the strange sickness. The researchers discovered lipid-laden macrophages, a type of immune cell containing oily droplets, in the lungs of all six patients treated for vape lung at Salt Lake Citys University Hospital. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #vaping

post224.caption: The vaping-related illness sweeping the U.S. may have been caused by a chemical that's relatively harmless for humans except when you smoke it. The FDA believes vitamin E acetate could be the culprit for the vaping related deaths. The vitamin is present in many foods, from almonds to olive oil, and its acetate form is often ingested as a nutritional supplement and used topically in lotions and skin treatments. But while it might be safe to eat or apply to ones skin, experts arent entirely sure what vitamin E acetate does to the human body when vaporized and inhaled. Lungs are designed to exchange gas molecules but theyre not meant to process other chemicals. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #vaping

post225.caption: He's baaaaaaaaaaaack. Do you remember the doctor who wanted to inject patients with young blood in the hopes of reversing aging? Back in February, the FDA shot down the procedure, warning that transfusions of youthful blood as anti-aging treatments were likely scams and based on dangerous pseudoscience. The warning spelled doom for Ambrosia, LLC, a young blood transfusion clinic founded by Stanford graduate Jesse Karmazin, which shut down soon afterward. Now, he's back, and ready to start injecting people again. But keep in mind: The procedure has no scientifically proven anti-aging benefits, it's a minimum of $8,000, and the FDA doesn't endorse it. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this vampiric science. #medicine

post226.caption: This is the story of a cloned cat named Garlic. Heartbroken after the death of his beloved Garlic, Chinas Huang Yu made a bold decision: he would have the cat cloned. Sure, Garlic 2.0 wouldnt necessarily have the originals personality, but at least Huang would be able to look at the new animal and see his beloved Garlic looking back at him... right? That was the idea, anyway. But $35,000 and one cloned kitty later, Huang's new and improved Garlic... isn't quite what he expected. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #cats

post227.caption: Who wants a bite of this space sandwich? Equipped with new data, astronomers hoped to make better sense of the Fermi Bubbles: a giant pair of high-energy blobs that sandwich our galaxy and appear to originate from the black hole at the center of the Milky Way. But they didnt quite find the answers they wanted. Even ignoring the high-energy beams that the bubbles seem to give off, scientists are still struggling to explain where the Fermi Bubbles came from in the first place. Its possible that theyre giant cosmic burps given off by our galaxys central black hole, or they might be the result of a massive chain of stars going supernova at once. Tap the link in our bio to read more on The Byte. #space

post228.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Pre-order our book "Cartoons from Tomorrow" for more! Link in bio.

post229.caption: Should we put nuclear weapons in the hands of artificial intelligence? Researchers associated with the U.S. Air Force want to hand over nuclear launch codes to an AI, which would decide when to launch the first strike. The researchers cowrote an article with the ominous title America Needs a Dead Hand arguing that the United States needs to develop an automated strategic response system based on artificial intelligence. In other words, they want to give an AI the codes to the nukes. And yes, as the authors admit, it sure sounds a lot like the Doomsday Machine from Stanley Kubricks 1964 satire Dr. Strangelove. But should we trust an AI to know when to mount a nuclear attack? Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on Futurism. #AI

post230.caption: Could a trip to space help cure cancer? That might sound ridiculous, but hear us out. A team of doctors has a new idea in the fight against cancer: ship tumors up into space. Thats based on a recent finding that most cancer cells subjected to microgravity in a lab died off without any other treatment. The team of doctors from Australias University of Technology Sydney wants to test the fringe theory by sending samples up to the International Space Station to further test the bizarre idea. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #cancer

post231.caption: How would you like to create your own wormhole? Here are some DIY instructions. Some assembly required. Oh, also, it's all just totally theoretical. So heres a simple how-to on how to construct a traversable cosmic wormhole that could send your spaceship to the furthest reaches of space: take two charged black holes, place them back to back, and thread two cosmic strings through both. Stretch both strings to infinity and presto! Youve got yourself a traversable wormhole. Confused yet? A team of astrophysicists dreamed up this solution, which could technically send travelers to a distant corner of the universe, in a preprint paper on arXiv earlier this month and Ohio State University astrophysicist Paul Sutter published a terrific breakdown of the concept. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #space

post232.caption: You're either going to think this is really, really cool or really, really gross. The future of brain surgery could involve worm-like robots wriggling through the veins in your brain. A team of researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have invented this little wiggling guy to be steered through the tiny arteries in the human brain using a magnet opening new doors for minimally invasive brain surgery by accessing places in the brain that have thus far remained unreachable. It could treat lesions and help unblock blockages in the brain that could otherwise result in aneurysms and strokes. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #neuroscience

post233.caption: So....... humans........ talk........ pretty slowly. At least, according to artificial intelligence we do. When scientists finally crack the code of superhuman AI, verbal communication between us humans and the machines may be a total wash, according to SpaceX and Tesla CEO Elon Musk. Musk thinks the main problem will be the different speeds that humans and computers process information with us humans moving at a glacial pace, comparatively. As computer engineers continue to build blazing-fast processors, our puny mortal brains won't be able to keep up with the future of AI. But Musk thinks Neuralink could help bridge the communication gap between AI and humans. Do you think we'll be able to keep up with AI? Let us know in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more on The Byte. #ElonMusk

post234.caption: What happens when TV's iconic "Westworld" actress @evanrachelwood and the world's most famous real-life humanoid robot, @realsophiarobot, have a chance encounter in a swanky NY hotel bar? Find out in "SophiaWorld", premiering September 4th only on Futurism.com

post235.caption: Here's some sweet news: the inside of Saturn might flow like honey. Using the data from the final transmission of the Cassini spacecraft which plunged itself into Saturn in 2017 scientists have made a remarkable discovery about the gas giant: its liquid interior might be viscous, flowing like honey. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what we learned from Cassini's "death dive." #Saturn

post236.caption: A newly proposed kind of space elevator could actually work. Researchers from Columbia University and Cambridge University published a new document which proposes the creation of "the Spaceline" which would link the Earth and the Moon. It could drastically cut the cost of space travel. The Spaceline would be tethered to the surface of the Moon and dangle down into geostationary orbit around the Earth like a plumb bob, waiting for astronauts to latch on and ride into the cosmos. It could even be built from materials that exist today, putting the cosmos virtually within reach of our fingertips. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Futurism.com

post237.caption: A mysterious disease affecting people who vape is sweeping the U.S. but experts still have no idea what's causing it. The illness has now claimed its first life, igniting an urgency at the CDC to investigate why there's now a surge in reported cases. If vaping were a brand-new practice, the illnesses might make more sense. But e-cigarettes and vapes have been around for years. So why are so many people experiencing serious vaping-related health issues now including death over just the past few months? Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #vaping

post238.caption: We probably should have seen this coming: kids are becoming emotionally attached to robots. Todays toddlers and preschoolers are growing up surrounded by friendly-looking, sometimes humanlike robotic devices and educational tools a phenomenon that scientists warn could be confusing. While young children tend to understand that the robotic helpers all around them arent truly alive, toddlers tend to form emotional ties with the bots a phenomenon that has some researchers concerned. Researchers advise parents to be mindful about the way they talk about robots. Don't ascribe the bot a gender, and remind impressionable children that their toys are merely machines. Tap the link in our bio to read about this and more on Futurism.com. #robots

post239.caption: Full steam ahead! Scientists are working on a new low-cost, efficient way to get satellites up into space. Instead of launching rockets from the ground, a team from the Finnish Meteorology Institute is investigating whether satellites could be lifted up into orbit through steam-filled balloons and launched from there. Tap the link in our bio to read more of the latest stories in science and technology. #space

post240.caption: This steampunk bionic heart uses maglev tech to pump blood and it could keep patients alive until their donor organs arrive. A team of engineers from private medical company Bivacor have been working hard since 2001 on building a bionic heart that can allow cardiac patients to stay alive without a real human heart. The steampunk apparatus works by harnessing the power of magnetic levitation to spin a disc at extremely fast speeds to pump blood to the body and return oxygen-depleted blood to the lungs. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this fascinating piece of biotechnology. #health

post241.caption: Super-intelligent AI could totally crush humanity if it wanted to. As tech corporations like Facebook and Google, and government research firms like the Pentagons DARPA or Russias Advanced Research Foundation try to create super-powered artificial general intelligence, precautions must be taken to prevent an AI takeover from happening. But is anyone really working on this? Wim Naud, a professorial fellow at the United Nations University, argues that the government needs to step in, both to make sure artificial general intelligence benefits the public at large and to make sure nobody unleashes a malicious algorithm on humanity. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #AI

post242.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Pre-order "Cartoons from Tomorrow!" Link in bio.

post243.caption: Get rekt scrub. YouTube is suing a man who allegedly swatted a Minecraft streamer. But that wasn't until after he tried to extort money from them. On Monday, YouTube filed a lawsuit against a Nebraska man for allegedly abusing the platforms copyright takedown process. According to the suit, Omahas Christopher Brady filed false copyright notices against at least three popular Minecraft streamers. He then attempted to extort money from the YouTubers and even launched a swatting attack (a form of criminal harassment in which a person contacts emergency services to falsely report a serious crime) against one. Tap the link in our bio to read this and more on Futurism.com #future

post244.caption: Cyberwarfare may seem like a problem for only big tech companies to worry about, but the impact of an attack can have devastating real-life consequences for society. Jeremy Straub, an assistant professor of computer science at North Dakota State University, argues that a cyberattack can be just as damaging as a nuclear weapon, wreaking havoc on transportation, health, and communications and could even lead to deaths. What do you think? Do you worry about your cybersecurity? Let us know in the comments, and tap the link in our bio to read more on The Byte. #cybersecurity

post245.caption: We finally have a cure for the deadliest strain of the most common infectious cause of death on Earth: tuberculosis. The Food and Drug Administration just approved the third and final part of a new drug regimen shown to cure the deadliest strain of tuberculosis, XDR, in 90 percent of people. Patients take five pills every day for six months straight, but thats nothing compared to the existing treatment, which requires 40 pills every day for two years. Tap the link in our bio to read more on Neoscope. #health

post246.caption: *monch, monch* Looks like Jupiter may have eaten one of its planet siblings. Jupiters core is a bizarre mix of solid rocks mixed with a diffuse bubble of hydrogen gas. And the story of how it got that way has long eluded explanation. But now scientists think theyre on to something, suggesting that the gas giant absorbed another protoplanet during a head-on collision some 4.5 billion years ago when our solar system was forming. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the origin story of our solar system's largest planet. #Jupiter

post247.caption: Kaboom. This is the explosion of the most massive star to ever detonate into a brutal supernova that scientists have ever witnessed. Like, ever. The European Space Agency scientists spotted the stellar explosion, dubbed SN2016iet, back in 2016 but it took three years of analysis and follow-up investigations for them to comprehend they had seen. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about this stunning explosion. #space

post248.caption: Woof. This doggie monstrosity named "Astro" is the stuff of nightmares. Researchers from Florida Atlantic University (FAU) set out to build a robodog that combined all the best parts of Siri, 3D-printing, and nimble, next-gen robots like Boston Dynamics SpotMini. Unfortunately, Astros engineers added an extra component to the bot: horrible, human-like eyes. Tap the link in our bio to see the strange pup in action. #robot

post249.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Preorder "Cartoons from Tomorrow!" Link in bio.

post250.caption: In the future, weapons may be able to target us using only our DNA. Humanity can't afford to wait when it comes to defending ourselves against biological weapons. According to a new report out of Cambridge University, world governments have failed to prepare for futuristic weapons based on advanced technology like artificial intelligence and genetic manipulation or even a killer pathogen designed to kill only people of a particular race. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #DNA

post251.caption: Sometimes, people are just too funny, and too clever for their own good. One cybersecurity expert learned this lesson the hard way when he tested a galaxy-brain plan to hide his car from license plate readers and ticketing systems by registering the vanity license plate NULL. His plan worked, sort of the NULL plates definitely caused a problem within the system. But they also caused a citation processing center to send the guy, who goes by Droogie in the cybersec community, $18,000 worth of parking tickets and other fines. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #technology

post252.caption: Who knew mice could be such great listeners? The future of deepfake detection could be in the tiny paws of mice like this one. The rodents seem to have impeccable hearing when it comes to detecting deepfaked audio. Researchers at the University of Oregon believe they can train mice to listen for irregularities in recorded speech, the kind that can crop up in audio deepfakes and so far, the rodents seem to show promise as organic deepfake detectors. Tap the link in our bio to read more about these tiny detectives. #deepfake

post253.caption: I spy with my bionic eye... Researchers from visual prosthetics company Second Second Sight Medical Products have created a new bionic eye system that sends electrical signals to the wearers brain via an implant, allowing them to see again. They say that not only will the devices grant improved fields of visual depth, but could also give wearers infrared vision. Talk about "eye-opening" insights! Tap the link in our bio to read this and more stories on Futurism.com. . . . . . #future

post254.caption: If you ever wanted to live off noodles, here's your chance. Nissin, the company behind one prominent line of instant ramen noodle packets, is poised to launch a new All-In Noodles product that, it says, fully satisfies a typical persons nutritional requirements. Nissin isnt the first company to try its hand at cheap, easy meal replacements but if you've ever wanted to try your hand at living off an all-noodle diet, there's no time like the present. Tap the link in our bio to read more stories like this on Futurism.com . . . . . . . #noodles

post255.caption: It's back... After being removed by Facebook, the event called Storm Area 51 has been resurrected. But no advanced extraterrestrial technology was behind the move: according to a spokesperson for Facebook, the event was removed by mistake. Oops... The resurrected Facebook event still has more than 2 million loyal followers enlisted to join the fray. While there's never been a shortage of "Area 51" paraphernalia, popular events like this have encouraged the creation of all kinds of official "Storm Area 51" merch. Tap the link in bio to read this and more on Futurism.com

post256.caption: Finally, just what we needed, a robotic tail you can wear. Scientists at Keio University built a robotic tail called Arque with built-in artificial muscles and vertebrae. The tail uses a pneumatic system to bend and move along with the wearer, acting as a smart counterbalance as they lean over or sway. Practical applications are... uncertain. While the robot tail is still fairly limited in functionality, its an unusual glimpse into the future of human-augmenting technology. Tap the link in our bio to see a video of the tail in action. . . . . #robotics

post257.caption: "You got to do what you got to do to protect your child." For parents in America, back-to-school shopping this year is about more than buying notebooks and binders its about giving their child the best possible chance of surviving a school shooting. Sales of bulletproof backpacks have sharply increased, but unfortunately, the backpacks arent quite as bulletproof as their name implies they're not effective against bullets from rifles. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #America

post258.caption: It may sound like a paradox, but some icy planets could be warm enough to support life. Hear us out. New research by a team of astronomers at the University of Toronto suggests that extraterrestrial life could survive on icy planets which, until now, were thought to be too cold. They ran thousands of simulations to explore the temperature fluctuations of planets inside habitable zones and found large unfrozen areas of land where life could persist. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #space

post259.caption: This blurry blob of a planet is basically Hell in the shape of a football. An international team of astronomers has found a distant exoplanet thats being deformed into the shape of a football by the brutal gravitational pull of its host star. A paper about the bizarre planet that was published today in the Astronomical Journal, explaining that these planets are so heavily irradiated by their host stars, theyre almost like stars themselves. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this strange misshapen discovery. #space

post260.caption: Can we build robots that are indistinguishable from humans? An artificial intelligence first passed the Turing Test in 2014, and now, a team of researchers from Staffordshire University has taken it one step further by creating a way to test whether a machine can act just like a human, as well as think like one. They call it a "Multimodal Turing Test," and they hope it will one day help answer the question posed above. What do you think? Can we do it? Let us know in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more. #robots

post261.caption: The future of warfare is a mysterious AI with a "brain." The U.S. military has been developing a top-secret artificial brain military AI system that they named seriously Sentient. Newly released confidential and classified documents describe the Sentient Program as a fully-integrated intelligence system that can coordinate satellite positions and may soon be used to manage battlefield operations during military engagements. That means algorithms, with all their dangerous built-in biases, could be directing military conflicts in the near future. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #military

post262.caption: Animal embryos + Human cells = the future of organ transplants? A Japanese scientist from the University of Tokyo just got permission from the government to create animal embryos that contain human cells ethically perilous work that could lead, eventually, to growing human organs in animal hosts for the purpose of transplantation. Would you accept an organ you needed if it was grown inside an animal? Let us know in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more. #health

post263.caption: Some of the design features used on social media are so addictive that even Silicon Valley parents dont want their kids using the services they create. A new bill before the Senate aims to ban social media and tech platforms from implementing addictive designs and features including autoplaying videos or endless scrolling. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #technology

post264.caption: Women have been integral to space travel from commanding the ISS to calculating the math to send us into space safely. And now NASA says the next astronaut to touch down on the Moon will "likely be a woman." But not everyone agrees with this plan. Retired NASA astronaut and former International Space Station commander Peggy Whitson is rebuking NASAs plan, saying she doesnt think gender should have anything to do with the Moonwalker decision. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #space

post265.caption: Mmm... nothing better than the smell of a crispy, plant-based meat substitute frying on a griddle. Beyond Meat, the successful plant-based meat company, has a new faux-meat product on the horizon and it might just be your favorite breakfast food. Arguably the king of animal product-based breakfast foods, fake bacon could eventually make its way into staple breakfast menu items like breakfast sandwiches. Would you try it? Let us know in the comments, and tap the link in our bio to read more. #food

post266.caption: Whew, that was a close one. A space rock that could have leveled an entire city just hurtled right past Earth, coming within six Earth diameters of smashing into our home planet. Astronomers didnt spot the city killer asteroid until days before it careened closer to the Earth than the Moon at about 61 times the speed of a commercial jet. And if it had hit us? It would have exploded with more energy than a nuclear weapon. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #space

post267.caption: Headstones and eulogies are about to get a lot more interesting. The future is filled with exciting new possibilities including horrible new ways to die. When will the first person die from a vengeful sex robot? What about a leak in your off-brand spacesuit? For that matter, wholl be the first person to escape the traditional age of death living to be 1,000 years old, or even far longer? Tap the link in our bio to read our predictions for the future of death, and let us know in the comments which futuristic way to die sounds the worst. #death

post268.caption: A strange pair of dead stars rapidly orbiting each other's corpses could shed light on everything from black holes to the birth of our universe. Every three nights, the California Institute of Technologys Zwicky Transient Facility uses its massive 576-megapixel camera to scan the entire sky, leading to the detection of hundreds of asteroids, comets, and supernovae. But the survey may have just made its strangest discovery yet: a binary white dwarf system called ZTF J1539+5027. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this bizarre bunch. #space

post269.caption: A tiny implant about the size of a penny could revolutionize the future of HIV prevention. Today, people with a high risk of contracting HIV can choose to take a daily medication called pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) which can prevent them from catching the virus. But just like some people have trouble remembering to take their birth control pill every day, theres a chance a person might forget to consistently take their PrEP, which makes it far less effective. Now, global biopharmaceutical company Merck thinks its found a solution to this problem: an implant that delivers a years worth of HIV-preventing medication gradually. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the future of sexual health. #HIV

post270.caption: RT: and I oop! Chris Wetherell, the guy who built Twitters retweet function, wishes he hadnt. Before 2009, people had to manually repost other peoples tweets onto their own accounts, something that required at least some amount of conscious effort and thought. With a retweet button, sharing and amplifying content online became more impulsive and less thoughtful a shift that led to an explosion of disinformation online. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #Twitter

post271.caption: Where in the world is John McAfee? The man who wants to be the next U.S. president is missing and therell be hell to pay if he doesnt turn up soon. McAfees campaign manager sent several tweets from his bosss account claiming he now has good reason to suspect that McAfee who has been running his campaign in exile since January to avoid charges of tax fraud has been detained. And if he doesn't show up soon? McAfee allegedly has "secreted data" hidden across the globe to be released upon his disappearance. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about what might be in these mysterious "data payloads." #JohnMcAfee

post272.caption: As if colonizing space wasn't hard enough, one scientist claims that babies born in space won't even be fully human. Evolutionary biologist Scott Solomon says childbirth in space will be incredibly difficult, making cesarean deliveries the norm for space explorers which could lead to babies evolving larger, alien-like heads. Eventually, people living in space could evolve to be different enough from people on Earth that we would consider them to be different species, Solomon says. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the evolutionary changes facing future human space colonists. #space

post273.caption: Astronomers have a new theory about the formation of supermassive black holes. Long-dead celestial objects called "dark stars" may have become today's supermassive black holes. Extremely bright objects that first appeared close to the birth of the universe theoretical objects called dark stars could have seeded supermassive black holes over millions of years, according to a new "Astronomy" story about University of Michigan physicist Katherine Freese. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the formation of these galactic behemoths.

post274.caption: Last one to the Moon is a rotten egg! Comic by @lukekingma and @loupatrickmackay Want more Futurism Cartoons? See this and 75+ more never-before-seen cartoons in our upcoming book, Cartoons from Tomorrow! Available this September, you can learn more or even pre-order a copy at the link in our bio. #futurismcartoons

post275.caption: Red pill, blue pill, or pill 3D-printed specifically to contain every medicine you are prescribed? Personalized pharmaceutical products company Multiply Labs envisions a future in which patients can finally say goodbye to swallowing a cocktail of different pills organized in a plastic divider case. The startups promise: a single, 3D-printed daily capsule tailored around the needs of each patient. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the future of medicine.

post276.caption: Scientists made mice hallucinate by shining light at their brains, and now they're wondering why humans aren't hallucinating all the time. Unless you suffer from a neurological disorder, such as schizophrenia or like to dabble in psychedelics chances are you dont spend much time worrying about seeing things that arent there. But now, a team led by researchers from Stanford University believes its found a way to make mice, and therefore potentially humans, hallucinate and what they discovered has left them wondering why humans arent hallucinating all the time. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post277.caption: "Digital fur technology" will transform the star-studded cast of the upcoming cinematic remake of the Broadway show Cats." Increasingly complicated software and algorithms have slowly been helping Hollywood to tackle challenging animated effects. Detailed fine fur, for example, is very difficult to animate because of its complexity. Now "digital fur technology" is being credited with creating more realistic looking human-cat hybrids than we've probably ever seen before. Tap the link in our bio to read more and see a behind the scenes clip. . . . . . . #futurism

post278.caption: Ready or not, bionic enhancements are coming. Will they change what it means to be human? Theoretical neuroscientist Vivienne Ming has focused her professional career on exploring ways to use tech to maximize human potential but in a fascinating new Quartz essay, she details how she has also channeled her inner mad scientist for an intensely personal reason. According to Ming, after her son was diagnosed with autism, she put her expertise to work to build a face- and expression-recognition system for Google Glass designed to interpret others facial expressions in real-time, a skill which most neurotypical people are born with but one that may seem like a superpower to someone with autism. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post279.caption: There may be fundamental flaws with our understanding of the universe. A new attempt by scientists to calculate the Hubble Constant which represents how rapidly the universe is expanding outward has revealed some troubling gaps in our understanding. The discrepancy in scientists' numbers calls into question not only our idea of how old the universe is, but also our ability to fundamentally understand the physics that drive its behavior. Tap the link in our bio to learn more. #Hubble

post280.caption: Careful out there. The guards of Area 51 are fully prepared to defend it against intruders. Over 1.3 million Facebook users have clicked "Going" to a tongue-in-cheek Facebook event called Storm Area 51, They Cant Stop All of Us with the goal of storming the secret Air Force base in the Nevada desert in search of aliens. But be warned: those defending Area 51 are authorized to use deadly force," if necessary. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #aliens

post281.caption: Mark your calendars. Elon Musk's mysterious neurotechnology startup, Neuralink, is finally going to break its silence this Thursday. The company, founded in 2016, is focused on finding a way to directly link the human brain to computers and soon we might finally learn what they're achieved these past few years. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #ElonMusk

post282.caption: Don't worry, mommy is here to tuck you in. It turns out robots really could take over all jobs including being a parent. According to author and AI ethics expert John C. Havens, bots could become very efficient caregivers, good enough to one day steal the right to raise children away from humans. What do you think? Let us know in the comments and tap the link in our bio to read more. #robots

post283.caption: Are you ready to join the front line in the search for extraterrestrial life? Almost 300,000 people say they're going to storm Area 51 to look for aliens at least that's according to who has RSVP'd to a Facebook event called Storm Area 51, They Cant Stop All of Us. The page has amassed an army of memers, schemers and tinfoil hat-wearing conspirators who are ready to raid the top-secret Air Force military base in the middle of Nevadas desert. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #aliens

post284.caption: "Its really a life-changing thing. Australian surgeon Natasha van Zyl has dramatically improved the lives of 13 people who suffered total paralysis in all four of their limbs after sporting and traffic accidents. By moving around the nerves in their appendages using a technique known as "nerve transfer," van Zyl restored the patients ability to extend their elbows and grasp and pinch with their hands and she thinks many others could experience the same benefits. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #health

post285.caption: Here's Jimmy! Someone has finally done it: they used machine learning to superimpose the face of Jim Carrey onto Jack Nicholsons character in Stanley Kubricks iconic 1980 adaptation of Stephen Kings The Shining. In terms of mapping Carreys face onto Nicholsons complex performance, it's one of the most impressive deepfakes weve seen. Lets be real, though you just want to see it. Tap the link in our bio to watch the video and read more. #machinemearning

post286.caption: Should we risk experimenting on humans especially when the intervention is not necessary to save their lives? This is the question scientists are asking themselves about Denis Rebrikov the Russian biologist who wants to use CRISPR to create more gene-edited babies. Rebrikob has five pairs of Russian parents eager to let him gene-edit their embryos for a very controversial reason: to prevent the offspring from inheriting their parents deafness. But are the benefits of hearing worth the risks of gene editing? Let us know what you think in the comments, and tap the link in our bio to read more. #CRISPR

post287.caption: Sorry to disappoint, but that big floating space rock 'Oumuamua wasn't sent by aliens. In 2017, an asteroid came barreling past the Earth. And not only did it hail from outside our solar system, but it also had a weird shape and spin, plus it accelerated in an unexpected way while passing the Sun. Astronomers dubbed the strange asteroid Oumuamua, and soon, speculation swirled that the object was sent by aliens but a new study sheds some light on its true origins. Tap the link in our bio to read more. ##aliens

post288.caption: We may never know when the third CRISPR-edited baby is born. The Chinese government has kept quiet in the face of news that a third CRISPR birth is expected soon. Either theres no news to report, or the Chinese government is closely controlling the information surrounding the massive scientific controversy. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #CRISPR

post289.caption: This is big. Really big. For the first time ever, researchers have eliminated HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, from the genomes of living animals a major accomplishment along the path to freeing the world of this deadly disease. While the researchers are optimistic, they're also aware that there's a lot of ground to cover between mice and humans. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this amazing breakthrough. #HIV

post290.caption: Calling all of Earth's citizens! Scientists want to know how you think humanity should react if aliens come calling. Every movie about aliens arriving on Earth tends to show only politicians and scientists deciding what to do. But the UK Seti Research Network thinks the average person should have a say in how Earth responds if aliens ever decide to say hello to humanity. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #aliens

post291.caption: Your Fourth of July fireworks have nothing on these stunning photos from Hubble. Roughly 7,500 light-years away from Earth is a double star system called Eta Carinae. In 1838, one of the systems two stars underwent a near-death experience astronomers dubbed the Great Eruption, and for nearly two centuries, scientists have been watching the stunning aftermath of that event. NASA and the ESA released new photos of Eta Carinae captured by the Hubble telescope and the most extravagant July 4th firework display won't hold a candle to this cosmic one. While you're celebrating, tap the link in our bio to read more. #Hubble

post292.caption: If you have the money, these Rent-a-Friends have the time. Lots of people think they know how to address the loneliness epidemic sweeping the globe. But this is the strangest effort we've seen yet. Long before loneliness epidemic was even a term, entrepreneur Scott Rosenbaum was already attempting to help people feel less socially isolated by renting friends to them by the hour. Tap the link in our bio to read more (but check out the fine print on that dollar, first). #money

post293.caption: When in doubt, just go to the post office. At least, that would have helped the two men in Southern California who used the dark web to sell more than $8.8 million worth of methamphetamine they marketed as Adderall. The operation appeared to be chugging along quite nicely until the dark web drug dealers made a fatal mistake. The men mailed drugs to undercover federal agents using pre-printed postage purchased online and the feds were able to track that back to them. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #darkweb

post294.caption: We cant travel billions of years back in time at least not yet, anyways. So, until then, one of the best ways to understand how our universe evolved is to create computer simulations of the process using what we do know about it. An international team of researchers has built an AI that can quickly generate highly-accurate, three-dimensional simulations of the universe but somehow, it seems to know more than it's been taught. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #AI

post295.caption: "Hmm... Do I detect an apple?" By embedding engineered bacteria into the fingers of a robot arm, researchers have created a biohybrid bot that can taste using its hands and they think it could lead to a future in which robots are better equipped to respond to the world around them. "We are closer to future breakthroughs like soft biohybrid robots that can adapt their abilities to sense, feel, and move in response to changes in their environmental conditions, one researcher said. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #robots

post296.caption: Europe is on fire figuratively and, in the case of Spains Catalonia region, literally. A town in southern France called Villevieille just reached the countrys hottest-ever recorded temperature of 45.1 degrees Celsius that's 113 Fahrenheit and its hotter than the recorded highs in the Saharan desert. Some are saying the extreme weather is directly linked to climate change. To others, its a warning shot of whats still yet to come. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #Earth

post297.caption: Check your pulse or this laser might do it for you. The U.S. Special Forces are developing a device that can detect a persons unique cardiac signature using an IR laser from a distance. Nicknamed Jetson, the tech can work from at least 200 meters away by analyzing tiny vibrations on the surface of the skin to detect a heartbeat even through a layer of clothing. When a biometric facial recognition system fails to get a good view of a targets face, the laser could help correctly identify targets by their pulse. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #military

post298.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!
