post299.caption: Forget what you think you know about the universe or at least one dimension of it. A two-dimensional universe may still be able to support life. That statement runs in stark opposition to whats called the anthropic argument, which states that if the fundamental properties of our three-dimensional universe were tweaked, life would no longer be possible. Its a bold claim, but University of California physicist James Scargill did the work to back it up, sharing his theory in a new paper that upends many assumptions about the requirements for life as we know it. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #science

post300.caption: Bitcoin is back from the dead. The popular cryptocurrency has reached the highest value it's had in more than a year and Facebook is likely to blame. The social media giants recent unveiling of its own cryptocurrency called Libra seemed to bolster investors confidence in crypto across the board. Though Bitcoin never really recovered from its massive crash in late 2017, the recent resurgence is a sign that the cryptocurrency isnt quite fading away as some believed. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #bitcoin

post301.caption: Apparently, most people in the USA don't really care about getting to Mars. U.S. President Donald Trump recently made it clear he wants NASAs attention on Mars instead of the Moon. But the American people think the space agency should focus on a different planet: Earth. Most of the people polled called monitoring asteroids and comets that could hit the Earth very/extremely important for NASA, but only 27 percent said the same thing about sending humans to Mars revealing a stark disconnect between the priorities of Americans and the administration governing them. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #NASA

post302.caption: Want to control a robot with your mind? You currently have two options. You can get a brain implant in which case your control over the robot will be smooth and continuous or you can skip the risky, expensive surgery in favor of a device that senses your brainwaves from outside your skull, but your control over the bot will not be nearly as precise. A team from Carnegie Mellon University is narrowing the gap between those two options, creating the first noninvasive mind-controlled robot arm. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #robots #

post303.caption: 3D-printed organs that mimic real flesh and blood could become critical practice tools for doctors and surgeons preparing for complex surgeries like transplants. I just wanted something that looks like a kidney that bleeds, one doctor said, and as 3D printing gets cheaper, rehearsing a surgery on a printed replica of a specific patients organ could become the norm rather than the exception. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #medicine

post304.caption: Ready to go under the knife in pursuit of the perfect selfie? In 2018, researchers coined the term Snapchat dysmorphia to describe the phenomenon of clients undergoing surgical procedures to look more like themselves or, at least, the heavily filtered versions of themselves theyd often share on social media. According to a new report it seems that "snapchat dysmorphia" and social media in general are driving more teens and young people to go under the knife sometimes in pursuit of downright impossible results. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post305.caption: Three U.S. senators just received a closed-door Pentagon briefing about UFO sightings. The meeting was about a series of sightings by Navy pilots of unidentified aerial phenomenon yet another sign that Congress is starting to take the matter more seriously. The news, reported by Politico, comes after information emerged in April that the Navy is working on new guidelines for its personnel to report sightings and other encounters with unidentified aircraft." Tap the link in our bio to read more. #UFOs

post306.caption: It used to be that you needed to actually discover something in space if you wanted the thrill of naming it but a new competition is ensuring astronomers dont get to have all the fun. The International Astronomical Union recently announced a competition giving every country on Earth the opportunity to name one exoplanet and its host star. (And the pair will be visible to citizens using a small telescope.) Participating countries will have until November 2019 to decide on a name but Planety McPlanetface wont make the cut. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #space

post307.caption: There are dangers caged within the surface of Arctic ice but the Earth's rising temperatures are threatening to release them. Alongside the ancient fossils now peeking up from the melting permafrost lie frozen toxins, nuclear waste, and enough sequestered carbon to double the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere today. Its a dire situation failing to address global climate change has turned the Arctic into a ticking time bomb. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #climatechange

post308.caption: Death comes for us all even galaxies. Astronomers believe our universe is home to at least 100 billion galaxies. And just like us, each of those massive collections of stars and other space stuff will eventually die. But also like us, galaxies go through a host of phases between birth and death. Now, a researcher from the University of Kansas has discovered one scientists never knew about before. She calls it the cold quasar phase and it could completely upend our understanding of how galaxies die. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #astronomy

post309.caption: What would happen if a robot like Dolores from @westworldhbo met Sophia the Robot? That's the premise of our new short film, SophiaWorld, starring @evanrachelwood and @realsophiarobot! From @futurismstudios, SophiaWorld is premiering Sunday, 6/16 at the @mauifilmfest. Keep an eye on our story highlight for behind the scenes and more information.

post310.caption: We feel the need, the need for... well, maybe some ear plugs. An investigation has has revealed several major problems with the US military's F-35 fighter jet including spikes in cabin pressure that cause pilots to experience severe ear and sinus pain. Some pilots also cant fully control the aircrafts pitch, roll, and yaw after completing certain maneuvers and in some conditions, the aircrafts night vision camera displays green horizontal lines that make it difficult for pilots to see the horizon. The F-35 is supposed to play a major role in the future of the U.S. military but the trillion-dollar program may be in even worse shape than the public knows. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #military

post311.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post312.caption: Its hard to imagine anything that could kill a black hole. The ultra-dense celestial vacuums consume everything in their paths but that cosmic appetite could theoretically be their undoing as well. Thats according to research from the Israel Institute of Technology. A new model shows that a steady diet of bizarre particles with negative energy could gradually chip away at the immense mass of a black hole until it vanishes into nothing. RIP. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #space #

post313.caption: Sorry to disappoint, but alien life is probably way rarer than we thought. Researchers at the University of California, Riverside say that thanks to excessive toxic gases, more than half of the planets we initially thought could harbor alien life are probably dead zones or at least couldnt host life as we know it. But even though those planets are out of the running, it does help narrow down where to look. Tap the link in our bio to read more #space

post314.caption: "I think I'm crazy enough to do it." These are the words of Russian biologist Denis Rebrikov, who told the journal Nature that he's planning to use CRISPR to gene-edit human embryos and bring them to term as soon as later this year. Rebrikov is following in the footsteps of Chinese researcher He Jiankui, who gene-edited a pair of human babies shocking scientists and researchers across the world, who are calling for a moratorium on similar experiments. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this contentious topic. #CRISPR

post315.caption: The Moon has a mystery hidden under its surface and it's the size of an entire island. A team of astronomers found a large excess of mass under the Moons largest crater, the Aitken basin likely a relic from an ancient asteroid impact event, but perhaps something much stranger. Imagine taking a pile of metal five times larger than the Big Island of Hawaii and burying it underground, said lead author Peter B. James from Baylor University in Waco, Texas in a statement. Thats roughly how much unexpected mass we detected. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #Moon

post316.caption: Hey! Down in front! There's something blocking the view of the black hole in our Milky Way. Scientists just got their best look yet at the accretion disk a halo of gas swirling around the supermassive black hole at the core of the Milky Way. Existing X-ray observations have shown that our black holes accretion disk includes an inner layer of superhot gas. But new research confirms for the first time that theres a cooler, outer layer of gas in the accretion disk that hides the rest of the halo from view and it could help explain how black holes behave. Tap the link in our bio to learn more. #blackhole

post317.caption: Alan Turing, who during World War II helped the Allies break Nazi codes and later came to be regarded as a pioneer in computing and artificial intelligence, finally got a proper sendoff in the form of a New York Times obituary. Not only did Turing help decrypt seemingly-unbreakable Nazi codes during WWII, but he also helped kickstart the entire field of artificial intelligence. But in spite of his scientific contributions, Turing died by suicide in 1954 after the British government convicted him of homosexuality a crime in the U.K. until 1967 and chemically castrated him as punishment. Were sorry. You deserved so much better, said then-Prime Minister Gordon Brown in 2009. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #AlanTuring

post318.caption: Your next vacation could be out of this world! Literally. NASA just announced that it will officially allow regular citizens, not just certified astronauts, on board the International Space Station but tickets to the ISS wont come cheap. NASA will be charging private companies about $35,000 a night for use of the stations facilities. And thats not including what the companies will charge individuals for transportation to and from the Space Station. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #space

post319.caption: Can you guess what's in this image? Here's a hint: nothing can escape it and it recently had its first official portrait taken. It's a black hole! Or, at least, a simulation of one. Its been less than two months since scientists released the first actual image of a black hole, but astronomers have been studying the strange phenomena for more than a century. One modern tool is helping: computer simulations that allow researchers to visualize black holes in otherwise-impossible detail. Tap the link in our bio to see more. #blackhole

post320.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post321.caption: Found: Schrdingers cat, alive and well. It might be the most famous feline that never lived. Or that never died, depending on your perspective. In 1935, physicist Erwin Schrdinger concocted a thought experiment to illustrate a pair of strange quantum physics phenomena: superposition and unpredictability. The experiment became known as Schrdingers cat, and for more than 80 years, its served as a cornerstone of quantum physics. But in a newly published study, a team of Yale scientists essentially destroys the premise at the center of the experiment groundbreaking work that could finally allow researchers to develop useful quantum computers. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #science

post322.caption: The technology to create believable deepfakes computer-generated media depicting real people doing or saying things that never occurred is already here and widely accessible. And yet, as America moves towards its 2020 presidential election, Axios reports that not a single candidate can point to measures theyve taken to prevent the spread of this potentially-dangerous media. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #machinelearning

post323.caption: A new flying-v plane would put passenger seats in the wings of the plane. Airlines are testing all sorts of ways to make planes less of a drag on the environment. Virgin Atlantic recently used recycled waste to power a commercial flight, while Boeing and JetBlue have backed an effort to create hybrid electric planes. The Netherlands KLM Royal Dutch Airlines is taking a different approach. It just partnered with a university to develop a radical new airplane designand it could decrease the amount of fuel needed for flights by a substantial 20 percent. Tap the link in our bio to read more. :KLM / TU Delft

post324.caption: Scientists say it's more important than ever to regulate CRISPR or we risk its use to create gray-market enhanced human beings. Chinese researchers have found a way to nearly triple the efficiency of a tool designed to edit genes in human embryos, and their method should be ready for clinical use soon, with gene-edited babies available in another year or two, says Yang Hui, the lead researcher behind the project. But even she is concerned that her teams technological breakthrough could have dire consequences. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #science

post325.caption: Have you seen an extra sparkle in the night sky? Maybe not without a good telescope. But some scientists have been seeing weird flashes of light on the moon. Several times a week, short bursts of light appear on the surface of the Moon and so far, scientists have only been able to guess as to why. But a team of German astronomers has a new theory and it could provide crucial information for humans who want to settle the Moon. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #moon

post326.caption: We know you love Fluffy, but cloning your pet might not be a great idea. Today, anyone can have their dog cloned for $50,000, and that price drop means the service is now starting to hit the mainstream. But experts say pet cloning is overhyped and borders on animal cruelty: All cloned animals have shorter life spans and many more health problems than non-cloned animals. Tap the link in our bio to read more about why you should not See Spot Cloned. #dogs

post327.caption: Its no secret that DeepMinds artificial intelligence has become a champion at video games like StarCraft II and Dota 2. But now, the AI has figured out how to ace cooperative multiplayer mode as wellin fact, it may be better at it than human players. While playing rounds of capture the flag in the classic first-person shooter Quake III Arena, DeepMind was able to outperform human teammates and with the reaction time slowed down to that of a typical human player. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #Deepmind

post328.caption: Stephen Hawking was on to something when, in 1974, he proposed that black holes emit small streams of particles at their event horizons. These particles became know as Hawking radiation, and based on the physicists predictions, a black holes mass should determine its temperature. Researchers from the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology tested his theory, but by creating a different kind of black hole one that absorbs sound in the lab, and measuring the temperature of its Hawking radiation. The measurements matched what Hawking had predicted 45 years ago but we wont know for sure if his theory holds up in space until were able to test the theory on the light-absorbing black holes populating our universe. Tap the link in our bio to learn more. #blackhole

post329.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post330.caption: Have you ever heard of parthenogenesis? Well, a snake at the New England Aquarium just did it: an anaconda named Anna had a "virgin birth" in which she produced offspring without ever having mated. Scientists at the New England Aquarium confirmed last week that one of their snakes gave birth without ever mating with a male, producing three little anacondas with identical DNA to their mother. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this fascinating genetic fluke. #snakes

post331.caption: If startups selling alleged brain-enhancing wearables are to be believed, their brain-zapping headsets will help you rapidly learn new skills, stave off neurological disease, and become an elite athlete. But because thats not the case, scientists and ethicists are urging the companies to dial back their bold claims because the science, they say, simply doesnt hold up. Tap the link in our bio to learn more. #brain

post332.caption: Plasma is the most common form of matter in our universe, but it's extremely difficult to study. But there's good news: by studying the plasma in the Suns atmosphere its gases exist primarily in plasma form since, obviously, its extremely hot researchers say we could learn how to control the plasma here on Earth and finally make fusion energy a reality. EDIT: The missing link to this article has now been added! Tap the url in our bio to read more. #energy

post333.caption: Bad news, people. The Earths oceans are gradually leaking into the interior of the planet. Thats according to new research by Norwegian scientists who say the Earths water is slowly draining into the planets crust though nowhere near fast enough to cancel out the sea level rises were currently experiencing because of climate change. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #environment

post334.caption: For a $1.2 million dollar bid, you could own a 2008 Samsung laptop containing six of the most infamous computer viruses in history. The infectious computer is an art project titled The Persistence of Chaos, created in collaboration between Chinese internet artist Guo O Dong and cybersecurity company Deep Instinct. Guo explained the reasoning behind his creation as a kind of bestiary, a catalogue of historical threats. Malware is "one of the most tangible ways that the internet can jump out of your monitor and bite you, Guo said. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #computers

post335.caption: In order to combat superbugs bacteria that have evolved to survive even the most potent antibiotics doctors have started to gene-hack viruses to hunt and kill dangerous strains. Scientists have tried to use CRISPR gene-editing tools to modify viruses to kill off dangerous bacteria and ignore healthy gut bacteria for several years. But now a company called Locus Biosciences developed a mixture of three CRISPR-edited viruses that can infect and kill dangerous bacteria like a living antibiotic a promising new weapon in the fight against antibiotic resistance. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #bacteria

post336.caption: Here's a new one: a flirting chatbot aptly named "Slutbot" was created to teach people how to responsibly and respectfully flirt and sext through an iOS app called Juicebox. The idea of getting intimate with a chatbot might seem odd, but the goal is for Slutbot to help people learn to navigate conversations around sexuality and consent without the risk of alienating or insulting another person. As a queer woman collaborating with sex educators and erotic fiction writers, we were the right people to think through these concerns, Juicebox founder Brianna Rader told . Tap the link in our bio to read more. #communication

post337.caption: For the first time, police in the U.K. are going to have to defend their use of facial recognition tech in court. British office worker Ed Bridges is claiming that South Wales Police scanned his face at least twice without his permission. He believes these scans violated his human rights, an assertion he will present during a three-day court hearing that kicked off in Cardiff on Tuesday and if the court agrees with Bridges, the ruling could profoundly alter future use of facial recognition tech by law enforcement. Tap the link in our bio to learn more. #technology

post338.caption: A team from the University of Cambridge unveiled a video featuring a fleet of mini robot cars capable of autonomously switching lanes while navigating a two-lane track. The cars had a special ability: they could communicate with each other via WiFi. According to the experiments, that capability dramatically improved traffic flow evidence that well need to teach autonomous vehicles to talk to one another if we want to take full advantage of self-driving tech. Tap the link in our bio to see them navigate. #CambridgeUniversity

post339.caption: Its sadly ironic: If Earth becomes uninhabitable and we look to other planets for a new home, the only way to ensure the long term survival of the human species might be to become a completely different species. Scientists have set their sights on getting humans to Mars and maybe even terraforming the Red Planetbut despite the resources being funneled into technology to transport us to Mars, we dont yet understand the evolutionary implications the move will have on the human body. Evolutionary biologist Scott Solomon thinks its worth asking what will happen to Martian colonists in the long term as mutations start to cascade through the gene pool. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #Mars

post340.caption: UN officials are very worried about the possibility of radioactive waste leaking from a "coffin" in the ocean. Between 1946 and 1958, the U.S. government tested 67 nuclear weapons in the Marshall Islands. It later dumped radioactive waste from the tests into a crater on one of the islands, placing an 18-inch-thick concrete dome over the horrifying sludge. Because the crater was only supposed to be a temporary storage solution, the bottom of it was unlined. Thats led to recent concerns that the coffin is leaking radioactive waste into the Pacific Ocean a potentially devastating blow to both the environment and the people of the region. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #UN

post341.caption: In the coming years, scientists plan to grow human embryos in a lab using high-tech artificial wombs. Doctors at the Childrens Hospital of Philadelphia are in talks with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to begin testing artificial wombs on human embryos within the next two years, according to Metro. If theyre successful, the research could radically change the way we view pregnancy, childbirth, and perhaps even human evolution. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #childbirth

post342.caption: Scientists say that something mysterious punched gigantic, cosmic bullet holes in parts of the Milky Way. Theres a string of holes in a long stream of stars called GD-1 that suggests that some yet-undiscovered thing blasted its way through, according to research presented to the American Physical Society last month. Harvard-Smithsonian astrophysicist Ana Bonaca, the scientist who discovered the cosmic crime scene, suspects that the gigantic bullet holes may have been carved out by invisible dark matter. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #space

post343.caption: San Francisco is preemptively shooting down the use of facial recognition. On Tuesday, the California metropolis Board of Supervisors voted 8-to-1 to ban its government agencies from using facial recognition tech despite the fact that none of the agencies currently use the technology. That makes San Francisco the first city in the United States to pass such a ban and the decision could inspire others to follow suit. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #surveillance

post344.caption: R.I.P. to the grumpiest cat there ever was. The famously dour-looking internet sensation Grumpy Cat has passed away, according to obituaries by CNN and the New York Times. We could mourn the feline and move on to the next weird internet animal. Or we could embrace the latest in genetic technology and clone her like iconic singer Barbra Streisand famously did with her dog. But is that the legacy wed want for Grumpy Cat, who reportedly had a sweet personality that clashed with her perpetually ticked-off facial expression? Tap the link in our bio to read more. #GrumpyCat

post345.caption: When stars explode and die, they tend to swallow and incinerate everything around them. But sometimes exoplanets survive, left to drift the galaxy as celestial orphans. Now, a team of astronomers from the U.S. and Europe determined which planets are most likely to survive the deaths of the white dwarf stars they orbit, according to new research. Small, dense, and distant exoplanets have the best odds, which could help astronomers pinpoint even more planets in the remote cosmos. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #space

post346.caption: Have you seen this man? Or, at least, have you seen his look-a-like? The New York Police Department used photos of the acclaimed actor Woody Harrelson to catch his Doppelgngerwho was a suspected shoplifter. According to a new report, NYPD detectives noticed that a suspected shoplifter resembled Harrelson, so when the grainy surveillance footage didnt result in any useful matches in their facial recognition system, they decided to try a high-quality photo of the actor. It came up with a match, and they later arrested the look-alike for petty larcenyadding to the mounting evidence that police are using facial recognition technology however they see fit. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #WoodyHarrelson

post347.caption: CRISPR: Not for playing around. Josiah Zayner rose to internet fame after performing various biohacking stunts on himself including a livestreamed attempt to edit his own genes using CRISPR. Those antics are coming to haunt Zayner. Now, the California Department of Consumer Affairs is investigating a complaint of unlicensed practice of medicine filed against him a strange development that could have implications for the future of biohacking. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #CRISPR

post348.caption: Did you know that about 10 percent of people are left-handed, but among great pond snails lefties are even rarer? Only two percent are born with shells that are left-coiling, spiraling counter-clockwise from their smallest point. But in 2016, a Japanese scientist posited that a single gene controlled whether a snail would be right- or left-coiled. Now, she and her team have seemingly proved that the theory is correct by using CRISPR to create lefty snails a discovery that could one day help unravel the mysteries of human biology. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #nature

post349.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post350.caption: Parked Teslas keep catching fire for seemingly no reason a disturbing pattern for which the company appears to have no explanation. On April 21, a Tesla Model S burst into flames in a Shanghai parking garage. Less than two weeks later, one of the vehicles caught fire in a San Francisco parking garage. Now, Hong Kong-based newspaper Apple Daily is reporting yet another Tesla fire, and once again the vehicle was parked at the time of ignition. Tap the link in our bio to read more. #Tesla

post351.caption: Weve all seen heartbreaking pictures of dolphins trapped in plastic six-pack rings. But new research suggests that plastic pollution is hurting marine life in far subtler ways that could have dire consequences for the entire world ecosystem and threatening ten percent of the Earth's supply of breathable air. A sea-dwelling, photosynthetic bacteria called Prochlorococcus generates a tenth of the oxygen we breathe, but according to research published Tuesday in the journal Nature Communications Biology, chemicals leaching into the water from waste plastic are stunting the bacterias growth at a genetic level and potentially depriving the Earth of a precious source of breathable air. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about this startling discovery. #science

post352.caption: When Starlink, the planned constellation of SpaceX satellites that will blanket the planet, goes live in the mid 2020s, CEO Elon Musk will have a chance to give the world the gift of a free and open internet. When the satellites start beaming down high-speed internet, Musk could decide to blanket the planet with free, unrestricted internet access, returning some semblance of net neutrality to the planet something the United States has arguably been missing since the FCC gutted American net neutrality protections last year. Will Musk decide to support a free, neutral internet? Tap the link in our bio to read more. #SpaceX

post353.caption: Could re-freezing Earth's melting North and South Poles be the key to stopping the rise of our sea levels? Scientists from Cambridge University are launching a new research center to investigate possible solutions for how to re-engineer the planet to prevent or reduce the worst effects of climate change. David King, the former chief scientific adviser to the U.K. government, is among them and he says some of the solutions the research center will investigate may be considered drastic. Tap the link in our bio to read more about their efforts. #climatechange

post354.caption: These are neurons grown from the reprogrammed skin cells of science writer Philip Ball. When Ball donated some flesh from his arm to a neuroscience lab growing mini brains, he originally intended to contribute to research into the biological mechanisms of dementia. Instead, he ended up with a simplified genetic replica of his own brain growing in a petri dish and found himself questioning what makes us human, according to Ball's upcoming book "How to Grow a Human: Adventures in Who We Are and How We Are Made." Tap the link in our bio to read more. #neuroscience

post355.caption: Ever since Einstein posited that space and time were inextricably linked, scientists have wondered where the cosmic web called spacetime comes from. Now, ongoing research in quantum physics may finally arrive at an explanation: A bizarre phenomenon called quantum entanglement could be the underlying basis for the four dimensions of space and time in which we all live, according to a deep dive by Knowable Magazine. In fact, in a mind-boggling twist, our reality could be a hologram of this quantum state. Tap the link in our bio to learn more. #physics

post356.caption: Jeff Bezos finally revealed the long-awaited plans for his private space company Blue Origin to send a lander to the Moon at a mysterious press event Thursday. Bezos showed off the brand new design of a Blue Moon lander, which is designed to carry 6.5 tons to the surface of the Moon, and took three years to build. A very fundamental long-range problem is that we will run out of energy on Earth, Bezos said at the event. This is just arithmetic. It will happen. Tap the link in our bio to read more about Bezos's big announcement. #JeffBezos

post357.caption: Chris Hughes helped Mark Zuckerberg launch Facebook. But times have changed. In a New York Times op-ed titled Its Time to Break Up Facebook, Hughes argues that Facebook has gained too much power and that it should be broken up and regulated. Its been 15 years since I co-founded Facebook at Harvard, and I havent worked at the company in a decade, Hughes wrote. But I feel a sense of anger and responsibility. Tape the link in our bio to read more. #Facebook

post358.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post359.caption: Well give you the bad news first: A newly-discovered gene gives infectious bacteria the ability to survive even the strongest antibiotics. Oh, and it's highly mobile. Cornell University biologists found the bacterial gene mcr-9, which when activated makes bacteria resistant to an antibiotic of last resort called colistin. If bacteria with the gene were to spread, doctors could find themselves facing a dangerous and perhaps untreatable superbug. Click the link in our bio to learn more. #health

post360.caption: Criminals are going to have a tougher time using the dark web for illegal activity. On Tuesday, the FBI announced the seizure of Deep Dot Web, a website that provided links to dark web marketplaces the latest example of law enforcement cracking down on the shadowy side of the internet. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the FBI's fight against the dark web. #darkweb

post361.caption: Who's that Pokmon? Seasoned Pokmon masters likely know the original 151 like the back of their hand. And now, new research reveals how thats possible: brain scans show the region of the brain responsible for storing information about Pokmon. It doesn't quite suggest that our brains have a truly hard-wired"Pokmon region" but rather, researchers found, may suggest that our brains categorize information in similar ways. Given the unique style of Pokmon it's likely gamers' brains developed similar systems for pattern recognition which serves to teach us about the ways humans learn. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post362.caption: What you're seeing here is a 3D printed "lung" the size of a penny. Scientists just took a major step forward in 3D printed organs with a new lung-like system full of air sacs that can expand and contract pumping oxygen into blood just like normal lungs do. Bioprinted organs could someday help people who are waiting, and sometimes dying, on the organ transplant waitlist. Tap the link in our bio to see a video of the lung "breathing" and learn more. #health

post363.caption: An extensive HIV study has yielded a groundbreaking discovery: antiretroviral therapy completely eliminates gay mens risk of transmitting HIV through sex. Our findings provide conclusive evidence for gay men that the risk of HIV transmission with suppressive ART is zero, researcher Alison Rodger said in a press release, adding that this powerful message can help end the HIV pandemic by preventing HIV transmission and tackling the stigma and discrimination that many people with HIV face. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about this pivotal new research. #medicine

post364.caption: Fifty years ago, astronaut Buzz Aldrin became the second human to walk on the Moon. Now, hes urging the United States to make putting people on Mars a national priority and hes not talking about just a few lucky astronauts. The United States eyes and our unified commitment should focus on opening the door, in our time, to the great migration of humankind to Mars, Aldrin wrote in an op-ed for The Washington Post. Tap the link in our bio to hear more from Buzz. #Mars

post365.caption: Google might not be listening through your microphone, but the company can simulate with remarkable accuracy the conversations you're likely to have. Tristan Harris, a former Google design ethicist, says those eerily hyper-targeted ads for the very product you just talked about arent popping up because your phones mic is spying on you. Instead, Google and Facebook have gathered so much data about you and your habits that they can simulate what Harris calls a little voodoo doll, avatar-like version of people in order to predict which ads they might click or products they might buy. Click the link in our bio to read more about the futility of digital privacy. #Google

post366.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post367.caption: In November, Chinese scientist He Jiankui announced that hed genetically edited a human embryo that was implanted into a woman who then gave birth to twin girls, making them the worlds first gene-edited humans. Almost immediately, the scientific community derided the experiment as unethical and risky. Now, some are saying he demonstrated a troubling lack of the requisite understanding of genetics and gene editing meaning the twin girls might not even benefit from the risky procedure. Click the link in our bio to read more.

post368.caption: Marijuana is now legal in California, but an estimated one million people in the state still suffer the consequences of past cannabis convictions. Now, a new algorithm is making it far easier for Californians to have those convictions stricken from their records thereby eliminating the barriers that accompany a criminal record. Click the link in our bio to learn more.

post369.caption: Black holes are already one of the most peculiar phenomena in the universe, but V404 Cygni takes strangeness to the next level. Instead of spewing jets of plasma from its poles, like most black holes, astronomers caught this black hole almost 8,000 light-years from Earth shooting jets in rapidly changing directions all while its gravitational pull dragged the fabric of spacetime itself. We were gobsmacked by what we saw in this system it was completely unexpected." Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post370.caption: "What if we could expand your capabilities beyond what we as humans have ever had before?" Find out in I Am Human a new documentary from @futurismstudios, premiering at the Tribeca Film Festival on May 2nd.

post371.caption: New data from the Hubble Space Telescope confirms that the universe is expanding nine percent more rapidly than theoretical calculations predicted. The new data suggests that the universe could be substantially younger than previously believed perhaps by as much as a billion years! We're going to need to rethink our earlier calculations in order to explain this, but, as Johns Hopkins University astronomer Adam Riess put it, Hey, its good news, everybody likes to look younger. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post372.caption: Researchers have created a nanofiber yarn that they say could help repair damaged muscles and tendons. Essentially biotech sutures, the nanofiber yarn, produced by researchers from MIT and Beihang University, is made by creating tight coils out of hundreds of thousands of aligned nanofibers made from biocompatible materials. The fibers are then seeded with different types of live cells, like muscle cells, which continue to grow on the fiber. The team hopes the material could one day eliminate the need for restrictive boots currently used to help tissue injuries heal. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post373.caption: This time, artificial intelligence is literally taking jobs. Documents obtained by The Verge show how Amazon used a computer system to automatically track and fire hundreds of fulfillment center employees between for failing to meet productivity quotas a grim glimpse of a future in which AI is your boss. Tap the link in our bio to read more about Amazon's AI automation.

post374.caption: I Spy... Your internet-connected devices share a lot of the information that they collect about you, even when youre not actively using them. Thankfully, a new app will tell you when your smart speaker is spying on you. The Princeton IoT Inspector, built by a team of Princeton University scientists, uses a common hacking technique to track every transmission that a smart home device, such as an Amazon Echo or a smart TV, sends out. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post375.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post376.caption: Armed with CRISPR gene-editing technology, scientists are trying to move away from performing experiments on common model organisms, like fruit flies and zebrafish, which have long defined biological research by crafting new ones at the genetic level. But scientists developing new organisms are running into a challenging dilemma. The genetic changes made to organisms are taking hold, but it is difficult for researchers to keep the organisms alive for long afterward... Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post377.caption: US airports will scan 97% of outbound flyers faces within four years. That's according to a recent Department of Homeland Security report, which says that U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) plans to dramatically expand its Biometric Exit program to cover 97 percent of outbound air passengers within four years. The goal of the program is purportedly to catch people who have overstayed their visas but some civil liberties experts aren't so enthused... Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post378.caption: There are many things you can will for your remains when you die. Soon, residents of Washington state may have one more option. The state government is one signature away from legalizing the composting of human remains. The process outlined in the legislation, pending the governor's signature, is called recomposition, which involves placing a body in a chamber that accelerates decomposition. Over time the remains are broken down into nutrient-rich soil which can then be safely used for planting purposes adding a more green and sustainable option for your afterlife. What would you like to will for your remains? Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post379.caption: Scientists created a new material with artificial metabolism Is it alive? Well, maybe not technically. Even so, it is one step closer to creating a living machine or machines that mimic life as we know it. The new biomaterial built in a Cornell University bioengineering lab uses synthetic DNA to continuously and autonomously organize, assemble, and restructure itself in a process so similar to how biological cells and tissues grow that the researchers are calling artificial metabolism." Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post380.caption: An amazing new rocket engine sucks up atmospheric oxygen for fuel. The potentially revolutionary rocket engine is being prepared for real-world testing within the next 18 months. Reportedly the futuristic hypersonic engines being manufactured by Reaction Engines could be used to cut the journey from London to Sydney to just four hours. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post381.caption: In 2011 disaster struck the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant in Japan when an earthquake-triggered tsunami caused a loss of power leading to three nuclear meltdowns. Apart from being concerned about the potential risk of fallout reaching U.S. soil, the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission turned its attention to another frightening possibility. Could a similar fate affect a U.S. power plant? According to a Bloomberg review of correspondence between the commission and plant owners, 54 of the nuclear plants operating in the U.S. werent designed to handle the flood risk they face. Fifty-three werent built to withstand their current risk from intense precipitation; 25 didnt account for current flood projections from streams and rivers; 19 werent designed for their expected maximum storm surge. Nineteen face three or more threats that they werent designed to handle. And as sea levels continue to rising the risks are only getting greater. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post382.caption: It's not the East Coast hyperloop Musk envisioned, but it's a start. Nearly two years after Elon Musk first claimed his Boring Company had permission to build an East Coast hyperloop, the project is finally starting to come to fruition. Tap the link in bio to read more.

post383.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorites and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @futurismcartoons for more!

post384.caption: In March 2018, Yale neuroscientist Nenad Sestan shared a remarkable bit of news with his peers at a National Institutes of Health (NIH) meeting: he was able to keep pigs brains alive outside their bodies for up to 36 hours. The news quickly made its way from that meeting to the media. And now, more than a year later, the details of the radical study have finally been published in the highly respected journal Nature, confirming that what sounded initially like science-fiction was actually sound science and raising startling questions about what it really means to be dead. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post385.caption: The U.S. has officially started using CRISPR on humans. Back in June 2016, the National Institutes of Health gave a University of Pennsylvania (UPenn) research team the go-ahead to begin a human CRISPR trial. Now those trials have officially begun. The research team hopes to investigate the potential use of CRISPR as a cancer treatment in which immune cells were removed from the patients, CRISPR edited to target tumors, and then returned to the patients bodies. Only time will tell whether the treatment proves effective or not. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post386.caption: Scientists might have just figured out where nightmares come from... and no, they don't hide in the dark or lurk under your bed. New research, expected to be published Tuesday in the journal JNeurosci, tracks down which part of the brain is responsible for generating feelings of anger in sleeping people. Participants in a study who reported feeling angry during their dreams had increased neural activity in the right half of their frontal cortex, suggesting that that part of the brain is responsible for dreaming up a bad time. Tap the link in our bio to read more about where bad dreams come from.

post387.caption: In an interview with MIT researcher Lex Fridman, Tesla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk reiterated his belief that were all living inside a simulation. When Fridman asked him what his first question would be for the first-ever artificial general intelligence system, Musk replied: Whats outside the simulation? Is our reality just a simulation? If so, as Musk speculated, what awaits us outside of it? Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post388.caption: Scientists at Tel Aviv University have 3D printed a small heart using human tissue that includes vessels, collagen, and biological molecules a breakthrough, according to Haaretz, that they hope could one day render organ donation obsolete. The process isn't quite ready for transplants yet, however, but it's a start. The cells need to form a pumping ability; they can currently contract, but we need them to work together, said lead scientist Tal Dvir. Tap the link our bio to read more.

post389.caption: Scientifically speaking, how might we fight threats to life as we know it? How can we safeguard humanity's future? These are the questions we must ask ourselves. Tap the link in our to watch more.

post390.caption: New research suggests that fecal transplants can reduce the severity of conditions associated with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and that the changes last several years after the transplants. The study, published Tuesday in the journal Scientific Reports, shows that the reduction in symptoms persisted for two years after the fact, further demonstrating the link between the gut microbiome and the brain. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post391.caption: The first-ever black hole photo is even more amazing when you zoom out. While the Event Horizon Telescope was focused on the event horizon of the black hole at the center of M87, NASAs Chandra X-ray Observatory was taking a wider view of the same target and the image produced through those observations puts the black hole photo into stunning context. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this wide angle view.

post392.caption: Sometimes, organs donated to science don't always end up where they should. Not only were a father and son team from Michigan just charged for illegally selling human body parts which had been donated for scientific purposes but the duo also failed to disclose that the corpses carried infectious diseases. Strangely enough, selling body parts isn't always illegal but with more than meets the eye involved in these sales, these two body part pilferers face several criminal charges. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post393.caption: A new quantum material could one day transfer information directly from human brains to a computer. Like a backup hard drive for your brain, if your natural brain functions began to falter, it could allow you to continue remembering things like normal. Although the device is in early stages still, it seems we are one step closer to true brain-computer interfaces. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the new quantum material scientists say could download your brain."

post394.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post395.caption: This is the first-ever image of a black hole. On Wednesday, an international coalition of scientists that came together to form the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) more on that later announced via livestream that they had captured direct images of a supermassive black hole in the M87 galaxy. These images signify that scientists have finally seen, first hand, celestial bodies that up until recently were only assumed to exist. Because the light observed by the EHT has warped around the black hole before traveling to Earth, the shadow we see is actually the entire surface of the black hole, as though it had been ripped open and flattened like a pancake, surrounded by a disk of orbiting light. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this world first and what the discovery means in scientific communities.

post396.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post397.caption: The organ shortage will soon get worse. Animal organs could help. Nearly 75,000 Americans need an organ transplant. Of those, an estimated 18 will die today because they didnt get one soon enough. The bottom line is that there just arent enough donor organs available to meet the nations need. Soon, in a strange twist, self-driving cars could exacerbate the problem by reducing the number of car accidents, which is currently one of the primary sources of donor organs. Researchers across the globe are hunting for ways to save patients. And now, an idea previously relegated to the realm of science fiction is starting to look like a viable option: transplanting organs from animals into humans. The growing crisis means that when it comes to such a radical idea, "Its no longer a question of if. Its just a question of when." Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post398.caption: Scientists say new cyborg plants could someday grow on Mars. In new research, Australian scientists show how plants can be augmented with nanomaterials that make them better at absorbing sunlight and may help them survive on futuristic Martian farms. We've long been able to introduce other materials to plants, but by introducing new nanomaterials called Metal-Organic Frameworks (MFOs) we amplify plants' natural abilities. Tap the link in our bio to read more about so-called "superplants."

post399.caption: This company is gamifying books to make them more like Fortnite. If old-fashioned books are too boring for you, ebook distributor OverDrive wants to gamify them with interactive elements and video game-inspired achievements and badges for kids who finish their reading homework. OverDrives student-focused reading app, Sora, takes notes from the same elements that help make Fortnite so addictive. How else is OverDrive changing the script on the future of reading? Tap the link in our bio to read this Futurism exclusive.

post400.caption: This weekend, brought to you by climate change.

post401.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post402.caption: So-called evolutionary roboticists raise the question: why go to the trouble of building a new and improved machine when current robots could do it for you? The idea invokes a high-tech Darwinism, in which researchers ultimate goal is to design artificial intelligence and robots that can analyze their own source code and mate with others by combining bits and pieces of their code with that of other robots to create offspring, much like organic life. Tap the link in our bio to read more about what happens when robotics takes biologic inspiration.

post403.caption: "Fake alcohol" which induces a buzzed sensation without the state of being drunk may soon be hitting store shelves. For more than a decade, scientist David Nutt had been developing a synthetic alcohol substitute he calls Alcarelle. He claims his creation has the potential to allow drinkers to enjoy all the benefits of alcohol and none of the drawbacks meaning it could bring an end to everything from hangovers to alcohol-related cancers. (You'll still need to drink responsibly though!) Tap the link in our bio to read more about the future of "fake alcohol."

post404.caption: Tech-savvy DJs have a whole new way to drop a beat. Instead of using sequencers and turntables, some DJs are writing code that generates sounds and beats in real time, assembling new tracks on the fly during whats become known as an algorave. "Hey, DJ! Code us a beat." Tap the link in our bio to read more about the "algorave."

post405.caption: Ready to take a journey to the center of our galaxy? Strap in and hold tight youre about to be teleported into a 360-degree rendering of the center of the Milky Way galaxy. The ultra-high-definition visualization comes courtesy of data collected by the Chandra X-ray Observatory, a space observatory that launched into orbit in 1999. NASAs Ames supercomputer rendered the data as a stunning simulation you can experience from the comfort of home. Tap the link in our bio to sail through the stars.

post406.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post407.caption: Chinese officials have cloned a top-performing police dog, state media announced, with the goal of "mass producing" genetically identical dog cops. The pup, Kunxun, just started police dog training, to see whether the original dogs aptitude for drug detection and crowd control have carried over. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this case of a doubled dog.

post408.caption: Cambridge scientists say they've grown a miniature brain in a petri dish that seizes control of biological material around it. Unlike previous lab-grown brains, this one actively will send out "tendrils" to connect to a spinal cord removed from a mouse and can then use its new spine to control a mouse muscle attached to it. There are many questions left unanswered, but the novel approach could open doors to new surgeries and new avenues of research. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this newly grown brain.

post409.caption: As always, weve got some news about the future. Except this time, its about us. Were about to enter the next chapter of Futurism, one that will usher in a new era for this site. Itll come with new ways well be able to deliver on everything youve grown to read, watch, subscribe to, and love about what we do here. And also, more in volume of what we do, with larger ambitions, and ultimately, a higher level of quality with which were able to bring those ambitions to fruition. As of today, Futurism Media is proud to announce that were joining operations with Singularity University. Tap the link in bio to read more about what this change means for our future.

post410.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post411.caption: Get ready, this is wild. Russian scientists used a quantum computer to turn back time. Before you get carried away, the finding is unlikely to lead to a time machine that would work on people. But the team of physicists managed to restore IBMs public quantum computer to the state it had been in just a moment earlier, according to research published Wednesday in the journal Nature Scientific Reports a nuanced result, but one that could have striking implications for the future of computing, quantum physics, and our understanding of time itself. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this quantum time turner.

post412.caption: NASA engineers have captured the first images of the interaction between shockwaves from a pair of flying supersonic aircraft and they are stunning. Were seeing a level of physical detail here that I dont think anybody has ever seen before, senior research engineer Dan Banks said in a NASA press release. Just looking at the data for the first time, I think things worked out better than wed imagined. We never dreamt that it would be this clear, this beautiful, physical scientist J.T. Heineck added.

post413.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post414.caption: All bots go to heaven. Jibo, the company selling anthropomorphic dancing smart home assistants that were meant to make your life at home easier, laid off most of its employees last year. And now the bot itself is ready to say goodbye forever. I want to say Ive really enjoyed our time together, the robot says in a video posted by tech reporter Dylan Martin. Thank you very very much for having me around. Tap the link in our bio to see Jibo's fond farewell.

post415.caption: Startups that sequence your DNA to help piece together your ancestry have a new target market, according to a story in The Atlantic: your long-dead ancestors, who may have inadvertently left behind genetic material when they licked stamps and envelopes. Maybe our ancestors did not realize it, MyHeritage founder Gilad Japhet said at an industry conference last year, according to The Atlantic, but when they were licking those stamps and the envelope flats, they were sealing their precious DNA for you forever. Tap the link in our bio to read more about DNA and the deceased.

post416.caption: The European Union is displeased with tech giants Google, Facebook, and Twitter because all three corporations have failed to prevent the spread of fake news. In October, the three companies agreed to a voluntary pledge to fight the political misinformation that proliferated on their platforms, as an alternative to harsher legislation being enacted against them in Europe. But after months of progress, it seems EU officials feel the three companies aren't doing enough. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post417.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post418.caption: Chemists grew a synthetic brain that stores memories in silver and one of its creators thinks it could usher in "the post-human revolution." In the ongoing quest to build an artificial human brain, scientists from UCLA may have just taken a big step forward. While a real synthetic brain is still far away, a team of chemical engineers found out how to grow self-assembling circuitry that resembles the structure and electrical activity of parts of a brain. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this "thinking machine".

post419.caption: The United States used to send about 40 percent of the recyclables it collected to China for processing. But in early 2018, China decided to stop importing much of this foreign garbage, and that decision has left U.S. cities struggling to process mountains of recyclables so now, in a bleak twist, theyre sometimes just burning them. The resulting emissions can have lasting health and environmental impacts. Tap the link in our bio to read more about a situation which generally just stinks.

post420.caption: The people who moderate Facebook spend their days reading and watching conspiracy theories, violent murders, and hate speech, often hundreds of times per day. The sheer volume of intense content they see can have lasting social and psychological consequences so severe that many moderators are coping by getting high and having sex during work. The revelations beg the question, who should be responsible for moderating and how can they themselves be supported? Tap the link in our bio to read more about Facebook's freaked out moderators.

post421.caption: Soon, researchers will launch a clinical trial in which theyll attempt to bathe the brains of people with the increased-risk version of the gene linked to Alzheimer's disease (APOE4) with viruses carrying the lowered-risk version of the same gene (APOE2) and it could lead to a novel gene therapy for one of the worlds most devastating diseases. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this "brainwashing" approach to an Alzheimer's treatment.

post422.caption: When infamous Chinese scientist He Jiankui edited the genes of human twin babies last year, he was reportedly trying to make them immune to HIV. But researchers familiar with the genetic changes he made are now saying that the specific manipulation he performed may have broader consequences. The CCR5 gene is linked to HIV susceptibility, but research published Thursday in the journal Cell shows that it also enhances cognition in mouse studies. In short, it's possible that the first two enhanced humans with genetically boosted cognition and memory... may already be born. Tap the link in our bio to read more about these gene-hacked twins.

post423.caption: We still have a lot of questions to answer before autonomous vehicles can go mainstream: Whos at fault if an AV has an accident? Should people need licenses to ride in a self-driving car? How should an AV decide between running over a dog or a cat? Now we have yet another question how should AVs interact with law enforcement? and the solution might involve ceding control of your car to cops. Tap the link in our bio to read more AVs, PDs, and the future of law enforcement.

post424.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post425.caption: Tomorrow's farms will look nothing like the rolling fields we know today. In fact, there's a good chance the future of farming may take place indoors. Tap the link in our bio to watch more about the vertical future of farming.

post426.caption: Elon Musk is talking cryptocurrency. The real Elon Musk, not one of those Twitter scammers. On Tuesday, Teslas CEO sat down for a podcast interview with ARK Invest, a tech investment firm. In addition to chatting about electric vehicles and self-driving cars, the interviewers decided to throw Musk an off-topic question about cryptocurrencies. Tap the link in our bio to read more about Bitcoin through Musks's eyes.

post427.caption: Californians may soon get a cut of the proceeds when tech giants like Facebook sell their personal data. During his State of the State address on Tuesday, Governor Gavin Newsom announced his support for an initiative which would require tech companies to pay people for their personal data a move that could permanently upset the balance of power between the worlds biggest tech corporations and their users. Tap the link in our bio to read more future of your data.

post428.caption: Amazon has chosen Valentines Day to break up with New York. On Thursday the massive e-retailer announced it was pulling out of its deal to open a second headquarters, referred to as HQ2, after facing resistance from NYC residents and lawmakers. It's unclear what the company's next moves may be, but withdrawing now may help create a more welcoming climate for Amazon to move into New York at a later date. Tap the link in our bio to read more about Amazon's decision to see other people.

post429.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post430.caption: In 2017 the U.S. Navy revealed a futuristic laser weapon mounted on a transport vessel which the media dubbed the world's first active laser weapon. Now the U.S. Air Force wants in on the laser weapon trend. The Pentagon released new plans which detail the use of F-35 fighter jets equipped with laser weapons to help defend the United States. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the Pentagon's plans for planes with lasers.

post431.caption: To the who helped humanity progress, and all of the women who are future pioneers, we're grateful for the contributions of women in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics! #womeninscienceday

post432.caption: An international team of scientists has claimed to discovery the "neurological signature" of consciousness within the brain. The quest to discover the source of consciousness is one that spans decades. Many researchers have ventured guesses but now we may finally know the answer. Rather than a specific chunk of the brain thats responsible for consciousness, the researchers say theyve located a brain-wide pattern of activity thats only present when people are awake and responsive. The finding could lead to additional research into how these patterns can be altered through injury, drugs, or other factors. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this brain-tingling discovery.

post433.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post434.caption: Self-propelling pills that work like tiny speedboats could mean the end of needle vaccines. A new type of tiny motor could help shuttle medicine to wherever it needs to be within the body. It could make a world of difference for infants, or if you're like us and just don't like needles. More effective medicine and fewer shots. Now that's a future we can get behind! Tap the link in our bio to read more about the tiny tech making medicine more user friendly.

post435.caption: Is the US being a bad space roommate? Russian media is reporting that the American toilet on the International Space Station burst late last week, spilling gallons of fluid that astronauts had to catch with towels. Over 10 liters (roughly 2.5 gallons) of water leaked before the problem was fixed. Navigating the bathroom situation between you and your roommate can be high stakes enough, but it's a whole other level when bathroom negotiations also involve international relations. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the roommate issue.

post436.caption: The Russian Navy has outfitted two warships with a weapon that it says makes enemies hallucinate and become disoriented. It may also induce dizziness and nausea. The weapon works using high-powered flashes of light that disrupt night vision and rangefinder devices. Despite the frightful sounding side effects, some have pointed out that a light based weapon might be easy to counter. Tap the link in bio to read more.

post437.caption: Before his passing, Gerry Cotten, the founder of crypto exchange QuadrigaCX, amassed $137 million worth of Bitcoin safely tucked away in an encrypted cold wallet. The only problem is that Cotten was the only one who knew who knew how to access these funds. Now the fortune, which accounts for most of the company's funds, is inaccessible and QuadrigaCX's business practices have come under fire. It's a prime example of the way in which blockchain technology, which can help promote accountability and transparency, can also allow companies to operate without legal oversight a glaring problem when it comes to financial matters. Tap the link in our bio to read more about this cautionary tale which teaches a lesson on the importance of password management.

post438.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post439.caption: Physicists have long assumed that the mysterious force they call dark energy was a constant. But now, strange new observations from quasars suggest that it could be getting stronger over time. Some scientists suggest the discovery may require us to rethink our understanding of physics in order for this dark matter behavior to be properly explained.

post440.caption: In this case the chickens came before the eggs. Genetically modified chickens have been made to lay eggs containing anti-cancer drugs. To get the chickens to lay the enhanced eggs, researchers spliced a human gene into the animal's DNA. Tap the link in our bio to read more about these bio-hacked hens.

post441.caption: An early Waymo One rider spoke with Futurism about their experience with the developing autonomous rideshare service. New details indicate that surprising choices made by selfdriving vehicles, like taking unnecessary u-turns or failing to merge onto a highway, still plague Waymo One's progress toward autonomy. Tap the link in our bio to read about one rider's firsthand experience in an autonomous vehicle.

post442.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post443.caption: For some, climate change won't be all that bad. Despite extreme weather events occurring more frequently and global temperatures continuing to rise, Apple hasn't begun to sweat just yet. In fact the iconic electronics company says that as the climate worsens, the iPhones utility at keeping people connected will instill a greater sense of brand loyalty among its customers. So, hey, the world may be dying, but at least there's a rose gold lining somewhere, right? Tap the link in our bio to read more about Apple's take on climate change.

post444.caption: Cotton sprouts grew on the Moon! Now, granted, the plants have long since died but it still marks the first time a plant has sprouted on the Moon. It's groundbreaking work, but it isn't the first time we've had plants in space. Tap the link in our bio to watch more about the future of outer space agriculture.

post445.caption: Nature dealt SpaceX a powerful blow on Tuesday night as hurricane-force gusts tore through southern Texas. The strength of the wind caused SpaceX's Starship to break free of its mooring blocks and sent it toppling over, causing damage that will take "a few weeks" to repair, according to Elon Musk. Though undoubtedly a setback, the damage probably won't keep SpaceX from continuing to reach for the stars. Tap the link in our bio to see more of what's become of the once mighty Starship.

post446.caption: Organ donor waitlists are horrifically long. To cut down the wait time for those in need, many scientists have explored 3D-printed organs as an option. The trouble with things like lungs and hearts is that they break so easily. No, seriously, the complex structures tend to collapse under their own weight when printed in labs. That's why 3D printing startup Techshot is teaming up with NASA to send a biological 3D printer to space where research will focus extensively on printing heart tissue. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the future of 3D-printing organs in space.

post447.caption: In a real life "I don't feel so good" moment, astronomers are watching as a Neptune-sized planet disintegrates. About 800 light years away, K2-22b is literally having a hard time keeping itself together. The Neptune-sized rocky planet has been crumbling into pieces since before astronomers first discovered it back in 2015. Scientists hope to learn as much as they can about how and why planets fall apart before the doomed planet meets its inevitable fate. Tap the link in bio to read more about the exoplanet that has our newsroom saying, "Mr. Stark..."

post448.caption: We already knew that the U.S. Department of Defense had secretly funded research on unidentified flying objects yes, UFOs thanks to 2017 reporting by the New York Times and the Washington Post. Now, new documents released by the Defense Intelligence Agency reveal that the program also studied a laundry list of topics that sound like plot devices from The X-Files, including UFOs, warp drive, extra dimensions, and traversable wormholes. Tap the link in our bio read more about military research on a lot of fringe science.

post449.caption: Antibiotics help livestock stay healthy but overusing them can cause major problems. Here's what's up with antibiotics, superbugs, and your food. Tap the link in our bio to hear more about how farmers and the government can make sure antibiotics aren't being abused.

post450.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post451.caption: Lab rats paralyzed from spinal cord injuries regained the ability to walk after scientists gave them 3D-printed implants loaded up with stem cells. The implants were biocompatible scaffolds full of minuscule channels through which stem cells could grow. They bridged across the injured section of the rats spinal cord and restored function to the rats back legs, according to research published Monday in the journal Nature Medicine. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post452.caption: The human brain reconstructs memories in reverse order. According to new research, the brain works in reverse order to reconstruct memories it starts big and moves on to the small and this discovery could help us understand everything from how aging affects our memories to post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Tap the link in our bio to read more about the mind and memory.

post453.caption: In June, public opinion and data company YouGov surveyed 2,000 Americans to gauge their feelings about artificial intelligence (AI). According to the recently released survey results, just 41 percent of Americans support advancing AI. Experts fear that lack of consensus combined with a lack of faith in AI developers could prevent the tech from reaching its potential. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post454.caption: A former US senator wants congress to listen to UFO reports. Its been just over a year since the U.S. Defense Department officially declassified two videos that showed an encounter between two Navy F/A-18F fighter jets and an unidentified flying object (UFO). Now, former Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-NV) a longtime proponent of UFO research is calling on Congress to review reports like the Navy encounter, which the Defense Department has collected for years as part of a program dubbed Black Money. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post455.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post456.caption: In about 10 billion years, our sun will harden into a giant crystal. According to new research published in the journal "Nature", white dwarf stars in their old age will cool into enormous and super-heavy crystal orbs the likely fate of our Sun, in about 10 billion years. It's possible that billions of white dwarf stars in our galaxy have already gone through this process. The findings confirm a longstanding theory among astronomers. Tap the link in our bio to read more about these crystallizing stars.

post457.caption: New research suggests that giant, rotating black holes could be portals for hyperspace travel under specific conditions. For years, scientists have theorized that black holes could serve as portals for interdimensional travel. But theres always been a problem: how could a hyperspace traveler ever approach a black hole without getting torn to teeny-tiny shreds by the black holes unholy gravitational forces? It turns out that some black holes are gentler than others. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post458.caption: It may seem silly, but simple tin foil can offer your car a lot of protection from hackers. A makeshift Faraday cage could mean the difference between thwarting a would-be hack attack or waking up to find your ride missing. Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the method behind the madness.

post459.caption: A bionic face brain implant could help treat facial paralysis. The device works by copying neural activity from one half of the face and sending it to the paralyzed part. The ultimate goal is to restore natural movement to people with facial palsy or other conditions which would limit facial motions. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post460.caption: Road rage is no longer relegated to the road. A bizarre trend has emerged in which drivers of vehicles with traditional combustion engines have been harassing Tesla drivers, purposely blocking off Tesla Supercharer stations with their vehicles. The act has come to be known as ICEing, a verb form of the acronym for internal combustion engine." Tap the link in our bio to read more about the emerging culture war between Tesla drivers and truck drivers.

post461.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post462.caption: We've all dialed the wrong number before, it happens. Dialing the wrong number, it turns out, even happens to astronauts. In a new radio interview with Dutch public broadcaster Nederlandse Omroep Stichting, Netherlands astronaut Andr Kuipers recalled how he accidentally ended up calling American emergency services while on board the International Space Station (ISS). Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post463.caption: Washington may become the first state to legalize human composting thanks to a bill being sponsored in the states legislature. The bill seeks to expand the kinds of options people have when it comes to their final wishes. Researchers have been developing methods for safely decomposing human remains into a nutrient rich soil. Tap the link in our bio to read more. Editors note: We had to rearrange some vegetables so our skeleton friend could rest in peace.

post464.caption: Researchers in China have reportedly lost track of patients who underwent human gene-editing trials. In the U.S., the Food and Drug Administration recommends that researchers follow up with patients in gene therapy trials for 15 years. No such recommendation exists in China and without any follow up no one knows for sure how the editing may affect patients in the longer term. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post465.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post466.caption: According to one of the astronauts aboard NASAs 1968 Apollo 8 mission, it would be stupid and almost ridiculous to pursue a crewed mission to Mars. Anders argued that there are plenty of things that NASA could be doing that would be a better use of time and money, like the unmanned InSight rover that recently touched down to study Mars interior. The crux of the problem? Which will have the biggest impact on future research crewed or robotic missions? Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post467.caption: Name a problem and someone is probably trying to use artificial intelligence to solve it. So finding a use for Christmas leftovers should be a piece of (fruit)cake for AI, right? Scientists at Stanford University set out to do just that and the results, while creative, were... somewhat less than savory... Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post468.caption: Caption this! We'll choose our favorite and give you a shout-out in our story on Friday. Follow @FuturismCartoons for more comics!

post469.caption: Your home is likely a hotbed of toxins, with everything from formaldehyde to chloroform finding its way into the air you breathe daily. Houseplants can help remove some toxins from the air, but not in dramatic amounts. It turns out we can boost the detoxing ability of a common houseplant. All it takes is a little DNA from an ordinary rabbit. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post470.caption: Andy Thomas doesnt mince words. Thomas is one of Australias most celebrated astronauts, having flown four missions with NASA and helping launch the Australian Space Agency. On Monday, he participated in a press conference in promotion of the newly formed agency. During the conference, he shared his thoughts on Richard Bransons Virgin Galactic and what he had to say wasnt exactly complimentary. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post471.caption: It's official: U.S. President Donald Trump signed an executive order Tuesday for the creation of a "U.S. Space Command." The first U.S. Space Command was founded in 1985 and disbanded in 2002. The newly created Space Command would "streamline command and control of time-sensitive operations" and "consolidate space operations under a single authority." Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post472.caption: The scientific community has largely denounced He Jiankui, the researcher who recently claims to have used CRISPR to alter the genomes of twin babies in China. A key critique has been that CRISPR's effects aren't understood well enough to guarantee the twins safety. In fact, mutated animals show why Gene editing isn't ready for human trials. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

post473.caption: Scams demanding cryptocurrency payments are an old phenomenon that have taken a dark new twist. post647.caption: On this day, May 15, 1857, Scottish-American astronomer Williamina Fleming was born. Fleming trained a generation of all-women human "computers" at Harvard College Observatory and recorded observations of thousands of stars using a system she devised. She is credited with discovering 310+ stars, 10 novae, and 10 nebulae, including the Horsehead Nebula. Much of Fleming's work was credited to her male colleagues at the time but, thankfully, is recognized today. In 1906, Fleming was made an honorary member of the Royal Astronomical Society of London, the first American woman to receive the honor.
